I've kept coming back to this film over the years and am firmly convinced that besides being John Hughes's finest work, it is THE teen comedy. Hilariously perfect in every respect.Sensibly eschewing the wholesale teenage angst of many of his other pre-adult films, Hughes just focuses wholly on comedy tinged with a liberal dose of gentle satire, which is generally manifested in a continuous Mickey-taking of adult behaviour. In Ferris's world adults don't understand the teenagers in their care, be it Ferris's parents or the high school principal Mr Noonan, who makes it his mission in life to catch Ferris in the act of doing something he shouldn't be doing. His litany of comedic failures contrast markedly with Ferris's success in doing all the things in just one epic day off school, that many of us might not have the nerve to do in a lifetime. He is aided and accompanied in his adventures with girlfriend Sloane and best pal Cameron.The casting is perfect with Matthew Broderick excelling as the exuberant, witty hero in what is undoubtedly his most famous role. Not to be outshone though is Alan Ruck in what is arguably his most beloved role as the also talented, but far less self-confident Cameron. Amazingly, the near 30 year old Ruck convincingly looks the part. Mia Sara is suitably elegant as Sloane, whilst Jeffrey Jones uproariously and inevitably plays the hapless coyote, to Ferris's always superior road runner. One cannot look past Jennifer Grey either, as Ferris's bitter but attractive younger sister, Jeanie. Both Charlie Sheehan's (police station) and Ben Stein's (form teacher) cameos are not to be missed by anyone ... anyone?The Windy City of Chicago plays its extremely functional part in all of its late spring (actually early autumn) glory. Memorable side trips include the observation deck of Sears Tower, Wrigley Field, the Chicago Art Institute and the stand out Von Steuben's Day Parade where the famous lip-sync of Twist and Shout occurs with a good deal of both improvised and choreographed dancing among the crowd.Hughes's decision to have his lead character frequently break the fourth wall was a winner, as were the many striking camera angles used and the music selected for the soundtrack.John Hughes passed away far too early. But in Ferris Bueller's Day Off, he left a lasting legacy full of cross-generational appeal. It's a classic!

reviews.review_title: Never had a day off like this!
reviews.content: Even today, I've wondered why this film is so loved by many people today. I guess it's because it was made during the decade that will never die, the 1980's. I've often felt that the reason people cherish the 80's is because the 1990's and the oughts of 2000 haven't got anything to distinguish them. Even in 2002 or 2003, we seem to be still stuck in the 1990's. Unless this decade has a style that will distinguish it, the 1980's will continue to be beloved. All the excesses of the 1980's are here.The story is pretty simple: Ferris Bueller (Mathew Broderick), a young man who seems to be in a class by himself, fakes an illness so he and his girlfriend Sloane Peterson (the cute Mia Sara) and best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) can traipse through Chicago. While he's out there, his "enemies" are out to ruin his afternoon. Jeffrey Jones is Ed Rooney, the Principal of his HS who is trying to bust Ferris for past truancy and is out to look for him. Jennifer Grey (who looked ancient in this film and was dating Broderick at the time) plays his older sister Jeanie, who wants to also ruin the day for him but ends up being the one with the bad day.Yes, the film has decent acting and is a somewhat fun romp, but the film was made to once again show everyone why the 80's was such a storied decade. The excesses are here: the big dance and song routine at the parade, Grey's outfit, the fact that Ferris' mother (Cindy Pickett) has a more hip hairstyle than her daughter, etc. You could never remake this one today, the 2000's haven't earned any distinct image yet. Not a favorite of mine, but I can understand those 80's lovers fawning over this. I guess I prefer to revere the 80's through video games like Grand Theft Auto:Vice City and Activision Anthology and the music (not the videos).

reviews.review_title: THE Greatest Teen Comedy Movie Ever Made
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's Day Off has stood the test of time and is as clever and witty today as it was when it first came out in 1986. The perfect teen movie, where every adult in the film is portrayed as a buffoon or imbecile. FBDO captures the warmth and angst of teens with humor, depth, and heart. One of Hughes's masterpieces that should be watched in every cinema studies class in film school. A pièce de résistance in casting. FBDO has enormously contributed and impacted US pop culture in so many ways and on too many levels to state. A national treasure.

This movie was awful. I have no idea why this film became a cult classic, but I suggest strongly avoiding this one. The only good things about this movie are the "Oh Yeah" song, the famous "Bueller, Bueller, Bueller" scene and the scenes involving a Rottweiler chasing down Jeffrey Jones' character, Ed Rooney.

When describing 1980s cinema the word typical comes to mind very often. Unfortunately "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" does not break the trend. Is it a good film? Yes, but barely. Is it enjoyable? Once again yes, but barely. In short the film slips by the whole way and just barely overcomes its two-star premise. The reason? John Hughes' smart screenplay and his over-achieving direction are the main reasons why the film works most of the time. Matthew Broderick and friends Mia Sara and Alan Ruck take a Friday off from high school and travel all around the city of Chicago. The whole way they dodge Broderick's parents and their evil high school principal (Jeffrey Jones). Overall the film is watchable, but it is not as good as many think. In short it is another one of John Hughes' curious over-achievers. 3.5 out of 5 stars.

I've recently met too many people in their twenties that haven't actually seen this film (although they're familiar with it). Twenty-six years later, however, it's still hilariousthe fashion and technology are outdated, but the comedy is timeless, and the commentary on society is still keen. Broderick reminds you that every day is an adventure waiting to happenget off your couch and carpe diem! Ben Stein became famous from this film by demonstrating the pitfalls of the lecture system in high schools. With the help of burn-out street therapist Charlie Sheen, Jennifer Grey shows you how sibling jealousy will only hold you back in your enjoyment of your own life. And Ruck exhibits how rich, repressed kids can turn into ticking time bombs.This movie is a pop culture icon. The recent Honda CR-V Super Bowl commercial is a testament to that. If you haven't seen this flick yet, your penance is throwing an 80s party within the next couple of weeks, featuring an old-school boombox, Pop Rocks & Mountain Dew, and a screening of this filmand invite me; I'm there.For more reviews and a kickass podcast, check out www.livemancave.com

This movie had survived the test of time. I saw it recently and still laughed my ass off. Plus: it's the best tourist guide of the city of Chicago you'll ever find. Who can forget the role that made Ben Stein a legend? John Hughes, who will be remembered as the director who made the 1980s his decade, reached his peak with this film. A neo-classic.

reviews.review_title: Overrated, despite doing some things right
reviews.content: When Ferris Buellers day off was released in 1986, it got so much positive reviews and became so famous it had a lot of movies/ TV shows reference it. That's just a brief history of a movie that I think is actually really overrated, frankly. But how come? The story in this is about a teen wise guy named Ferris who pretends to be sick so that he can force his friend to go and lie to get his girlfriend out of school so that the 3 can spend a day in Chicago. The problem with the story is that its just weak. I mean, just a highly sophisticated plan for a day off of school? That's not all. There's no emotional journey for the protagonist, no real drama, and no heartwarming moments. There's also no message. I mean, this film is so lighthearted they lacked all those things. But one thing people might be wondering, is at least funny? Well, the movie actually has some really great humor and plus its a little enjoyable to watch with a great soundtrack. But that still doesn't make up for the pitiful main story. Also, one really bad thing about this movie is that it makes skipping school when there's something important like a test without permission from your parents or teachers so that you can have fun look cool, which is a not a good message at all. I give it a 4.5/10 The characters in this movie. Let me say that they are just one dimensional with no development. First off, our main character, Ferris, is a high school hot shot who's selfish, unlikable when he bully's his Ill friend to go on the trip, and a liar. Like I said, he makes skipping school and being selfish look cool. He is an absolutely terrible role model for kids. His ill friend Cameron, is a character that you can feel bad for because of not wanting to be on the trip to Chicago but he's actually a great guy whose honest, kind, and doesn't find Ferris's selfish acts cool. Ferris's girlfriend Sloane is just a one dimensional girl who agrees to go to Chicago and forgettable. The "Villain" Principal Ed Rooney, is actually good because of trying to bust Ferris, but pointlessly bumbles around the suburbs doing so and has no development, but he's a bit funny. Then there's Ferris's sister, Jeanie, who is aware of Ferris's whereabouts. She's very bland and instantly forgettable.So overall, Ferris Beullers day of is funny, has great music and is enjoyable, but it still has a weak story, and lacks any real drama, emotion, and character development. The characters are all one dimensional with a couple of bland ones. So this movie is just a light hearted comedy, and if you want a movie with a valuable message, this is not it.

I've known if this film for a while but always been hesitant to get round to it as I don't really mix with comedies that are considered "classic" but this was one that certainly lived up to expectations. Postmodern but not overly pretentious and highly relatable I felt I watched it at just the right time personally as I can fully understand all the jokes and the characters situations. It's bold and ambitious in a way not too dissimilar to Home Alone and those high stakes usually result in some hilarious jokes. Packing in exceptional word play and other smaller scale physical jokes there's so much on offer here to laugh at as well as a serious and emotional "subplot" of sorts. A true classic of cinema and one I'd regard as in my all time 10
Classic John Hughes. Tapping into the teenage mindset. It's consistently funny throughout with hardly a quiet moment. What kid hasn't faked sick? What kid hasn't fantasized the perfect fake sick day?

I've always loved 80's movies. So when I saw that this was on Netflix I was excited. It's a funny look at how to skip school. (Don't worry, it would never work today) However, when I finished watching this I thought: "This is the basic premise of a typical Phineas and Ferb episode." Kid plans something big. Parents are oblivious. Only sister knows truth. Tries to get brother in trouble. Fails. Evil guy vs. family pet. So yeah, Phineas and Ferb doesn't seem very original now. And this is so much better, anyway. It's got teen hijinks, humor, and is just all-around fun movie for the mid-high school-crowd. Grade: B- (took away points for profanity, and lots of it) 8/10 3.5/5

reviews.review_title: We could all use a day off like "Ferris"...
reviews.content: In the late producer/writer/director John Hughes's blockbuster 1986 teen-comedy "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," cool, easy-going Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) fakes being terribly ill in order to spend a care-free day in downtown Chicago with his beautiful girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) and his best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck).All the while, the trio are pursued by Edward R. Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), the dean of their high school who's out to catch them by any means necessary, and Ferris's younger sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey), who resents his free-spirited ways and for always getting away with his complex schemes.That alone would be enough to make the movie last for its two hour running time, but John Hughes, that "adolescent philosopher" (in the words of the late film critic Roger Ebert) who also made "Sixteen Candles" (1984) and "The Breakfast Club" (1985) and understood the teenage condition better than anyone else in his time, seems to have other things on his mind.In keeping up with one key theme from his two previous features, Hughes examines how the events of a single fateful day can forever change the lives of his teenage protagonists. In "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," Ferris Bueller faking being sick in order to ditch school is actually less about him having a good time in downtown Chicago than it is about helping his high-strung best friend Cameron develop some much-needed self-respect in order to stand up to a bullying and neglectful father. (In short, while the film is ultimately about Matthew Broderick's title character, its true emotional center is Alan Ruck's troubled Cameron Frye and his overcoming a dysfunctional family life.)Of course, this doesn't mean that "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is devoid of the usual teen movie antics. This movie is laugh-out funny; its laughs haven't diminished one bit over the years. I haven't seen "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" in a good long while; the film was a perennial favorite of mine during my early teen years in the late '90s, and I remember watching the film almost to the point of memorization during that time. In watching the film again today for the first time in years, it has yet to lose any of its appeal. Matthew Broderick was perfect for the role of Ferris Bueller, and it remains his most famous film role to date - though, one should not overlook his commanding performance in the Civil War drama "Glory" (1989). He's as appealing and charming as he's ever been, or will ever be.Now here, and in closing, we get a little bit personal. In watching this film today, it was a very conscious decision on my part. I realized I myself needed a "day off" - by enjoying a movie that's about leisure and taking it easy and forgetting your problems. And just having a good laugh. In getting over the recent failure of a really difficult relationship, I found a sense of peace and catharsis in this film that I didn't realize would be there. It's proof to me, that this movie isn't really dated - though it is very much a product of its era in the mid-'80s.I would recommend that anyone who needs a "day off" from the troubles of everyday life, watch "Ferris Bueller's Day Off." I promise you, it'll be the best "day off" you'll ever have.10/10P. S.: And Ben Stein is utterly hilarious in one of the single funniest, completely improvised scenes in film history. And Charlie Sheen's brief cameo, while funny, also turned out to be eerily prophetic...

reviews.review_title: The movie was not only unrealistic but had a bad message I feel
reviews.content: I did not enjoy the movie at all. There's nothing in this film that is worth appreciation. I have been teen once upon a time but I feel I surely would not have liked it even then. The teen in this movie seems to get away with anything and everything bad and the grown ups are shown as a bunch of idiots who can never catch him. His parents don't even get a hint of what he is up to!! The movie is a dark spot for parental/kids relationship. I feel sorry for those who liked such a movie but I would never want my kids to see such a movie. I did not like anybody's acting either! If there was a lower rating than one (1) star for this I would have definitely gone for that.

reviews.review_title: Life goes too fast so take a day off
reviews.content: An irreverent eighties comedy with only one message, the one above. Mostly harmless slapstick but there was one utterly cringe worthy moment when Ferris pretending to be his girlfriend, Sloane's father who came to pick her up in order to cut school without getting caught starts snogging her and the principal/headmaster was like eh I guess that's how they greet in the family. Yikes! Not as bad as the comedies nowadays though.

When I think of Matthew Broderick, I picture Ferris Bueller. I haven't seen him in anything else except the 1998 "Godzilla" remake, but for me, this role kind of typifies for me his personality as an actor. I'm kind of surprised by the haters who reviewed this movie negatively because it appeared to be done in good fun and in the spirit of those old time Warner Brothers cartoons in which Wile E. Coyote is consistently outsmarted by the Road Runner. Jeffrey Jones portrays Wile E. of course, experiencing a series of escalating disasters as he tries to 'get the goods' on Ferris on his ninth day off from school. Personally, I would never have come up with the devious measures Ferris concocted to sidetrack his parents and Principal Rooney (Jones) while he tooled around the city with pal Cameron (Alan Ruck) and girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara). Highlight of the picture was Ferris commandeering the parade float with his version of 'Danke Schoen' and the Beatles' 'Twist and Shout', both very colorful and well choreographed. The picture might have taken Bueller's popularity to an extreme though, with schoolmates collecting money for a kidney operation, and the big city newspaper touting 'Community Rallies Around Sick Youth'. A little overkill there, but the whole picture was pretty much a parody so best to take it all in stride. Only thing is, as slick and smart as Ferris was, he was wrong about John Lennon. I'm pretty sure everyone knows the walrus was Paul.

From writer (Home Alone) and director John Hughes (The Breakfast Club; Planes, Trains & Automobiles), I remember seeing this once before, but I needed a second viewing to appreciate it even more. Basically street-wise teenager Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) convinces his parents, mother Katie (Cindy Pickett) and father Tom (Lyman Ward), that he has a serious illness forcing him to stay home and miss a school test. In reality he is faking to take the day off, and he has plenty of tricks, gizmos and back-ups to make sure he has little chance of getting caught. To make his nice spring day much more enjoyable he needs his best friend Cameron Frye (Speed's Alan Ruck) and girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) to join him. Knowing how often he has been absent from school, overly suspicious Dean Ed Rooney (Beetle Juice's Jeffrey Jones) knows Ferris well, and he wants to catch him in the act this time. Ferris, Cameron and Mia meanwhile have taken the convertible Ferrari 250 GT California, beloved by Cameron's father, to have a city adventure in Chicago. In the day they take the Ferrari to a garage with two untrustworthy attendants, eat at a fancy restaurant stealing someone else's reservation, watch a ball game, visit an art gallery, and take part in an annual parade. The parents have been fooled by Ferris's contraptions and stuff to thinking he is still at home in bed, but Rooney is going to all lengths to prove he isn't. So he goes to one or two places before going to the Bueller residence to find Ferris himself, and suffering all the humiliations of the house, e.g. mud, the dog. After a long day, Ferris, Cameron and Mia take the Ferrari back, but Cameron decides when it gets damaged, oh, and goes speeds backwards down the hill, to stand up to his father. Also seen in the story by the way is Ferris's sister Jeanie (Dirty Dancing's Jennifer Grey) who is resentful and jealous of Ferris, because he gets away with loads and she doesn't. In the end, Ferris races home to be there at the time his father said he would return, and when it looks like Rooney has busted, Jeanie backs him up and he gets away with it all. Also starring Edie McClurg as Grace, young Charlie Sheen as Boy in Police Station, The Mask's Ben Stein as Economics Teacher and Kristy Swanson as Simone Adamley. I love teen movies like American Pie, and this is considered by many as the ultimate skiving film, and with great performances by Broderick, Ruck and Jones, and early appearances by Grey and Sheen, it is good fun comedy. It was number 26 on The 50 Greatest Comedy Films. Very good!

reviews.review_title: one of John Hughes's few films I can watch over and over and not get tired of
reviews.content: Normally I'm not big on John Hughes's 80s movies, but there are some exceptions that do spring to mind (Breakfast Club is fun to watch when it pops up on TV, his script to Vacation is always very funny, and he had some underrated films with Planes Trains & Automobiles and especially with Uncle Buck). This, however, comes to mind as being a thoroughly enjoyable movie for kids, teens, adults, old people, etc, as it has that universal core- school stinks, enough to have one epic cut day, perhaps. Also at this core are some extremely good performances elevating the material. Matthew Broderick is in one of his most memorable parts as the title character, faking sick so he can a) get his friend Cameron (Alan Ruck, arguably his best role and performance to date), a closet-case, to allocate his father's golden calf in the form of a 61 Ferrari, b) get a friend, Sloane (Mia Sara) out of class, and c) take a tour of Chicago that forms as substantiative on its own and as a kind of fill-in-the-blank for other kids watching the film. What would you do on a day off? Some of the dumber parts of the movie, however still very funny and almost perfectly played depending on the scene, come from Jeffrey Jones as the smarmy, determined principal. And rounding out the cast is Jennifer Grey (pre-new nose) as the suspicious, jealous sister Bueller. All in all, even with sophomoric and diluted moments, it's an overall excellent chance at material that is just a lot of fun, even in its more dramatic moments. Darker issues are dealt with, such as with Cameron (and dealt on the somewhat shallow level of Hughes movies that only really broke with Breakfast Club). But in the end you watch the film for the all-too-memorable lines, kitschy moments, crazy turns at using the camera for comedy (as it pulls out of Cameron's mouth as he screams over the car), and music that is quintessentially catchy 80s. Funniest scene though is the call of Norm Peterson, on par with the funniest scenes in all modern comedy.

reviews.review_title: Refreshing Hughes teen flick one of his best
reviews.content: Teen flick king John Hughes is writer/director for this escapist movie about how high school kids should try not to let life pass them by in the prime of their youth.A great boppy soundtrack which includes Yello's "Oh Yeah" and "Twist and Shout" from the Beatles accompanies Matthew Broderick's refreshing turn as the excessively confident and immensely popular young Ferris. He is perfectly cast, as is Mia Sara, the attractive girlfriend, and Alan Ruck, Ferris' ever paranoid and worrying friend Cameron who supplies the trio with their 'choice' transport, a 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California. Also great value are Jeffrey Jones as the Dean of Students from hell who is determined to catch Ferris, and Jennifer Grey as the insanely jealous sister with an attitude. Charlie Sheen drops by with a cameo as a drug fiend with some friendly advice.While one of Hughes' best teen comedies, the movie still has his trademark misplaced scenes. Much of the attempts at drama are corny, the serious moments don't work and any moral messages fall flat. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" works best sending itself and other films up. Some very clever comedy is evident and Hughes produces some hilarious scenes including two terrific running gags involving firstly an over the top "Save Ferris" campaign and secondly a little tune called "Auf Wiedersehn". Broderick talks to the camera through much of the film which proves to be relatively effective.Friday, May 19, 1995 - Video

reviews.review_title: This is one of the very few movies that can make you forget all your worries and nudge you to engage in life from a place of happiness.
reviews.content:
What an amazing movie!!!The movie is about a happy, blessed high school teenager Ferris's day off from school. He deceives his parents and the school dean to take a break from School to enjoy life with his best friend & girl friend. So many things happen in the day and nothing seemed like an exaggeration.
Incidents throughout the day make Cameron shed his inhibitions and gives a positive outlook on life. I remembers smiling throughout the movie. Definitely worth your time!!!

reviews.review_title: Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it.
reviews.content: I was ready to give it nine stars but then I remembered mine days off from school. The parade scene its one of the kind! Made me dance and sing along! About the rest of the movie... it's clever and funny. One of my favourite parts is the police station scene with Jennifer Grey and Charlie Sheen. This movie never gets old!

reviews.review_title: Take a day off and watch this gem
reviews.content: John Hughes defiantly had his finger on the pulse of teen comedy when he made this gem. My favourite comedy of all time, it has everything you want to keep you entertained. It is about a boy bored with school who decides that he is determined to have one last day on the wag before he and his friends finish for good.  Despite being totally over the top in many parts you will be able to relate to near enough everything that happens during the first half an hour. Tying to fool your parents by faking illness, The stroppy sister telling them that there's nothing wrong with you while your extra busy parents are in a rush! Best of all, which will strike a chord with everyone is the boring teacher who sends everyone to sleep as he rattles on in a monotone voice!!! Matthew Broderick is excellent in the role he was born for, while I wish they had girls in my school who were are gorgeous as Mia Sara, convincing as his girlfriend. Alan Ruck is brilliant as Ferris' extra nervous hypochondriac best friend Cameron while Jeffrey Jones is a hoot as Buellers Nemesis (The Headmaster at school)  The gags speed along just as fast as the kids do in Cameron's dads Priceless Ferrari!!. Comedy like this makes good viewing for everyone and I recommend it highly.

Matthew Broderick plays a kid who goes to high school and decides to take a day off.He plays hookie with his friends Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) and Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) and enjoys the day in Chicago.There's only one person who can stop the fun and that's the principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones).And Ferris' sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey).OK, that's two persons.Ferris is a slacker but in his parents' eyes he's a perfect angel.So can Ferris get away with his plan or will he get caught? Ferris Bueller's Day Off is an amazing John Hughes movie from 1986.The movie's twenty years old and yet it seems so fresh.Teens all over the world still love the movie.Oh so young Matthew Broderick shines in the lead.This movie was made for him.Just like the role of Marty McFly was made for Michael J. Fox in Back to the Future one year earlier this one was made for Matthew.All the other actors do a great job too.The young Charlie Sheen can also be seen in the movie as Boy in police station.The movie is filled with terrific scenes.One of the greatest moments is when Ferris gets up and sings Twist and Shout by The Beatles.This movie sends a great message for the kids at school.Everybody should follow Ferris' example and skip school once in a while.Let's all just get out of that class room and have a piece of the world out there.All you need is a good plan.You have to pretend you're sick.You're gonna have to be a good actor so you can fool everybody.It helps if your best friends' father has a Ferrari.It makes it all cooler.I'm kidding of course.You kids should stay at school.I'm graduating tomorrow and I haven't skipped any day of school.And no, I am not a geek.Now a few words about the movie before I finish.This is the king of all high school movies.It's entertaining, it's funny, it's serious in times.It has everything you can ever ask for a teen movie.Another thing to mention about the movie is Ferris' straight to camera monologues he gives.That thing works in this movie.That's some wise stuff he says there.It's a very well written movie.Much more intelligent than teen movies generally.Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a movie for all the high school students and those who feel like one.

reviews.review_title: A delight from start to finish
reviews.content: Trying to explain the true glory of Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a tough thing to do. It's not a big thought provoking masterpiece made on a shoestring nor is it an ensemble piece featuring the best of the worlds acting talent. It's just an 80's teen movie featuring a cast of 'B'-list talent and a good idea. What would you do if you had one day in which anything was possible. In which ignoring the rules and regulations that bind the rest of us poor mortals was all part of the fun. It's one of those movies you see when you're a kid and you wish so much that you could do the same thing, take a Ferrari, your girlfriend, best mate and a wad of cash and enjoy all the guilty pursuits you can in one day. It's the perfect fantasy movie and demands constant screenings in order to fully appreciate its brilliance, its glorious simplicity. And the characters are a joy to behold, the carefree Ferris, uptight Principal, tightly wound sister and friend and completely ignorant parents. After seeing it you'll wish your school days were so much fun and the ending is surprisingly touching. You just know that's not the last stunt Ferris will pull and you can't wait for the surely forthcoming sequel. Please John???

A classic John Hughes movie, it uses the city of Chicago like a perfect background,& unlike all the '80's teen movies, you can watch it with your friends, or watch it with your grandma. He doesn't rely on typical cheese to make a movie great.

An American comedy; A story about a teenager who skips school for a taste of carpe diem around Chicago and so he can help his best friend win some self-respect. The school dean is hot on their trail but Ferris Bueller is always one step ahead. All of the adults are dim-witted and one-dimensional and the solutions to teenage problems are quite simplistic but there is warmth, whimsicality, sweetness, good humour and the film's heart is in the right place.

reviews.review_title: Take a day off and watch 'FERRIS BUELLER'S DAY OFF'
reviews.content: John Hughes is one director who make you feel life as a fairy tale filled with rainbows. Before he took the baby out (Baby's day out) he did ask Ferris to take his day off. The movie contains certain scenes that may require Parental Guidance (PG) but far better than high school movies of today. Other than that it is a family entertainer and is one of the best. Ferris character is superb and everybody loves him and wants to be him. Mia Sara looks very pretty to me. The principal's character is the funniest of all. My favorite was "Twist and Shout" scene, where all people dance to Ferris lip-synch. The bottom line is that it is one of the best 80s comedy flick and not to be missed. So, take a day off and watch 'Ferris Bueller's day off'.

I really wanted to like it, after hearing friends talk about it like it were some paradigm of coming of age masterwork. But I really couldn't. The main character takes a day off, behaves badly and gets away with it. Which would make for a funny, cheeky film, weren't for the fact that such main character is an unlovable, self-absorbed young idiot. The film itself has more plot holes than a narrative colander and the other characters are little more than cardboard cutouts. Charlie Sheen fleetingly raises the tone slightly with a tiny, well acted part of a juvenile delinquent -- but this is pretty much the only positive thing I can say about this absolute dud of a movie.

reviews.review_title: My Personal Favorite Film from John Hughes!
reviews.content: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it." Ah, wise words from our new young friend, Ferris Bueller. In John Hughes's 1986 film, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, all Ferris wants to do is take a day and have fun. That is the most simplistic theme the movie has. You can go deeper, but the main takeaway is that it is okay to have fun. That is a motto I have taken to heart. I really loved the film. People consider The Breakfast Club to be Hughes's best and most important movie. That's a fine statement to make, but I would personally rank the film number two behind this particular one. The teen characters are instantly relatable, it has a memorable antagonist for the children, and this is basically a thirty-year-old travel guide for Chicago. Just how Woody Allen creates his movies as love letters for New York, this is applicable for John Hughes. A Chicago love letter!Like all of his films, Hughes wrote his own script. Due to possible picketing from the writer's guild, Hughes wrote a basic first draft that had a beginning and an ending. The middle would be made up as production ensued. The first cut of the film was nearly three hours long, so the rest of the screenplay would be completed in the editing room if that made sense. Hughes, always the adolescent philosopher, wrote a very familiar screenplay. Teens that are relatable and one-dimensional adults who do not believe in the word "fun." Somehow, these adult antagonists seem to make the history books as the roles to remember. Just as I remember Paul Gleason's principal role in The Breakfast Club, I certainly remember Jeffrey Jones's dim-witted Ed Rooney here. Hughes takes time to develop his characters which should come as no surprise.I guess if you were going to commit truancy, you would want to follow in the footsteps of our main hero, Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick). All he wanted to do was take a day off from school. He enlists his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) to steal his father's red Ferrari. The duo, along with Ferris's girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara), head into Chicago for a day to check out the sites; the architectural landmarks, the art museum, the fancy restaurant, Wrigley Field, and an American-German parade where "Danke Schoen" and "Twist and Shout" might be key songs to remember. Meanwhile, Principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is hellbent in capturing Ferris. He might have an ally in Ferris's moody but really pretty sister Jeanie Bueller (Jennifer Grey).Hughes always wanted Matthew Broderick as Ferris. Broderick possesses a charm that is not seen in many modern actors. After watching the film, you could obviously see why Broderick and only him was cast in the lead role. Broderick had a close friendship with Alan Ruck which led to great chemistry between the actors. Despite being 29, Ruck did make a believable high school student. He was excellent and captured the true feelings of a high school student not wanting to go to school. Mia Sara is beautiful, but she wasn't given much to do. Molly Ringwald wanted to play this role, but Hughes cautioned her for good reason apparently. Yes, Ed Rooney is a one-dimensional, child-hating character but my gosh is Jeffrey Jones ever memorable. I love the scene where the dogs sic him and is forced to ride a bus. Hehe. Jennifer Grey is fantastic! Finally, a shoutout goes to Ben Stein and his monotonous lecture on economics.Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a wholesome, incredibly fun film. There is nothing mean-spirited to see. It is all about teens wanting to have a good time. If I were to be truant, this is how I would want my day to go. The other theme is Ferris wanting to lift the spirits of his best friend from his materialistic father. A more subtle theme, but I appreciate it. This is one of those movies that is wholesome, but also incredibly funny. I laughed too many times to count and that is a rarity. Great performances and great fun add up to John Hughes's best film. Yes, I rank it higher than The Breakfast Club.My Grade: A

reviews.review_title: A dream for kids; a nightmare for adults.
reviews.content: No matter how you try to put it, this will always be a teen movie, or at least a movie for people under the age of 25 who were recently in high school. It's premise is based on the human urge to go against the system and buck the rules and just have a good time. Practically every kid that feels stuck in the walls of an institution such as high school is going to get these urges, and for all of those kids, Ferris Bueller is their hero. Matthew Broderick brings a warm, innocent charm to the title role as a young man who has luck on his side. Everything goes his way, from worming his best friend (Alan Ruck) into taking his father's rare Ferrari, to warding off the high school principal (Jeffrey Jones) to getting his girlfriend (Mia Sara) out of school as well.Writer/director John Hughes takes his love for teenagers and school situations and gives us a story that deals with life outside school and the freedoms and privileges of being a kid. What Ferris does is, as they say, getting away with murder, but it is such a joy to watch him get into predicaments and wonder how can he possibly get out of this one. Broderick is a delight, as are the supporting cast, especially Jennifer Grey as his envious sister. This movie is about luck and what that power can do for you. It is also about enjoying life and the power that can do. It is the ultimate skipping school movie and is one of Hughes' best efforts as a writer and director. See it for the story, the funnies or the plain joy of skipping school and catching a glimpse of life.

I had been told for years how funny this movie was before I finally saw it. Maybe I would have liked it better if I had seen it as a teenager (or at age 21, when it was actually released), but quite frankly, I doubt it. I'm not sure why we're supposed to identify with the obnoxious, selfish Ferris and his rich preppie friends, but I spent most of the movie waiting for Ferris to get his comeuppance, which, needless to say, is not forthcoming. This movie apparently confuses "having fun" and "cutting loose" with "being selfish, pushy and inconsiderate" and never made me care about any of its characters. I give it 5/10 for the occasional chuckle.

"Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is a 10/10 in my book and one of my favorite comedies, especially of the teen genre. The only other teen comedy I gave a 9 or 10 to is "10 Things I hate about you". In my opinion "Ferris Bueller" is not only John Hughes best film, but one of the best comedies in general. The three lead actors are terrific, the supporting cast is also great, and the film moves along nicely, leaving the audience feeling as if they joined Ferris on the day's adventure.The other plus for "Ferris Bueller" is that it is funny without needing to be too crude or crass, which most comedies of this genre are. And the film does not feel dated even today; it doesn't have that excessive 1980's feel that say "Pretty in Pink" has which was released the same year. Also, the cinematography is top notch, with Chicago and its suburbs providing an excellent setting, almost becoming a character in this film.And who can forget the terrific art museum scene which is one of my favorite scenes in all of cinema. It was filmed beautifully with a great instrumental musical track overlaid. While Ferris and Sloane kiss under the beautiful blue stained-glass, Cameron is searching for himself in the complex pointillist painting of Seurat. This scene exposes the audience to art that they might not have otherwise seen; this is unique in film, for what other big film spends minutes showing an art museum? And this scene is far from boring, rather it is one of the highlights of the film, making the whole film anything but fatuous.I also liked how both Sloane and Ferris are keen on getting married soon, nowadays I don't think this attitude would appear in film. People today seem reluctant to get married, especially at a young age. But I think it is nice to see Sloane and Ferris be honest and vulnerable with their needs and wishes. If you are fortunate enough to find someone to love, who loves you back, then why not tie the knot sooner rather than later?"Ferris Bueller" is the film which perhaps best embodies those feelings of being 16-18 years old, unsure of your future, but full of hope and optimism, with a twinge of fear. It shows an age in betwixt childhood and adulthood, where one is old enough to go have a fun adventure independently, but not too old to enjoy it. Youths are not yet jaded by the world, filled with ennui and boredom, just a trip to a city can be an exciting adventure at that age. Whereas older folk often just want to rest, weary from work and life's responsibilities.So, watch this film to relive those youthful days if only for a few hours, days which were full of wonder and magnificent possibilities. Sure Ferris is self-centered, spoiled, and maybe narcissistic, but he is that friend that so many of us need, the guy who can pull us out of our comfort zone and motivate us into doing something fun and memorable while you have the chance, because as he said: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."

John Hughes will be remembered for many teen comedies, but "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" qualifies as the funniest. Matthew Broderick is at his charismatic best in this outlandish saga about a high school rebel. As the eponymous character, Ferris hates to attend classes. In fact, when the film unfolds, Ferris has reached the maximum number of sick days; he has been sick nine days. High School Administrator Edward Rooney watches as the number of days shrinks from nine to two days on his computer. Ferris is an adequate hacker, but then computers were quite as sophisticated back in 1986. The title tells all in this amusing epic about freeloaders. Ferris, his best friend Cameron, and their girlfriend Sloane Peterson cruise into Chicago in Cameron's father's red sports car, a 1960 Ferrari GT California. The logistics of this comedy is how does Ferris pull the wool over everybody's eyes—his parents and the high school—while his friends and he goof off for a day. The suspense builds when Mr. Rooney—like Wiley E. Coyote—tries to catch Ferris in his lies and masquerades. Sure, there are other people who try to pull a fast one on Ferris, but he is just too nimble. This lightweight, frivolous comedy was made in another era when cell phones and other modern day amenities didn't exist. Aside from Ferris, we also watch his sister Jeanie wind up in police station where she meets a druggie (Charlie Sheen) who gets into a conversation with her. The conflict that emerges involves two garage hucksters who steal Cameron's father's car for the day while Ferris and company are cavorting around Chicago, masquerading as wealthy types to get a seat in an upscale restaurant.

reviews.review_title: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it"
reviews.content: It'd been years since I last watched 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986),' and, as a young adult, I was struck by just how tame Ferris Bueller's day off actually was. In my memory, I'd concocted all sorts of exciting and dangerous escapades. But Ferris (Matthew Broderick), it seems, is quite intent on emulating adulthood, and his choice of destinations is characteristically "grown up": the stock market exchange, an upper-class restaurant, a museum. He asks Sloane (Mia Sara) to marry him, lightly but nevertheless earnestly. Even his choice of parade music ("Danke Schoen" by Wayne Newton, "Twist and Shout" by The Beatles) harks to an older generation. "Life moves pretty fast," Ferris tells us, and yet he seems intent on accelerating the process.Spontaneity comes with youth. At first glance, we might consider Ferris Bueller to be spontaneous. But is he? Abe Froman, touted as "The Sausage King of Chicago," never arrives for his three-person reservation at the restaurant. Could Ferris not himself have made the reservation, and simply feigned spontaneity for the benefit of his friends? We've seen for ourselves the cunning genius with which Ferris creates illusions – that he is too ill to attend school, that he is sound asleep in bed – and this is just another deception, only now he's even fooling the viewer. This is perhaps referenced at the film's end, when Sloane suggests "You knew what you were doing when you woke up this morning, didn't you?", to which Ferris coyly replies, "Me? Na." (Thanks to Scott Murray of "Senses of Cinema" for first planting this idea in my head).I haven't mentioned Cameron (Alan Ruck) yet, but he's the most important character. Whereas Ferris remains his usual glossy self throughout (whoever that may be), the uptight and neglected Cameron learns to stand up for yourself, particularly towards his cold (and appropriately absent) father. There's one particularly striking sequence in the Chicago Museum of Art, in which Cameron studies Georges Seurat's "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte," fixating so closely on the image of a mother and child that the child's face becomes indistinguishable amid the texture of the canvas. Is this a deconstructionist hint, referencing the artistic medium in the same way that Ferris' fourth-wall breaking does so? Or does it have the opposite intent? The more we look into it, the less truth we see. So just have a fun day, damn it.

reviews.review_title: A Few Laughs, But Predictable and Over-Rated
reviews.content: I remember this movie when I was in my first year in college, People billed it as a classic and it certainly made Matthew Broderick a star. The problem that I have with this movie is that I have a resentment for smart-alec know it all kids who make adults look like one-dimensional airheads, making the kid out to be some sort of hero for skipping school, slacking off, and pushing people into uncomfortable situations. The audience thinks that the "Know it all" is the greatest, coolest, most wonderful person in the whole world. But in reality, Ferris Bueller is a character with an attitude. Give Matthew credit for playing him brilliantly, but if you are like me and a "character type" person rubs you the wrong way, you won't think this movie is as great as so many make it out to be.We all know the story: Ferris Bueller is a typical high-school slacker who wants to take the day off, so he cons his RIDICULOUSLY gullible parents into believing that he is sick, calls his best friend Cameron over, talks poor Cameron out of stealing his father's Ferrari out of the garage, picks up his girlfriend Sloane by disguising himself as her father in a phone conversation, conning the Dean of Students Mr. Ed Rooney into believing that her grandmother has passed away so that he can get her out of class disguised as her "Dad" driving Cameron's Dad's classic car.He acts like a jerk in a classy restaurant to a Matre'D, pulls a few strings to get an expensive lunch, goes to an art museum, and a baseball game, while always able to elude Mr. Rooney and his parents.It's the typical teen comedy movie where you root for the teen because he's able to get away with crap, while the parents and school administrators can't catch him. It's too bad that the adults are made to look so superficial in this movie, because some do a good job such as the zany school secretary, some funny lines by the Dean of Students Mr. Rooney, and Ben Stein as an economics teacher, (Who's lecture, other than the roll call, was improvised because he had a Master's Degree in economics and John Hughes the director liked the idea.) Maybe it's because I have grown out of the teen years, might be another reason why I can't give this movie a higher review. I think people in their teen-early adult years might like it better.

reviews.review_title: What a day off can do for you!
reviews.content: When it comes to making films about teenagers, John Hughes is really the only writer and director who can get it right. Some of his incarnations can be very thought provoking like The Breakfast Club. In other cases, they can be downright funny. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is such an example, and manages to be quite inspirational too.Set in Chicago (like all of John Hughes' films), the audience is introduced to Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick). Ferris is a teenager who realises life can be complicated. That is why you're never too old (or too young!) to have a day off.He fakes an illness to his parents with "a non-specific symptom", much to the chagrin of his sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) who just knows he is faking it. But still, his parents fall for it, hook, line and sinker. They believe their son is an angel who would never lie to them.Once they're gone, then the audience is properly introduced to Ferris Bueller. A hip, trendy, free-wheeling, philosophical spirit who has now been absent from school for a total of nine times in the past semester.One of the nice touches about this film is the way Ferris addresses the audience. He does seem to like to give sermons about how to enjoy life, and some of his observations about life are quite interesting. This derives from his personal philosophy that I must quote:"Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it."It is exactly for this reason he wants to take a day off from the monotony of high school. When we actually see some of his lessons, you understand in an instant why.But a day off is no fun on you're own. It is an experience best shared. Ferris wants his best friend Cameron Frye (The superb Alan Ruck) to join him.Cameron is the exact opposite of Ferris. Ferris doesn't worry about anything, and manages to make the impossible possible. Cameron, on the other hand, is a neurotic, paranoid young man who is not in school that day because he genuinely believes he is sick. He is terrified of life, and how it seems to control him.Ferris hopes this day off will help Cameron to reflect and learn to appreciate life instead of running from it. When Ferris (eventually) convinces Cameron to come over to his house, they still have to add one more person into the mix.Ferris' girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) has been invited along too. In a scheme concocted by Ferris, Cameron calls the school pretending to be Sloane's father. This is one of the most hilarious scenes in the film, because his impersonation is so funny it had me in hysterics. It made me wonder if Sloane's father was really like that.Claiming that Sloane's grandmother has passed away, they manage to get one over on the principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones). He is certain that Ferris is faking his illness, and would like nothing more than to catch him in the act. His purpose in the film is to expose Ferris and failing in every attempt.Once they've got their hands on Cameron's father's Ferrari, a car his dad loves more than life itself (and sadly more than Cameron), Ferris, Cameron and Sloane are ready to go.Once they're in the city, our trio enjoy the sights and sounds. From checking out the Sears building to a baseball game, dining at a fancy restaurant, enjoying modern art, the audience begins to realise this is all for the benefit of Cameron. He's not really enjoying himself, mostly because he's terrified something will happen to the car.Gradually, he does begin to loosen up. Events such as Ferris singing on a parade float help Cameron to do that. That scene is so funny, because the whole crowd join in on Ferris' enthusiasm. It's quite nice as well to see so many people enjoying themselves at once.Cameron eventually manages to bring his perceptions of life into focus. He knows he can't just stand by and let life control him. For too long, he's allowed that to happen. Because his parents have never given him the love and affection he has wanted, and given it to the Ferrari instead, his first act of rebellion is to destroy the car.He is willing to take the blame, because he now wants to be the agent of his own destiny. This is something Ferris has been trying to teach him. Cameron is the real star of the film, and his courage about standing up to his father for wrecking the car is both inspirational and touching.Matthew Broderick is perfect as Ferris Bueller, bringing the boyish charm he is famous for. With people like Jeanie and Rooney against him, and coming out on top, it is hard to dislike him. Although Jeanie learns something from this day too, and becomes a better person for it, like Cameron.This film has a great deal to teach, about how life's moments must be seized, and reflecting on it to make the way for a better future, not only for yourself, but for other people out there like Cameron. It also has a wonderfully surreal touch, that adds a whimsical feeling to the whole enterprise.This is definitely my favourite of John Hughes' teenage films.

"Ferris Bueller's day off" is another of the many 1980s teen comedies (many of them John Hughs) set in the Chicago suburbs.
Ferris's famous talking into the camera was one of several things which made this movie iconic, his "life moves by fast" philosophy and a Ferrari taking an important role in the film. Alan Ruck's nervous Cameron, the son of the cold uptight Farrari's owner, and his need to loosen up and join the hero on his infamous day off, was the movie's next iconic element. Jeffrey Jones's most famous movie role, Edward Rooney and his "throw all my other priorities to the side until I deal with my no. 1 priority Ferris Bueller" principal role was the next iconic landmark. Ferris's fooled parents, his not so fooled and resentful (Dirty dancing to-be-star at the time) sister, and the humorous gimmicks (like the snoring sound effects radio and dummy in the bed tied to a string to the door to make it look like Ferris is turning in bed sleeping whenever someone peeks into the room).Then, the phone calls including Ferris talking to one of his many friends in school (the coughing synthesizer) about his made-up illness, their funny comments ("Ferris is gonna get me out of summer school, I hope he doesn't die, I'd hate to go to summer school"), his calling Cameron to get him out of his bed of self pity (and his bed) and over to him, and Ferris somehow fixing the computer in Rooney's office from his own computer (Ferris: "I asked for a car and I got a computer, how's that for being born under a bad sign?") which lessened the stated amount of days he's missed while Rooney's on the phone telling Mrs. Bueller (Rooney: "nine times"). Then the call from Cameron disguised as Sloan's dad telling Rooney about her alleged grandmother's passing to get Sloan (Ferris's GF) out of school to join them. Then Sloan outside the school doors with Rooney (calling him a beautiful man, lol) waiting for "her dad" (Ferris) while we can hear teacher Ben Stein's "anyone? anyone?" from a nearby window, a funny follow-up from the famous funny classroom scene with Stiein's "anyone? anyone?", "Bueller. Bueller. Bueller.", and the student's response "I heard from my boyfriend's sister's neighbor's girlfriend's best friend's cousin's sister's friend (or something) that they saw Ferris pass out at 31 Flavors last night". That comment, the earlier phonecall scene, people in numerous different places throughout the movie asking about Ferris (including the police station), a "Save Ferris" sign on a watertower, and Rooney's secretary's famous comment about his popularity ("dweebs, geeks, sportos, motorheads, etc., they adore him, they think he's a righteous dude"), they were all several examples of Ferris's popularity and how almost everybody was fooled by his "illness" except his skeptical sister and Rooney, who's treck off school grounds to confront him was another iconic gimmick of the movie (along with Rooney's numerous funny hijinks while seeking him such as getting muddy, and him and the dog that doesn't like him).The above isn't even the half of it yet, there's still all of the famous and hilarious hijinks of Ferris, Cameron, and Sloan in Chicago, the different landmarks they visit; the Sears tower, stock exchange, art gallery (and Cameron's strange fascination with the little girl in the "Sunday afternoon" painting), a couple of innings at the Cubs game (with Rooney watching the same game from a pizza parlor (and him asking the owner the score, the owner responding: "nothing, nothing", Rooney: "who's winning?", Owner: "the Bears" lol), and then him mistaking a girl for Ferris and getting her drink spit on him, lol), and then Ferris/Cameron/Sloan eating at a fancy restaurant with a near miss with seeing Mr Bueller (Ferris: "1000 restaurants in this city and I pick the one my dad goes to") and the comical confrontation with the weird restaurant owner when trying to get in (Ferris posing as the Sausage king of Chicago) and the owner not buying it until Cameron uses his same funny disguised voice from earlier with Rooney, this time as police officer on the phone, to convince the owner to believe Ferris is the Sausage king of Chicago.There are still numerous funny classic things from this iconic movie I haven't mentioned, because there just isn't enough room here. There's still Cameron's freakout over the sleazy professional (Cameron: "professional what?") taking his dad's Ferrari on a joyride throughout the city adding 150 extra miles to the car. But Ferris's biggest motive, besides having his fun filled day, was getting Cameron to learn to not get his self-esteem lowered by and to stop being scared of his super-strict "I love my car much more than my son" dad. Because of how this movie went, and because Camerons dad was an unseen but talked about character in this movie, it's probably best that it was left to our imagination on what Cameron's dad's reaction was gonna be to his car not only having 150 extra miles on it, but it now being smashed on the ground after running through the window of Cameron's museum style display room of his house (sort of a connection to a comment earlier by Ferris: "Cameron's house is like a museum, it's very big, very cold, and you're not allowed to touch anything").

reviews.review_title: giving it the test of time
reviews.content: "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is over 25 years old now and so I thought it was about time I gave it a review. Recently I also went back and reviewed Risky Business, NL's Vacation and a few other 80's movies and so I'm kind of going to try and compare it to its contemporaries. Anyway, I'll kick this off by asking a few question: No 1 - Where do you think Ferris wound up in life after he graduated from High School? Another question might go like this: "If you liked Ferris, how would you compare your life now to that of someone who didn't like Ferris?". THere is a polarization of attitudes here at IMDb over him, and so these would seem to be relevant questions.And so to begin with, as has often been pointed out over the years, the biggest issue with Ferris for many was that he was made of Teflon - i.e. nothing stuck to him. I think that this was due in part to the fact that he got so much love and attention from his parents that he never considered the possibility that others might not also love him. This in turn made him feel impervious to wrongdoing and caused him to do morally questionable things :) Another issue is that he came from that part of society where parents are powerful enough to bully school administrators whenever they feel like it. Witness Ed Rooney's shivering in his boots when he thinks he's talking to Sloan Peterson's Dad. So, Ferris moral compass is a bit skewed, and if you have any teaching experience, you have probably seen this all before.Now, contrast him to buddy Cam and maybe Joel Goodson of "Risky Business". Cam and Joel, in contrast to Ferris, had moral consciences. Where Ferris would just sort of go out and do something whenever he felt like it, Cam and Joel were more restrained and prone to weighing pros and cons. All of these differences to me were related to each character's relationship with his parents. Only Ferris seemed to take his parents (and their love) completely for granted. And where Cam would say "I don't know what I'm going to do with my life", it shows you that at least he's thinking about it. Joel Goodson was also on a career path at the time his story takes place. But Ferris? Does Ferris ever talk about what he wants to do with his life? No, not that I can recall. So, I ask myself all of this because I am no longer 18 and am not that successful in life. I also got a kick out of skipping class when I was in high school, and didn't like to talk about what I wanted to do afterwords because I didn't know. And......I always pretty much loved this movie which has perhaps caused me to be blind to its message. And just what was the message?Well, a good movie will take you on a journey, a journey in which the principal characters change. Well, but the problem as I look back on it now is that Ferris DIDN'T change that day. Cam did, and Joel did in Risky Business, but Ferris learned only that, once again, deceitful and impulsive behavior results in no consequences. This was perhaps the movie's message, that Ferris was some sort of God or something and well, "just don't try this at home kids!" Sounds like I really didn't like him, heh? Well, but i DID! I'm not one of those Ferris haters. But I gotta admit, of the three characters I'm referring to, he's the one who's going to have the most issues to deal with later in life, IHMO!And so the irony to me is that Ferris was the catalyst that caused Cam to grow up and face his fears, but it was really Ferris that needed a catalyst, not Cam. Catalysts cause other things to react and change, but don't change themselves. This was the "Teflon" aspect of Ferris's existence. He didn't project any sense that he needed to work on himself, to grow. Perhaps unconditional parental love is not always a good thing then, and Ferris never appreciated how good he had it. Guys like that can get you in a lot of trouble because they have few moral boundaries owing to that love. I don't know, but remember that "the motorheads, dweebs, wasteoids, dickheads, etc" all loved Ferris. That left Ed and sister Jeanie to lead any attempts to burst his bubble, to catalyze any change in him. They don't succeed here, but maybe they planted some seeds in his brain? So "wake up and smell the coffee", Ferris. Cam's dad's is going to find out that you really wrecked the car, not Cam. And then your reputation is going to be the next hot topic around town.....OK, OK......there, I've said it. I've made my peace with myself and with Ferris. Yeah, we love you, and I'd still pluck my money down to watch you outsmart Ed Rooney and the whole town of Chicago. But if immortal youth is the only God in this universe, you've got some years of reckoning ahead of you. That is unless of course, you drift into theatre, acting, comedy, or are independently wealthy. Because I guess I still don't know what you were really planning on doing with YOUR life? What skill sets were you going to bring to the rest of world? Well, you might have made a pretty good houdini....

reviews.review_title: A day in the life of Ferris
reviews.content: There are some movies that hit the right spot with the right people and they become cult classics. We all know about star wars and the Rocky Horror Picture show. Did you realise that FBDO is also one of those cult movies. There are those who watch it over and over again....be warned before you get this movie, you could become an addict.The idea behind this movie is great. It is about all the lessons you learn during your school years which you don't actually learn while you are at school.Ferris is the sort of guy that school is good to. He is good looking, but not a jock, he is good at study but not a nerd, everyone likes him, but he is not a hero, he is good looking but wears bad 80s clothes and has a bad 80s hair cut.Skipping school, borrowing his friends dad's Ferrari, singing "twist & shout" at a parade and crashing an exclusive french restaurant don't quite add up to a riveting story.What we have a school student who is not a loser who makes good, but someone who is perhaps too perfect. He is the person whose head you would must like to shove down the toilet and flush on a bad day at school. But he is also the person you like and in many ways admire. He is the over dressed wussy boy you actually want to be (or perhaps date...or both).Like "pretty in pink" it was one of those movies in the 1980s you quietly mentioned to friends you liked only to find they also liked it. Because there is nothing else like it around it is worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: classic 80s film - a joy to watch

reviews.review_title: Lots of fun, though ridiculous at times
reviews.content:
This used to be one of my favorite movies, and I still love watching it, but I can't help but realize more and more flaws in each viewing (which can add to the fun).  I understand it's a farce, from a teenager's point of view--and that's why all the adults are such incompetent jerks--but you gotta draw the line somewhere.But all in all, "Ferris Bueller" is not an easy film to resist.  It's a wild, energetic ride that will probably even make discerning grown-ups crack a smile.  There are some landmark moments, including Ferris singing "Twist and Shout" at a German parade and him driving away with his buddy Cameron's Ferrari with the song "Oh Yeah" pumping in the background.  Matthew Broderick gives a spirited performance (probably the one that put him on the map) and you couldn't imagine anyone else portraying Ferris as well as him. The same goes for Alan Ruck as Cameron and Jeffrey Jones as Principal Rooney.  Mia Sara is a beautiful choice as Sloane, Ferris's girlfriend. Keep a lookout for Charlie Sheen in a cameo as a drug addict who ends up falling for Ferris's sister, Jeannie.  I guess one of the reasons why I love this movie is because I relate to it, in my own way--and I'm sure many others do too.  Everyone aspires to be like Ferris--slick, free-spirited and without a care in the world.  My best friend is somewhat like Ferris, in a free-spirited sense.  And I would compare myself to Cameron.  I admit, I am quite cranky and paranoid at times.  Cameron doesn't like to throw himself into troublesome situations, like me, mostly because he's under the strict rule of his parents.  Now, my parents aren't that strict and they are decent people, which is why I don't try to violate their trust.  But there is something inside of me that wants me to break out of this constrictive shell that I seclude myself in, and I am somewhat envious of my best friend for being able to function without that shell, like Cameron is obviosly envious of Ferris without that shell.  I believe that everyone either is Ferris or knows a Ferris, and everyone is either Cameron or knows a Cameron.  The characters are both exaggerated, but the basis of them are true.
There are ridiculous scenes that couldn't help but make me roll my eyes and scream "Yeah, right!"  How many times did Ferris almost come face-to-face with his Dad and escaped at the last minute?  After Jeannie kicked Principal Rooney in the face, how come she reported that a stranger invaded her house? She knows Rooney from school!  When Ferris's Mom went to check on Ferris, how come she didn't actually step inside the bedroom and check on him, even after she remembered back to Rooney mentioning he was absent 9 times?  I'm sure any mother, whether her son was sleeping or not, would've went inside to check on him.  This is a great fantasy world, but us young people ain't stupid and our parents ain't either.  I don't even have overprotective parents, but my parents (well, my mom at least) are like human lie detectors.  They have extra-sensitive senses and are basically like psychics.  It's like the characters, not the actors, read the script and memorized their cues to become ignorant morons.So if you wanna have fun with this movie, please suspend and suspend and continue to suspend all disbelief.  The plot holes are so evident that a 10-year-old can point them out, but trust me--it's still a wild and crazy ride with some good laughs to spare!My score:  7 (out of 10)

This is one of those cases where its influences and references are recognisable throughout pop culture and even movies who try to emulate its more iconic moments, and in a sense you think you already know the original undertaking. In fact, that is not at all true, as it is indeed a sort of timeless feature, but for more than just the sum of the parts, both fun and thoughtful as I wasn't entirely expecting.What surprised me the most is that, despite the title, the story isn't so much focused on the titular character's shenanigans, as much as it is on Cameron's growth beyond his father's oppression through his friendship with Ferris. We never get to see the parent, being the modern garage filled with pictures of his beloved cars (contrary to what we imagine to be as stripped a house on the inside as it is on the outside) sufficient proof of Cameron's empty relationship with him.In the end, we don't even need to see the resolution, witnessing instead the certainty of Cameron's attitude as he doesn't even flinch at the idea of the confrontation with his father, in contrast to the insecurity we hear and see at the beginning.

reviews.review_title: A classic film, every boy's envy, every parent's fear, every dean's frustration.
reviews.content: Re-watching this movie again in 2022 it occurs to me, when I first saw it I had never been to Chicago. Over the years not only did I visit a number of times on business or pleasure, I also had two daughters living there and two of my grandchildren grew up there. It is even more fun now because I am very familiar with the city, including Wrigley Field.I vividly recall seeing "Ferris Bueller" in the theater in 1986, and it delighted me, especially the ending where the final scene is playing alongside the credits, then when the credits were over, Ferris comes out, looks us in the eye and says, "It's over...go home." I have always been one to watch the credits anyway so I didn't miss any of it, as many theater-goers did. All the way through this is a very clever and entertaining film.Now, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" has recently been issued as a DVD with Dolby 5.1 sound and widescreen, and with a selectable director's commentary. I bought my own copy and it really is a good one.June 2019 edit: Being reminded it is the 33rd anniversary of this movie I watched it again last night, almost as much fun as the first time! A classic.This is somewhat a vanity project for writer/director John Hughes who grew up not too far from Chicago, the setting of this film. Hughes has had quite a good history with screenplays, including such films as Sixteen Candles, Breakfast Club, Uncle Buck, Home Alone 1,2, and 3, Flubber, just to name a few. His commentary on this DVD is among the better ones, not going very often into the self-indulgent mode, and giving very interesting "behind the shots" commentary. An example of an interesting tidbit, although the film was set in Springtime, the outdoor shots at the ravine in Chicago were in the Fall, so they had to paint colored leaves green before each day's shooting, taking care not to knock them off!Some SPOILERS - The story is one day in the life of smart, master-slacker and high school senior, Ferris Bueller. Pretending to be sick, he gets his girlfriend Sloane out of class, his really sick friend Cameron out of bed, they borrow the rare collector car and have a day on the town. Restaurant, baseball game, stock market floor, parade, tallest building, art museum, lakefront. Meanwhile way-too-serious Dean of Students Rooney is trying to nab Ferris and expose him. The footrace with the cars near the end is a highlight. Ultimately, brother and sister bond are stronger than jealousy and Rooney gets his due.The filming at school was done with real high school extras, but only Mia Sara, who played Sloane, was a teen-ager among the cast. Broderick (Ferris) was 23, Alan Ruck (Cameron) was 29, pre-nose-bob Jennifer Grey (Jeannie) was 25. The film addresses Cameron's timidity and this day converts him, he decides to take a stand in his homelife. Also, Jeannie learns to appreciate and accept her wily brother. However, there isn't much message here, just clever fun and every student's secret desire, to make a fool out of school administration. My word description may sound sinister but in reality the comedic tone of the film doesn't allow us to take it very seriously.Of course this was a landmark role for Broderick, who looked like a teenager, and it made it hard for him to get "adult" roles later. Jeffery Jones plays Rooney just perfectly, a parody of a Dean of Students who has little connection with the real world. All in all an almost perfect cast, a witty script, and very effective directing make this one of my favorite films of all time.
Three kids run amok on a dream ditch day. Main cast has good chemistry and it's a fun concept for the storyline.

I honestly couldn't tell you how many times I've seen "Ferris Bueller's Day Off", but it's got to be close to double digits at this point. I'm not one of those people who thinks Ferris Bueller is a perfect movie, nor do I think it's one of the funniest movies ever made- it's not- but it is a film that I like to come back to every once in a while because I enjoy spending time with the characters and the situations they find themselves in, which, while sometimes a bit overblown, are still enjoyable to revisit. Ferris Bueller is about pitch perfect when it comes to finding an easy-going, feel good film, and, more than thirty years later, it's still incredibly iconic.
