reviews.review_title: An excellent family comedy which has been unfairly forgotten.
reviews.content: This movie is a light and fun comedy that takes us back to school days. After all, who hasn't wanted to take a day off and simply enjoy their youth? I think all teens have felt this urge, and often have, or played sick for one more day to themselves. What, surely, will never have happened is something as complex and sophisticated as what Ferris Bueller decided to do.The film is fun and uses a tasteful comedy style, without good resources, able to delight the whole family. John Hughes assures a firm and intelligent direction, who guides the film with skill, combining a creative and intelligent story with a very well written and thought out sense of humor.The still young and inexperienced Matthew Broderick does a good job as the protagonist, and is already showing signs of the talent he will develop in mature works. He knew how to give his character a strong charisma, combined with a rebelliousness and stubbornness typical of a teenager who has been pampered too much. Mia Sara did an equally competent job, even though she's a more cliché character: she's the pretty, popular girlfriend, who's obviously also one of the school's cheerleaders. We find characters like her in virtually every teen comedy! Personally, I didn't like Alan Ruck very much. The actor is good and does what he can, but the character is irritating with all his spoiled rich boy whining. However, it's not just Broderick that makes the movie worthwhile: Jeffrey Jones' incredible work also deserves applause. He gave life to the school principal, who wants to prove that Ferris Bueller is deliberately skipping classes, and at the expense of that, he goes through a series of hilarious situations where, of course, he suffers hard. It's an impressive work by this actor, which makes us laugh until we cry.Technically, it's a film that doesn't have any major demerits, but it also has little that stands out: it has good cinematography, an excellent soundtrack and a series of witty and well-written dialogues, but everything else is within the standard you would expect from a 80s comedy.

Ferris Bueller's day off is an inspiration to everyone that understands the complexity of high school. Ferris Bueller (Mathew Broderick) is an American Idol to all in this country. Everyone can appreciate the movie magic that is created when he takes of in the red car. The ingenuity of a moving, mechanical sleep dummy gets him started and on the right path to a truly successful day off. The plot is carefully orchestrated with Ferris Bueller (Broderick) as a wise-cracking high school senior from the fictional northern Chicago suburb of Shermer, Illinois (in reality, Lake Forest, Illinois), who decides to skip school (Lake Forest High School) for a day on the town by pretending to be sick. He convinces his nervous friend, Cameron (Ruck) to take his father's carefully restored 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California out for a spin, although Cameron's father has so little trust in him that he has memorized the car's mileage. Ferris makes the promise to erase any miles they put on the car by running the car in reverse when they return. Masquerading as her father, Ferris springs his junior girlfriend Sloane (Sara) from school on the premise that her grandmother has died. this is a truly remarkable film. This movie simply cannot be subjected to being graded by the same criteria as any other movie. It is completely original. To attempt to assess the acting in this movie is just stupid and pretentious. I have yet to see a movie that stands out in my collection (which is considerably large) as does this. Whether you are looking for depth or just comedy, which i think this movie achieves with class. Aimed at a younger generation of the time, it's truly surprising how much credit this movie gives to its audience; the esoteric conversations, the humor-in-dialogue-form, and the lack of crudeness is significantly above meant-for-the-average. This movie delivers any message a viewer may wish to find with class such that the movie/characters establish(es) an almost intimate relationship with the audience which must feel flattered by the highly intelligent work of art this movie is. It's a compliment to its viewer. Nine out of ten.

reviews.review_title: Life Moves Pretty Fast, if you don't stop and look around, you'll probably miss it.
reviews.content: I guess Ferris Bueller's statement "life moves pretty fast; and if you don't stop and look around you will probably miss it" sums up the entire theme of this movie. In fact Ferris Bueller's Day Off, in some circles, has reached the status of being a cult movie. I know that it is a cult movie in my circle of friends, though I don't see it as such. In my opinion it is a okay movie and does deserve to be stated that it is good, but I would not make it a cult movie. I guess when you compare it with real cult movies such as The Blues Brothers, Eraserhead, any Jackie Chan movie, and Edward Scissorhands (okay, it is not really a cult movie, but it is one of my favourites) Ferris Bueller's Day Off can't really compare.Anyway, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is about a final year high school student named Ferris Bueller (surprise, surprise) and guess what? Yes, it is about a day that he takes off from school. But there is a bit more to this movie that that. Ferris Bueller is an idol not only among the people at his school, and not in his home town, but basically everywhere. This idolisation of Ferris Bueller is taken right out of proportion, and in a way he is seen as the champion of everybody. He is the all round nice guy who befriends everybody, but earns himself bitter enemies, and these enemies are his principle and his sister.I guess this movie looks at High School life through the eyes of a teenager. Bueller's ambition is to own a car, and to drive the best car there is, which is his best friend's 1969 Ferarri (which is really the property of his best friend's dad). School is portrayed at a dull and boring place with dull and boring teachers. They are simply automations who tell the students everything, while the students sit there brain dead. This is contrasted with the time that Ferris Bueller is having. He is driving a cool car around the city, and going to expensive restaurants, singing in parades, and catching baseballs at a baseball match, while avoiding his Dad, his principle, and his sister.I guess the thing about this movie is the whole idea of carpe diem. Why worry about school when you are young because one has all of this energy and wants to waste it. Unfortunately when one reaches my age, one has the desire to be going out and making an impact on the world. I lived the Ferris Bueller life when I was younger, but the life got wilder and wilder until it crashed to a halt. For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction - the fun that I was having running around creating trouble smashed back on me creating a time a deep depression. Now I am much older and really wish that I did not waste so much of my youth - but in another way I if I did not waste my youth I probably will not be the person that I am today, and I would not have met that lovely lady that I have, as well as the really cool colleague that I have.On the other hand, Ferris Bueller is looking forward and knows that he must go to college to get somewhere, he simply justifies what he does now as taking time out too look at life for it goes so fast now that we will miss it if we are not careful. I guess there is a lot of truth in that because our obsession with making money and getting ahead means that we can miss a lot of the beautiful things such as love and the beauty that the world has to offer. It can also be that we miss the opportunity that God gives us.

reviews.review_title: OH YEAH! Ferris Bueller's Day Off is more like Cameron's Day off
reviews.content: Honestly I felt that this was more Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck)'s movie than Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) because nothing about Ferris is a coming of age story character arch. Ferris Bueller just end up being just Ferris Bueller by the end of the film, while Cameron grows as a character. This comedy movie written, produced and directed by John Hughes tells the story of Ferris Bueller who decides to skip school and spend the day in downtown Chicago, while not getting catch by Dean of Students Edward Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) or Ferris' sarcastic sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) . It's just another day in the life of Ferris Bueller. While, normal fans think that the movie is just that. A simple plot. Others think, the events of the day are really happening in Cameron Frye's mind. Ferris Bueller and even Ferris' girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) might just be made up in Cameron's mind to feel the void of no- friends. This might be taken serious due to the fact that Cameron is clearly older (Ruck was 29 playing 17) have no girlfriend, lonely, and has a control freak of a father. Ferris is the total opposite of Cameron: he's fun, spontaneous and has a loving family and sexy girlfriend. I don't really like Ferris due to his unrealistic nature. Truly he is unsympathetic prodigal son, leaping out of the nest at breakneck speed with flagrant disregard to everything except his own inner pleasure-seeker without judgment. It's Cameron that is the punching bag of events, taking all the risk. While, Ferris act sick to get out of school, Cameron is sick. This theory explains the more fantastic elements of the film such as the breaking of the fourth wall or unexplained events. For example, the whole city of Chicago rallies around the sick Ferris. This represents Cameron's dejected home life and how he yearns for people to care for him. This might also might represent what Cameron thinks the "popular" kids at school are like. The world revolves around them. Most of the film has Cameron wearing a medical insignia t-shirt. By the end of the film, the medical insignia, is inside out. Perhaps saying he doesn't need the medical help anymore, he has set himself on the path to correcting his life and facing his father. This film might be a comedy, but it's a thinking man comedy. There was the odd scene with Cameron was fixated on the little girl in Georges Seurat's 'A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte' painting. Does it any deeper meaning or just pointless. Cameron might see his life in pointillism, a technique of painting using small dots, hence the zoom in. That's kind of a discouraging thought. Unless, perhaps this was Cameron's mental journey towards understanding. In a way, that really works with this theory. The closer you look at the movie, the more everything looks like abstract blemishes on the fabric of Cameron's mind. When you're just observing the movie without thinking too deeply about it, it's just Ferris and his friends having a day running around Chicago. But the closer you look, the less things appear to be what we're shown. Actually, even before I did notice near the end that Ferris and Cameron had a bit of a role reversal when the car went over the edge. In that scene, Ferris, the always calm confident guy was scared and Cameron stepped up as the calm confident guy. Almost as though there was a momentary persona swap as though Cameron where beginning to reconcile himself, drawing Ferris strengths into himself and offloading his weaknesses into Ferris. Fascinating. Anyway, it's a cute theory, though probably not what John Hughes had in mind. The humor is so funny that it is often parody or use in other movies. The acting from all the cast is spot on. This movie is a tour guide of Chicago as it feature many famous Chicago landmarks including the then Sears Tower, Wrigley Field and the Art Institute of Chicago. I like how Wrigley Field had a Ferris Bueller's Day game in 2011. John Hughes wanted to film a scene where Ferris, Sloane, and Cameron go to a strip club. Paramount scrapped it. Honestly, that would have made the movie way more interesting than it supposed to have. I love the 1961 Ferrari GT California. I hope to get one, one day to drive around Chicago. Things I didn't like about the film: no character development for Ferris. All fun, but no work ethic. It might be telling kids, it's OK to have fun, it's not like you have to work a little to have that fun. I dig the "Danke Schoen" and "Twist and Shout" songs, just not the over the top parade scene. It felt too cheesy. I did like the 'Oh Yeah' song as well. The soundtrack is amazing. The movie was so popular, it got a short live TV show in 1990's with a then unknown Jennifer Aniston, a 2011's documentary and even an Super Bowl commercial in 2012. Overall: it has the spirit of effortless escapism. Like Ferris Bueller said on his day off, "Find the joy in life, because Life moves pretty fast; if you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it!'" So don't miss out on seeing this film.

Don't get me wrong, this is a good film. I just didn't get it! It just irritated me and I don't like films which break the 4th wall a lot. Same problem with Deadpool for me. I just found Ferris to be an idiot, the girl is just there to provide a pretty face and his friend is a rip off of all the breakfast club characters! That being said, I did love the back and forth between the Headmaster and Ferris. That was nearly laugh out loud comedy. Loved it! But overall, it was just a disappointment from all the praise I'd heard and kinda forgettable. But I can appreciate the film for what it is and no hate to those who love it.

Sad though this may be, I've all but built my own religion around this movie.  As an upperclass college student, I get my share of stress and bad days.  However, this movie has never failed to cheer me up.  I've actually taken days off from school in a weak imitation of Ferris.  Even though this movie is about 13 years old, it will be absolute required viewing for my children -- assuming Sloane will ever return my calls.

reviews.review_title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off joyously shows that perhaps we should all pull a sickie occasionally.
reviews.content: As with many classics which have been circulating around the historical presence of cinema, it's stupendously easy to be intimidated by a specific film. Ferris Bueller was one of those films. Endlessly referenced in pop culture, frequently discussed as one of the best teen comedies ever and directed by the 80s maestro himself that was John Hughes. Would I, a soulless British twenty-something, enjoy the fiascos and shenanigans of one Ferris Bueller? Turns out, yes! Ferris, nearing the end of the school year, decides to fake being sick so that he can explore the historical and cultural impact of downtown Chicago. However, hot on his tail are his sister and school Dean who are suspicious of his frequent absences.Not all films have to be heavy-hitting dramas tackling taboo subjects in a bid to evoke some repressed powerful emotions. Some can just be mild entertainment for the sake of depicting a joyous journey. Y'know, bringing a smile to one's face. And I know what you're thinking. "I hate smiling". Yes, well so do I. But I can guarantee, if you watch Ferris Bueller convince his friend Cameron to drive his father's 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California Spyder (believe me, had to look that one up!) or generating American buzz by slaying a infectious rendition of "Twist and Shout", you will not only smile. But laugh also. I laughed. I actually laughed!The sheer bombastic feel-good nature of this rather plotless comedy is too good to pass up. I mean, Hughes wrote the screenplay in less than a week, so clearly had intentions on character focus rather than an absorbing plot. And, despite a blasé hedonistic approach that lacked purpose other than being an exploration of Chicago (who goes to an art museum when pulling a sickie?), the intent narrative structure relying on characters worked to a certain extent.This is a film about the eponymous Ferris Bueller. His sly, meticulous and often charming personality makes him relatable. Fourth-wall breaks and all, a now legendary technique used to elaborate Ferris' inner thoughts. Broderick did a smashing job, and I couldn't envisage anyone else in the role. It was his, and his alone. Ruck as the constantly anxious Cameron also ensued some hilarity within his performance and was just as memorable as Ferris. Just a shame that the character of Sloane tagged along and had no substantial depth. In fact, she had no depth at all! An unexpected frustration from a screenplay written by Hughes, who usually carefully creates every character. Dean Rooney and Jeanie Bueller were also highlights and elevated the joyous buoyancy of the narrative. And there's something satisfying about a young Charlie Sheen playing a drug addict. I don't know why, but it amused me.The third act wrapped up too quickly for my own personal taste, with no real obstacles to overcome. Aside from Cameron confronting his father, to which we never see, Ferris surprisingly had an easy day which hampered the investment I had for the overall story. Ferris Bueller is essentially the "Easy Mode" of Chicago. Banging soundtrack though! "Love Missile F1-11"? What a tune!And to end the film with a poignant message, well, that's a Hughes film for you. Quotable, innovative and quite frankly a jubilant day off from start to finish. Despite my reservations for an actual plot, I would happily watch it repeatedly. Just so I can sing "Shoot it up"!

reviews.review_title: "80's Classic That Teaches Us To Enjoy Life Once In A While!"
reviews.content: Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara, Jeffrey Jones, Jennifer Grey, Edie McGlurg, Cindy Pickett, Lyman Ward and Charlie Sheen star in John Hughes' 1986 comedy. Broderick (Wargames) plays Chicago teen, Ferris Bueller who decides to play hooky from school. Ruck (Speed) plays his ill pal, Cameron Frye and Sara (Legend) plays Ferris' girlfriend, Sloane Peterson who join him. Jones (Beetlejuice) plays principal, Ed Rooney who learns what Ferris is up to and tries to catch him. Grey (Dirty Dancing) plays Ferris' sister, Jeannie who is jealous of him for being able to fool everyone and get all the attention. Pickett (Hot to Trot) and Ward (Planes, Trains & Automobiles) play their parents, Katie & Tom, McGlurg (Back to School) plays Rooney's secretary, Grace and Sheen (Platoon) plays a boy at a police station Jeannie meets. I grew up watching this 80's classic and liked it since. It's definitely one of Broderick & the late, Hughes' best I recommend.

reviews.review_title: You can't get a better teen comedy. A movie that breaks frontiers!
reviews.content: Seriously, this is a movie that display the real life of a teenager.See, I'm a Mexican 23 year old male. I had an American girlfriend who urged me to watch this movie. I was skeptical taking in consideration that this movie was highly compared with "American Pie" and many other American teen flicks.Well I decided to give it a try some years ago and I was impressed. This movie fits on any part of the world. Ferris has every single and possible clichè that perfectly shows how a teenager's life can be.The situations are hilarious and make you wanna return to high school times. Really! I couldn't stop praising American humor that does not necessary needs scatological references or clichèd mockery against minorities."Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is the perfect teenager movie with clever jokes, situations, and extremely likable characters. The chemistry between Ferris, his girlfriend, and his best buddy is simply charming.Ferries takes into practice the "carpe diem" phrase and teaches how a single day can change your life as a student. Sure, we all got responsibilities during that phase but come on, some spice is always necessary if not obligatory.My favorite scenes include the infamous car action where the two valet parking guys ride with the Star Wars score in the background; the way the Principal tells a girl "your ass is mine" thinking it's Ferris; the ending; the song "Oh Yeah" which is now used in "The Simpsons" as the Duff Beer theme, etc.Ah, this is a great movie that hasn't suffered from the strays of time. The best American teen movie to date. Forget about the "American Pie" boom.

Ferris buellers day off is is yet another very fun and enjoyable 80s teen comedy that holds up still today and it has a lot of very good staff in it,broderick as our lead ferris bueller was very charming and he was defienetly the best part of a film,rest of cast was also very enjoyable and interesting to follow their paths and stories,i think that many of young people can relate to this movie,cause most of us in high school were trying to achieve a one day without school and responsabilities ,and for sure i am one of them,story,script and direction were also pretty impressive and strong,to me it was even far better then movies like this deserve,ferris buellers day off was yet another great 80s teen comedy about breaking rules and geting some fun for our selfs

This post may not get a lot of love from 80's movie fans and I understand. This move is near and dear to a lot of people's hearts, and to many this may be their favorite film from the 80's. Personally, I thought it was just OK.I'm not a particularly huge Matthew Broderick fan. Not because he's a bad actor or anything. I just never really understood if he was more of a theatre type guy, a comedy kind of guy, a drama guy, or whatever. Don't get me wrong. The fact he can fall into all those categories is a testament to his versatility. It's just that of the films I have seen him in, I have always had just an average opinion of the film.The movie has a good story. Ferris Bueller obviously inspired the inspiration for Saved By The Bell's Zack Morris. And Mia Sara was the "too hot for him" type girlfriend. Even Alan Ruck provides some quality acting in this film.Perhaps the main issue with this is there were so many great movies in the same time period. This is one of those that if nothing else is on, I may tune in and watch it. But as a movie that bills itself a comedy, I feel it comes up short of the same kind of laughs that I get from watching most any other popular 80's comedy.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is considered a classic from the 1980s and one of John Hughes' best films. And it is a film deserving of this reputation because it was simply a fun film with well-writing jokes and lines and had some notable visual gags. It was a film that shows like The Simpsons, Hey Arnold, and The Goldbergs made their own versions and Family Guy stole some jokes. Ferris was a bit of an entitled ass but Matthew Broderick gave the character enough likeability and charm to override his selfishness. A little delight of a film.

A classic. It's actually good clean fun to follow "Ferris" through his day playing hooky. And it's not his first time. This is an endearing character who "gets away with everything". (Save Ferris!) His principal is out to get him. Will he succeed in bringing Ferris down? His sister is angry...She never gets away with anything. She knows he is faking. How can she get through to her parents and expose her brother for the faker he is? (Recognize the guy she joins on the couch? None other than bad-boy bro to Bratpacker Emilio Estevez, Charlie Sheen...) Not to mention, Ben Stein's breakout role ("Bueller....Bueller..."), this also brought Jennifer Grey and Matthew Broderick to America's attention. (Feel sorry for Michael J. Fox...I heard he turned down this role. But he already had our attention, didn't he?) I went to the theater twice to see this one when it came out. I don't own it -- yet -- but am looking forward to adding it to my collection. Well worth sitting through this one. Enjoy it with your friends and even your kids. It's a lot of fun.

"Bueller?... Bueller?... Bueller?" Every teenager dreams of skipping school and Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) does just that. In this 1986 teenage comedy, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, a not so innocent teenager nearing the end of his high school career, ditches school and, with best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) and girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara), embark on an adventure to the "Windy City" of Chicago. With the upcoming obstacles of college, Bueller plans a day of shenanigans in hopes of saving Cameron. Little does Bueller know that his sister, Jeanie Bueller (Jennifer Grey), and principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) would do everything in their power to make sure that the so called "perfect" child would be caught red-handed.Jeanie Bueller and Principal Ed Rooney didn't expect that catching the famous Ferris Bueller was going to be easier said than done. Along the way, they themselves dig into deeper trouble, even with the law! Running through neighbor's yards, encountering a gruesome rottweiler, and maybe even a little romance with a young, troubled teen (Charlie Sheen). What else could possibly go wrong? Throughout this movie, it is hard for anyone to despise Ferris. His young, seemingly childish attitude that never gets him in trouble appeals to everyone. He never ceases to address the audience with a sarcastic, funny side note as if we are apart of his scheme. By the end of this movie, the audience will see Ferris develop on so many levels. He even goes as far as taking the blame for something he didn't do, even if that means being caught. Matthew Broderick comes through with his best performance to date.Although Cameron, much more reserved than Bueller, is a bit skeptical of Bueller's mischief, he slowly warms up to the idea of fun and even does the unexpected. Yet throughout this movie he never seems to wear more than three expressions. It's not until the end that the audience sees the true Cameron that has been bottled up. Will his father ever open his heart to his son? Sloane Peterson plays the perfect girl for the wild and unpredictable Ferris Bueller. She's able to keep Ferris in check and temporarily out of trouble, yet she still plays along with his shenanigans. Together they balance out to the perfect high school relationship.John Hughes, director of the famous "16 Candles" and "The Breakfast Club," adds another memorable and comedic piece to his repertoire. Through the cultivation of every teenager's dream and the development of these characters, John Hughes certainly delivers. Anyone looking for countless laughs should indulge in this one of a kind teenage comedy.

I love this man, his work, his sense of humor, and his way to say important things by comedy.However, I see that the comic scenes here were less than what they should be, or maybe it's just me who waited for more! Plus, somehow I think that the real hero of the movie's drama was (Alan Ruck) as (Cameron Frye) the friend, because he is the only person who changed through the journey of the day / the movie, as he was dying because of his fear to do what he really wants, as the opposite of (Ferris Bueller). However, at the end, he became capable of facing his fear to be what he wants. But on the other hand, the original hero, or the movie's title character, remained the same till the very end; as the selfsame liar, swindler, who's enjoying the moment without any concern, or whatsoever about the future!Maybe (Hughes) was showing a nice symbol for being loose, released and free just to teach us, as the regular bourgeois, how to loosen a little, so not to miss the train of life. The beauty of it is that (Ferris Bueller), with all of his values, isn't harmful. Look at his frauds; for instance, he didn't run away from school to do drugs, or to rob a bank. He went with his friends to an art museum. I tried, so many times, to do such a visit with my own friends, and after the school time, but I couldn't convince them! And (Hughes) presented him as that intelligent wicked, to the extent that he could beat any future problems, especially with the love of the people. For example, he vanquished the principal too many times by his cleverness, having the ultimate victory by his sister's last minute rescue, when she finally believed in his crazy deeds and his lively philosophy. Therefore (Bueller) was just a symbol, a lovely mentor, more than a guy who would change. Although it's not as strong as being weaker, or suffering from defects sometimes, but (Hughes), by this dealing, didn't only venerate the character itself, he also meant to disclose our frailty and failure, compared to such a young man.I loved the glee childish feeling of the whole movie, the condensation of all the events in less than a daytime, the special appearance of (Charlie Sheen) in a brief yet suitable role, so (Jeffrey Jones) as the poor clumsy principal who looks and walks as so confident (Dirty Harry)! Plus those fresh ideas: the school's contribution for the fake sick (Bueller), redressing the car's counter by the hard way, the mechanical robot as (Bueller)'s clone in bed. And yes, I loved the main character and the performance of (Matthew Broderick), but I just think that he was more sensitive and less bravery to be (Bueller). Of course (Broderick) is a gentle comedian and his acting here is so vivacious, however his soft presence was one of some reasons that made me think that he wasn't as mad, bold and indifferent as (Ferris Bueller), or maybe not as any (Ferris Bueller) of who I've met.At last, you must ask yourself with confusion, as well as fury, where is that great writer?, and where are his enjoyable, innocent, and meaningful comedies?, and how could he let us in the hands of so-called comedies which have tons of toilet humor, and don't say something that lives longer than a week!

reviews.review_title: Since when is there a parade on a school day?
reviews.content: Just who is the parade for? Kids who skip school? And since when can someone just jump up on a float and start singing without being kicked off? And why can't Ferris just wait till the weekend to have fun? This movie sends the message that cutting class is cool and you will have a great time if you do and not get in any trouble. Awful.

I'm suprised John Hughes actually made a FUNNY comedy. Weird Science was dumb and boring, Breakfast Club was slow, nothing interesting happened, Pretty In Pink completly sucked. Ferris Buellers Day Off is a real suprise! Not very realistic(especially what Mr. Rooney goes through to prove Ferris is skipping school)yeah, but who ever said movies were supposed to be about reality? It's about time he made something funny and GOOD and not unbearable like all his other movies. FAVORITE SCENE: When Rooney says some very bad things to the man on the other end of the phone who he thinks is Ferris, then Ferris calls the secretary.

reviews.review_title: Wild, Carefree Hijinx with the Ultimate Coasting Senior
reviews.content: An unusually sprawling, giddy production from John Hughes's most fruitful period as a director. Where his preceding efforts like The Breakfast Club and Sixteen Candles were rich, moody tales set almost unanimously in small high schools, Ferris is a plucky, enthusiastic fantasy that breaks free from the confines of an institutional setting and celebrates life outside the walls. Matthew Broderick brings the brash, popular title character to life with an energy that's so infectious it's easy to overlook a few ridiculous twists and turns, and the plot takes full advantage, pushing the envelope as far as it can feasibly get away with. Great comedic timing, an astoundingly deep, versatile cast of characters and the rocketing pace of an out-of-control avalanche help make this a timeless comedy that's aged extremely gracefully. The only sticking point, really, is the totally '80s wardrobe.

What can I say about high school? The separation between diligent students and lazy students couldn't be more obvious. It's also funny how breaking all the rules is a desperate longing for rebellion and following all the rules is a desperate longing for acceptance. Highschool was surely a funny time.Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) was an interesting young chap who wanted to enjoy his life as a youth whilst living in a suburban Illinois neighbourhood. I must say, it is typical behaviour in places where there is no action. Suburbia is a 'manufactured' lifestyle where there is no activity of any sort. Children often feel bored and as a result, they misbehave more often.Ferris is in his senior year and he longs to have fun before he graduates. It may not seem so, but he means well when he drags his scrupulously-natured best friend, Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) and his sweetly-natured girlfriend, Sloan Peterson (Mia Sara) to 'dance' the day away (so to say). They play along with it and as a result, they unexpectedly had an unforgettable day and a thrill of a lifetime (the ball game, fancy lunch prank, cruising downtown Chicago in a red Ferrari). He cunningly fakes sick in the most technological of ways (even with our advanced 21st century technology, I must say this is more advanced than I could have ever imagined; he must have really planned this). Life is short. We should live every second as if it were our last.Mr Rooney was a successful, suburban secondary school principal who obviously has nothing better to do than to 'catch' Ferris in the act. He was so determined to do so that he went well out of his way to the point where he was only fooling himself. To reinforce authority is one thing, but to 'chase' someone is another.This movie really gets one thinking about how things could have been if he or she followed or broke the rules. Out of all the skip days I have seen, I must say that this is one that could never be easily executed (for those of whom I knew thought they were 'bad' by skipping school by writing false parental notes; that is rather asinine). I rate this film 5* for its originality and creativity.
Although it has its memorable moments, it falls short of the plot and charisma of the characters.

This movie is great, unlike most of John Hughes' efforts during the 80's (see Breakfast Club, Pretty in Pink, etc) Broderick is great in this role about a kid whose parents are saps and who can get away with anything. Incidentally, doesn't Broderick look like Greg Maddux? Anyway, Alan Ruck is good also as Cameron, and the scene where he pounds the hell out of his dad's ferrari is unforgettable. And who could forget Jeffrey Jones as the bum principal. He utters the classic line in the following sequence: Rooney: "What's the score?" Bartender: "0-0" Rooney: Who's winning?" Bartender: (incredulous) "the bears!"All in all this is a great film and every time I hear "Twist and Shout" I can't help of think of this movie.

I liked this movie. It is an escape-type film, for anyone who has ever wanted to get away with playing hookey. Matthew Broderick is hillarious, and the scenes with the economics teacher (Ben Stein) are classic. Incidentally, Mr. Stein and his trademark monotone can be seen on several other movies and the clear eyes commercials. *** out of ****

reviews.review_title: Take a break from Intense Drama movies and watch this .
reviews.content: This is an American teen movie, which any teenager of any country can relate themselves to. Such is the quality of stories written by John Hughes. Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick), a high school senior student, takes a day off from school and plans to have fun with his best friend, Cameron, played by Alan Ruck and his girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara). The movie, with hilarious effect, revolves around the trip of Ferris and also how he manages to trick his parents and principal, Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), even under his sister's reproachful eyes. Credit goes to John Hughes for some of the really side-splitting funny scenes. Jeffrey Jones is superbly funny as the determined principal who tries to catch Ferris red-handed and then falls to Ferris' pranks. Broderick, Ruck and Sara, they all do their parts and delivered a nice performance together. Jennifer Grey is also good as Ferris' resentful sister. Lastly, quoting Ferris " Life moves fast. If we don't stop and look around a bit, we might miss it" , one could say sometimes it's great for the movie-watchers to take a break from watching all those high intense drama movies and watch some light-hearted movies like this. :)

Variety was way off the mark when it stated that Ferris Bueller's Day Off exhibits John Hughes on an off day. This is one of the high points of the teen-comedy genre and probably the best of John Hughes's films (only The Breakfast Club can be considered a rival).Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is a teenager from a rich Chicago family. Adored by the pupils at his school, Ferris is the ultimate Mr. Popular with everyone apart from his spiteful sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) and the school's obsessive principal Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones). One hot summer's day, Ferris feels the urge to skip school so he fools his parents into believing that he has a fever. He then enlists the aid of his depressed buddy Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) to plan the ultimate adventure. First, they "borrow" Cameron's father's classic Ferrarri, then they engineer a story to get Ferris's girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) out of school, before heading off to Chicago to live the dream. On their agenda are such excesses as lunch in a swanky restaurant, a visit to Sears Tower, a trip to the baseball stadium, a whistle-stop tour of the museum, an interlude at the stock exchange.... at one point, Ferris even hijacks a parade float and performs a Beatles tune for the adoring crowds! Meanwhile, Ed Rooney spends the entire day attempting to catch Ferris out, proving once and for all that he isn't the dream son his parents believe him to be.What makes Ferris Bueller's Day Off work is the simplicity of the premise and the skillful accumulation of comic moments that are built around it. Jones has a fabulous time in his role as the ever-suffering school principal; Lyman Ward is hilarious as Ferris's gullible, goofy father; Ruck is by turns funny and pitiful as the melancholy Cameron Frye; Grey perfects a bitchy scowl as Ferris's sister; and, if you watch closely, there's a truly outstanding cameo from Charlie Sheen as a streetwise junkie who melts Jeanie's heart. All this is held together by Broderick's good work as the central character. There are some terrific comedy moments, the best of which for me are when Ferris's father gets held up by a car being erratically driven by a 4 ft octogenarian, and the scene where a busty nurse turns up to "cheer-up" the poorly Ferris. Many critics and reviewers have noted the sentimental vein that runs through the film, and it's true that it spoils things slightly, but on the whole this is an irresistible comedy and an absolute must for anyone who enjoys a good teen flick.

What a self-indulgent piece of crap. Yes, it has its humorous parts. Most not to do with Broderick.Here is a guy who killed two people in a road accident in Ireland (Northern Ireland), got off lightly, offers no recompense to the two victims' families, because he is Hollywood, that means spoiled and he offers no remorse, but just "does not remember what happened", sort of like the BS that Ferris thinks he can get away with. Spoiled little Hollywood brat who destroyed a family and offered no remorse on his part. Do you really like this guy?

reviews.review_title: A charismatic teenager risks it all for one more "sick" day.
reviews.content: When this came out in 1986, I had no intention of seeing it. There had been too many movies about bratty teenagers for my taste, and there seemed to be no reason to devote a couple of hours to it. Flash forward about ten years, and I finally saw it on one of the premium cable channels. Long story short, at the age of 52, I fell in love with it. I can't count the number of times I've seen it since, and I look forward to enjoying it again. I am particularly fond of Jennifer Grey's work in this; I haven't seen her since in anything that shows her talent as well. (P. S. Of course I own a copy too.) Love it, love it, love it!--arnie113

reviews.review_title: Ferry Bueller isn't as good as he looks.
reviews.content: This was a fun movie. The plot is very weird to be honest. Ferris Bueller takes a day off from school and the school principle tries to prove that he fakes it. This movie has many great jokes, but whole concept is just so weird. Ferris is good guy in heart but he does so many intentional evil things: he impersonates people, he forces his friend to let him use his dad's car, also he build a fanbase of students which he propogates to be rebellous, the list would go on and on. The principle is just doing his job he tries his best to keep kids in school, he tries to get Bueller so he could punnish him and maybe his fandom would reduce. As I said this is a fun and funny movie, but the concept is just so weird.

reviews.review_title: What a riot! One of the best comedies I've ever seen
reviews.content: Despite its age, 'Ferris Bueller' has to be one of my favorite comedies. There are some annoying sequences and the odd cliche, but mostly it's a well-written, funny take on a boy, Ferris (Matthew Broderick) who plays hooky from school, while trying to dodge the ever-annoying principal (Jeffrey Jones) and his parents (Cindy Pickett & Lyman Ward).Although the plot is well-known to most, I still have to say:***WARNING! POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD***Grade 12 student Ferris Bueller decides, impulsively, to take the day off & play hooky. He contrives a plan to get his girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara) out of school, and cajoles his pal Cameron (Alan Ruck) into going along. Dean of Students Ed Rooney (Jones) who discovers Ferris has been absent 'niiiiiine times this semester', also contrives a plan - to catch him in the act in order to keep Ferris from graduating. Ferris & his pals take off into Chicago, eating at expensive restaurants, seeing museums, and getting caught up in a parade (in a very badly overblown sequence). Mr. Rooney, meanwhile, tries to break into the Bueller home but finds himself confronted by the family Rottweiler and - later - Ferris's sister Jeannie (Jennifer Grey). What follows is a comedy of errors as Rooney finds himself sinking into a mudhole, getting chased by the Rottweiler, and being confronted by an obnoxious flower-delivery man. ***END SPOILER WARNING***The parade sequence was overdone and some of it was totally unnecessary, especially the 'Twist & Shout' sequence. I found myself squirming in my chair until that one was over. It also seemed a little cliche in the sequence where Ferris is racing to get home before his parents, and stops while running through a yard to introduce himself to 2 girls in bikinis suntanning in their yard. The teachers are portrayed as dull, boring, uninspiring goofs (which is exactly what I thought of some of mine!), especially the economics teacher (Ben Stein, in the role that launched his career) whose dull, monotone voice...'Anyone? Anyone?...the Great Depression...' left the students in an apparent trance, most staring at him with their mouths agape or in one case, asleep on his desk and drooling. The english teacher (Dell Close) was another favorite, leaving Sloane and her classmates in la-la-land with his bland, dragging voice; 'In....what...way...does the author's use of prison....symbolize...' This guy reminded me of teachers I'd had in Grade 8! By the end of these takes I was roaring. I'm not going to spoile the ending except to say it is hilarious as it shows what finally happens to Mr. Rooney. Rent it to find out!**** out of *****

Funny movie. It is about the perfect skip day. Ferris is the most popular guy in school and well, everywhere. Everyone knows and loves Ferris. Except Mr. Rooney the principal. Ferris devises the perfect way to skip and acts it out. Great movie, plenty of humor and remember, "if you want your parents to think you're sick. Lick your palms. It may seem childish and stupid but then again, so is high school."

Ferris Bueller's Day Off, is in my honest opinion, *THE* best comedy of the past two decades. Does this film have a single flaw? All performances are wonderful (especially those of Matthew Broderick and Edie McClurg as Grace and my personal favorite, Jennifer Grey). Ferris contains some truly unforgettable one-liners (most of which are spoken by Grey). The facial and physical actions of all the different characters are also a riot. From the sick in bed scene, to the boring teachers, to the snooty restaurant, FBDO, never loses it's comic momentum. John Hughes has truly capture the spirit of every coming of age teenager, in this film, which I've seen dozens of times. It's one of those classics which just never gets old. If you have not seen it yet-go rent it NOW. You dont' know what you've been missing.

reviews.review_title: Forget everything else, THIS is the best film ever made.
reviews.content: Where do I start? This is just too good to not see. Every scene is a classic, from start to finish.Highlights include:Ferris' guide to faking sick, The "snarty" waiter, Twist and Shout ft the actual mayor of Chicago, Dad's advice over the phone, Water Music with vomiting sounds (funnier than it should be!), Ferris' Dad's driving mannerisms, Charlie Sheen's druggie, shave and a haircut.I could go on.The quotes are endless; I use so many in my daily life that I could probably recite it all by rote:Hey Ferris hows your bod?, You killed the car, Niiiine tiiiiiimes.... , Shouldn't you be in class? Probably, So that's how it is in their family.Again I could go on.Life goes pretty fast. If you don't stop and see this film you could miss one of the greatest pieces of entertainment ever made.Save Ferris!

Maybe I am stuck in the past, but I never tire of watching this movie in reruns... and I just turned 50! It must be the secret dream of every adult (as well as student) to just "check out" for the day! And there's no better person to pal around with than Ferris. This guy could probably turn a trip for a root canal into a picnic.   Perfect casting all around - from the oh-so-typical Bueller family to Grace, the school secretary (who has a line on all the school cliques - the dweebs, motorheads, sportos, etc) Didn't everybody have an Ed Rooney in the head office? There is something for everybody on this joyride through Chicago. From the ballpark to the art museum to the parade and everything in between - a day could not have more fun crammed into it. Even those angst-ridden teen characters (Jeannie/Shawna and Cameron) have an upspin in their lives. All in all, a great time was had by all. Bueller....Bueller....Bueller....

Matthew Broderick is perfectly cast as the title character. Its the only time in his career he did a John Hughes movie and boy did he pick a good one, but its mostly because of him that its so good.  Ferris enjoys life, has a ton of friends and a very pretty girlfriend named Sloane Peterson.  The only strain in his life is his best friend Cameron who is prone to anxiety attacks, wild mood swings and general unpleasantness.
One day Ferris decides he cannot bear school so fakes an illness to spend the day with Sloane & Cameron.  They go to Chicago, see the city from way above, go to the Art Institute of Chicago and a Cubs game, have lunch in an upscale restaurant, and join in on a parade.  While all that is going on, Ferris is being found out by the principal Ed Rooney.  His sister is also after blood because she knows he's faking it and is jealous of his ability to get what he wants. Its all for fun and a lot of it works, but for me the movie drags considerably when Cameron starts in on his litany of problems.  I am not unsympathetic to a teenagers problems, but they are in the wrong movie. 
The best thing about this movie is the parade.  Ferris yells 'Twist and Shout' by the Beatles and all of Chicago joins in.  Something about all those people, all getting along and laughing and smiling and having a great time, makes me really love that scene.Lastly, what a car! And I don't even drive, but if I had that car I'd learn in a hurry!  8/10.

Wouldn't we have all liked to get away with what Ferris did? I liked this movie although not to the extent many reviewers on imdb did, I wouldn't rank this as the best teen movie ever although it was a great concept and a highly entertaining movie. I think the appeal of this story was getting away with the impossible-what kid wouldn't have wanted to get away with this? Maybe we all lived vicariously though Ferris!I remember very few teen movies from my past as popular as this one although there were a few. My feelings about Ferris Bueller(who came up with that soapopera like NAME?!) are all positive although I don't remember it as being quite as funny as others do. But this is a lovely little movie that didn't need to resort to cheap gags and over tired plots to be original and funny and that's a plus. Although this doesn't touch Breakfast club or Fast times to name a few for me, it's a darn good movie and a fun one that all kids should see.

Well, I finally saw this movie, and I can't say I thought a whole lot about it. We have a kid who doesn't think much of conventional education, and so he tends to eschew towards seeking knowledge and wisdom his own unique way; i.e. blow off school, homework, and embrace the big world.Yeah, okay. Great. Depending on what you do in life you may need that diploma and high marks, although I've never been asked for my grades on ANY job I've ever applied to. But hey, who knows? That may change, though I doubt it.Reasonalby well shot, cliché dialogue, predictable plot, I can't say I really enjoyed this thing from frame one. Hell, I could have written this script if I was of a mind to. We follow the adventures and misadventures of a teenager who's actually too ready for the world, and is being held back by formal institutions of education. In the end he finds his moment to shine, and we all benefit in the end.I can't tell you how many times since this movie hit the theatres that people kept telling me to go see it. Well, I did. Neat. It's a good movie, but I personally found it predictable to a fault. I guess my life is a little more unique than everyone else's. Oh well.Give it a shot, but odds are you've already seen it. Either way don't say I didn't warn you.

reviews.review_title: "It is his fault he didn't lock the garage."
reviews.content: This is a film that will lift your spirits every time. A real feel good movie, it delivers with a great story and first rate comedy. The film itself is funny and entertaining to watch from start to finish, with some scenes that feature a lovely Ferrari 250 GT California, which does get the attention of Ferris, who wants to take the Ferrari out for a spin.While it may be difficult to watch Ferris Bueller run up slides and jump on trampolines all to get home with a serious eye, one must admit that when one looks back at school, some things are like that, even if only in your mind. The movie has very funny jokes and slapstick. The parade downtown with Ferris on the float singing "Twist And Shout" is a showstopper, and a memorable cinema scene. Broderick is good. He brings Ferris' cocky charm to life and makes it real. Grey is perfect as the sister from hell. Overall, this is a great, funny, poignant movie, a tribute to living, instead of getting caught up in life.Overall rating: 8 out of 10.

In less capable hands than those of Matthew Broderick, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" might have been unbearable. Ferris is self-centered, manipulative, dishonest. He uses his friends and family. He hacks into his school computer. He commits identity fraud. But there is something so darn likable about the way Broderick plays Ferris, we don't hold any of that against him. He comes off as likable as any other literary trickster (more likable than some). One of the charming things Bueller does is break the "fourth wall" and talk directly to the audience, sort of like his own Greek chorus. This way we willingly become co-conspirators in his misdeeds, and share the wonderful feeling that comes with shaking school off for the day and having a good time.At rock bottom, Ferris is just a boy who doesn't want to go to school. And it makes sense. Ferris does not seem to cherish a good education, but he is a whole lot smarter than anyone else, especially his drab teachers (one of whom is played hilariously by Ben Stein). By his talk of college, Ferris is probably making good enough marks, and having to sit through one tedious school day after another is wasting a good mind.After all, one of the things Ferris does is to look at Kandinskys in an art museum. A boy who goes to a museum when he blows off school rather than a brothel should not be forced to grind through boring school days that confine his mind. Oh, he also takes in a Cubs game (the film is set in the Chicago area).But Ferris' cleverness is not appreciated in all quarters. Because everything seems to come so easily for Ferris, his sister (Jennifer Grey) is envious. Knowing Ferris is faking sick, she becomes determined to blow his cover and get him in trouble -- not knowing he has taken off from the suburbs and is in the big city. Ferris is also being stalked by Mister Rooney, the principal (Jeffrey Jones, who turned in a wonderful performance as the emperor in "Amadeus" a couple of years earlier, and who is just as good this time around in a very different part). He has no proof, but he is certain he can catch Ferris Bueller malingering. So obsessive is he -- even though he has Ferris' mother's assurance her son is off sick and not being truant -- one feels Rooney and Bueller have a long history together, and it is not just this one incident that sets him off. Bueller's little games, we sense, have gotten the better of Rooney before.Can Bueller escape detection in truancy with his sister and Rooney both pursuing him? Can he get his friend's father's EXTREMELY rare automobile, which they have taken without permission, back home without a scratch? And will he and his pals get safely back from Chicago before their parents catch them?Loath as I am to bring in personal experiences, I'll admit I am the age of some of the actors in the movie. I was born in the year after Jennifer Grey and the year before Matthew Broderick (I'm also exactly Broderick's height). So even though they are playing teenagers, they were both well into their twenties; I was in grad school the year this film came out. Somehow, I missed it. I probably figured it was another dreary John Hughes "teen angst" flick. I only caught the movie in 2011, twenty-five years after its release; I may be the only fifty year old this movie speaks to. My philosophy in school was the same as Bueller's. And frankly, work for me has been nothing more than an extension of school. I have pulled many "Buellers" in my time without having a name for them -- which I will now regularly apply when I call in sick to have a good time. Since I knew nothing about the movie before seeing it, I was able to enjoy it without knowing what was coming next, and seeing it as fresh as if it had just been released. And I related to it on its most basic level, which I probably would not have had anyone but Broderick gotten the lead role. Otherwise, I'd have written him off as a manipulative little skunk. With Broderick in the lead I can list this among my "feel good" movies.And I think I'll pull a Bueller this Friday!Oh, "skive" is British slang for shirking responsibilities to do something fun. And I won't be going a museum. Whoopee!

reviews.content: I love Ferris Buller's Day Off, the movie is very funny and very well written with a great job by the actors.The movie is basically just cool and that is the entire movie, Matthew Broderick is awesome and plays a very cool guy in this movie.The other characters are also very good and i like the writing, it is a good idea about him just taking the day off.This has been one of my favorite movies ever since i was a little kid, and i still love to watch it now and it really never get's old.You should watch this movie, a lot of people have seen it but if you have not you are missing out.Ferris Bueller is a classic, watch it laugh, enjoy and this film will become a classic to you.It is a cult film in it's own way, because it is just like the only film like this and i think it will always be that way.
One of the best movie of there but is so underrated it deserves more than this

reviews.review_title: An Accurate Reflection of the Decade of Grim Optimism
reviews.content: I think there's three movies produced, filmed, and released in my lifetime that fall into the category of greatness: Schindler's List, Pulp Fiction, and Ferris Bueller's Day Off.Don't see this movie for the hype. See it because you lived through the eighties. If you didn't live through the eighties, see it because this film gives you the spirit of the decade on a silver platter. You'll learn something.The eighties were about grim optimism, and this sort of semi-nihilistic veneer is expressed in the scene where Cameron and Sloane discuss their interests. Sloane: What are you interested in? Cameron: Nothing. Absolutely nothing.And they chuckle it off like it's no big deal to have no interests in life. Their outlook is positive despite themselves, or in spite of themselves. Meanwhile Ferris lip syncs on a parade float and the world is there to catch him before he falls. The Eighties and the Fifties had many cultural similarities, and let me just point out that Matthew Broderick is the first and only male lead since Johnny Weissmuller in "Jungle Jim" to effortlessly pull off animal prints. Bueller sports two: his vest, and in one scene, his swim trunks. Does this embody coolness? Probably not, but it works here. This film is fun, entertaining, but more importantly it's the best Hughes had to offer us. You know you want to see it. Oh, yeah.

reviews.review_title: Hilarious, even if the plot makes little sense
reviews.content: It's a comedy set in Chicago and one of its suburbs in the 1980s. It follows a charismatic high school senior who decides to skip a day of school a month or so before he graduates.Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is a smooth, fast-talking guy for whom everything seems to come up roses. However, the school's vice-principal/dean of students, Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), finds Ferris manipulative and slippery and wants to catch him in a serious misdeed. Ferris's sister, Jeanie (Jennifer Grey), resents his popularity and ability to manipulate their parents, Katie (Cindy Pickett) and Tom (Lyman Ward). Katie and Tom are focused on their high-power business jobs.Ferris talks his insecure best friend, Cameron (Alan Ruck), into skipping school with him. Together, they arrange to get Ferris's girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara), to join them. They borrow one of Cameron's dad's rare cars and spend the day in downtown Chicago with various adventures. Throughout the day, Ed Rooney tries mightily to track Ferris down. Jeanie finally overcomes her jealousy of Ferris after encountering a druggie (Charlie Sheen) at the police station near the film's end.The movie has no reality; it's just a fast-paced sendup of high school students outwitting adults at every turn. Nevertheless, it's hilarious, even if the plot makes little sense. Matthew Broderick is very funny, as is Jeffrey Jones. Alan Ruck is good; Mia Sara makes less of an impression.

reviews.review_title: When teenager films were not just about emo anxious kids
reviews.content: I have a strong dislike for teenage and coming of age films they take themselves too seriously and don't really get what being a teenager is all about. Most recently Boyhood in particular rubbed me the wrong way. Confusion and anxiety are a big part of teenage life but it's not the only thing, primarily it's about hanging out with friends, bunking classes, obsessing over girls (or boys as the case maybe), cars, lying to your parents to sneak into that party instead of fighting them like a spoiled brat and yes some confusion about one's future and existential dread as well, it's not the only thing. Ferris Bueller gets this perfect mix right. It's not only a fun movie with great moments but has some layers to it as well. My favorite scene is the iconic parade scene while Beatles' Twist and Shout plays in the parade. FB reminds us that while being a teenager can be hard, the good outweighs the bad and for the most part it's fun, something which most modern teenage films would like you to forget.

_Ferris Bueller's Day Off_ is one of those classic movies where the main character's struggle is something we've all strived for at one time or another: the struggle to take it easy. We've all had that one teacher or authority figure in our lives that just drives us nuts, and in this movie, Ferris, his best friend Cameron and his girlfriend Sloane fight against school, evil principals, and thier own inner deamons. A perfect film for anyone who's ever appreciated thier youth.

reviews.review_title: The film that started it all...
reviews.content: ,,, my irrational hatred of Matthew Broderick, that is!  I saw this film and initially thought I hated Broderick, which was puzzling, since I'd previously found him amiable enough in "WarGames" and "Project X".  Then I caught "The Cable Guy" on TV and realised that it wasn't necessarily Broderick that I hated, but Ferris Bueller!   Some people admire the character's brash personality and hip posing.  I don't.  Every time Bueller was onscreen I wanted to punch the smug, cocky little **** into the middle of next week.  Was it just me?  My repeated fantasies of doing immeasurable harm to Broderick with various sharp implements were just that, fantasies.  What's worse, is that I will never get my chance to exact revenge on Ferris Bueller, due to the minor inconvenience of his non-existence...  Despite these barely checked psychopathic tendencies at the mention of Bueller, I found it impossible to dislike the film.  It screams "good natured wish fulfillment movie" at every turn, is pretty inventive, and gets you wondering "What would I do?" at certain points.  The cast all have fun will their roles, but Matthew Broderick's status as a C list star and John Hughes' current record of cr*p movies is living proof that they are being punished by a higher power for their hateful rendering of such an obnoxius little prig.    After all the bonhomie, only the hardest of hearts will remain staunch in their hatred of the movie.  The hatred of Ferris Bueller, however, will remain supreme.  The fact that certain characters in the movie also hated Ferris as much as I did made a slightly bitter pill that much easier to swallow.   This could have been a great teen movie, but the fact that I consider it slightly over-rated and want to kill the main character merely makes it good.  There is a silver lining to every cloud, though, and for "Ferris..." it is this:  the fact that I consider it only a 'good' movie means that I do not feel obligated to add it to my collection.  Were I motivated to rate it one mark higher than the 7 out of ten that I actually gave it, it would require purchase; and then I would have to grimace through an otherwise decent film every time 'HE' appeared onscreen...   One final point: you may think that my slight hysteria over the main character is something of an act, in a crude ploy to make my review more interesting and amusing.  This it MAY have done, but an act I can assure you it is not.  I think I'll go have a lie down now...

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is about a high school student named Ferris pretending to be sick, so he can have a day out with his best friends.The plot of the movie is simple and engaging.The characters are really likeable and the dialogue between them is great. I really liked that Ferris Bueller broke the 1st wall often and the great speech Cameron gave, later in the movie.The acting was high quality.I would definitely recommend this film to people interested in a fun and entertaining comedy.

reviews.review_title: An 80's Classic That Has Aged Surprisingly Well
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a 1980's film gem that not only rises above its teen comedy genre, but escaped the outdated tag that now defines most of its peers. Written and directed by John Hughes, and starring Matthew Broderick as Ferris, the film is the tale of a spunky mischievous teenager who cuts school for the day with the ultimate of style and "moxy". Ferris is ultimately a tale of a self absorbed but lovable teen who just wants to have fun (with himself as the lead character). A little misguided and vain, but a character that "most" of the audience will root for nonetheless.NOTE: The story of Ferris Bueller is told from a young persons perspective, with the adults either relegated to minor roles, or portrayed as stick in the mud buffoons (for its intended audiences pleasure of course). This narrative is typical of most of Hughes best films, as is a certain "cartoonishness", so if not your cup of tea, your enjoyment of this film could be diminished.Ferris Bueller scores 8/10 (7 for the film itself plus 1/10 extra for the music)

Having watched the recent Honda commercial send-up of Matthew Broderick, I watched this movie again.This will always be a great teen coming of age movie, or at least a movie for people under the age of 30 who were recently in high school. It's premise is based on the human urge to go against the system and buck the rules and just have a good time. Practically every kid that feels stuck in the walls of an institution such as high school is going to get these urges, and for all of those kids, Ferris Bueller is their hero.Matthew Broderick brings a warm, innocent charm to the title role as a young man who has luck on his side. Everything goes his way, from worming his best friend (Alan Ruck) into taking his father's rare Ferrari, to warding off the high school principal (Jeffrey Jones) to getting his girlfriend (Mia Sara) out of school as well.Writer/director John Hughes takes his love for teenagers and school situations and gives us a story that deals with life outside school and the freedoms and privileges of being a kid. What Ferris does is, as they say, getting away with murder, but it is such a joy to watch him get into predicaments and wonder how can he possibly get out of this one. Broderick is a delight, as are the supporting cast, especially Jennifer Grey as his envious sister. This movie is about luck and what that power can do for you. It is also about enjoying life and the power that can do. It is the ultimate skipping school movie and is one of Hughes' best efforts as a writer and director. See it for the story, the funnies or the plain joy of skipping school and catching a glimpse of life as it was back then.

reviews.review_title: A classic 80s comedy that never gets old
reviews.content: What John Hughes brought to Hollywood in the 1980s was some classic teen comedies that went on by cult classics and brought inspiration to many other teen flicks. Hughes was a director that brought a new generation to the coming-of-age genre, and with films like 'Sixteen Candles, 'Weird Science', and his most famous 'The Breakfast Club', comedies that many teenagers today are sadly missing out on, as Hollywood has declined more and more with original comedies. In recent years, the teen comedy genre has been gradually losing its vibe with movies depraved of originality. This comedy directed by John Hughes, is one that stands high on the pinnacle of teen films. Matthew Broderick plays Ferris Bueller, a popular Chicago high school senior who's been known playing hooky from school by faking medical illnesses, unlike his sister Jeanie (played by Jennifer Grey) who's grown frustrated for being unsuccessful with ditching school without getting caught. On another day of skipping school, Bueller calls his reluctant best friend Cameron (played by Alan Ruck) and his underclassmen girlfriend Sloane (played by Mia Sara) to ditch school and join him on an adventure through the streets of downtown Chicago for a day of fun in Cameron's dad's 1961 Ferrari GT. Their truancy however, gains the attention of the school principal Ed Rooney (played by Jeffrey Jones) who's tried desperately to catch Bueller skipping school throughout the year, and goes the hunt for him, Sloane, and Cameron as they tour through Chicago on their day off.Ferris Bueller is definitely the role that defined Matthew Broderick's career, at least my opinion. Bueller is the kind of character who is easily likable and fun to watch, and his message about how life moves pretty fast and if you don't stop to look around every once in a while, you could miss it, a message many can relate to. The movie itself is very easy to relate, especially nowadays. When you reaches your senior year of high school, there's a good bet you developed a case of "senioritus" to the point where you might have planned a day to ditch school with your friends and go to the mall, got to the movies, etc. Yes, it is not the smartest decision to make and can handle you into trouble, but it is just the reminder that we were all teenagers at one point. Matthew Broderick brings such delight and charm to the titular character, and he is very funny in most scenes that it keeps viewers entertained and liking him as a character. Alan Ruck who plays his best friend Cameron who struggles to endure their day of fun from the fear of being caught by his hard-nosed father or Bueller's day who happens to be touring around Chicago the same day, is very great in his role and fun to watch, much like Mia Sara who plays Bueller's girlfriend. Every scene these three are in is entertaining, and provide viewers with some of the most quotable lines ever delivered in a comedy, as well as beautiful imagery of downtown Chicago and a nostalgic 80s soundtrack. And then there Jeffrey Jones as Ed Rooney, the sneaky principal has nothing better on his agenda than to catch Bueller skipping school and hold him back for another senior year. He provides some good comedic relief as we watch him involved in his unexpected shenanigans that make his day a living (and funny) hell. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is classic 80s comedy that certainly holds up today and something that everyone should watch, especially the teenagers who have yet to explore the 80s era of Hollywood. This movie is easily one of the most memorable movies of its decade, and quite quotable for many. If there is a friend you know who hasn't seen this, I strongly encourage you to make this a recommendation for him or her.
I'll say it.. this movie is wildly overrated. It was good and had its funny moments but it's not some transcendent classic comedy even for it's time. It was just alright.

reviews.review_title: Never gets tired or old,kinda like the characters themselves
reviews.content: Sharp-as-a-tack high schooler Ferris Bueller(Matthew Broderick,whose long and successful career since owes itself majoritively to this role over any other)decides on this particular sunny Chicago day that he should take another "sick day" off. His reasoning is simple: he feels that going off to school like a mindless drone when there are other things he'd like to do is a complete and pitiable waste. As he so famously puts it:"Life goes by fast,and if you don't slow down,you'll miss it. So slow down."To this end,he perfects a simple yet elaborate ruse to dupe his parents into having him stay home,much to the seething envy of his sister Jeanie(Jennifer Grey,who will always be Jeanie to me,much the way she's Baby from Dirty DAncing to others)who rarely gets this kind of parental benefit of a doubt. Next,he rounds up his two best friends:dyspeptic,hyper-depressed killjoy Cameron(Alan Ruck,fantastic here!)and his pretty,quiet girl Fallon(Mia Sara,lovely),who as much become party to the ploy as Ferris himself.The three are pretty much in the clear,save the dogged suspicions of the pompous,self-righteous principal(Jeffrey Jones,practically born to play this role it seems!),who goes in pursuit of catching Ferris,whom he's been convinced has been faking it through all of the(so far)nine sick days hes taken. It goes without saying that all three,Ferris,Cameron and Fallon have all done this before,and gotten quite good at it.From there,the tour-de-force(farce?)becomes a rollicking travelogue for the city of Chicago. The fun that is culled from these experiences is nearly surreal,and the time-line that these events(German Day parade,Chicago Cubs game,Art museum,dining at a ritzy four-star)would suggest that they didn't spend too much time in one place,just enough to drink in the experience.Director and co-writer John Hughes was on a colossal roll in 1986 and after dipping into darker material in the previous year's The Breakfast Club,returned to lighter fare here and did it seamlessly. Probably one of the best elements of the movie was the breakdown of the "fourth wall",where Ferris talks to the audience,setting the tempo and giving the story a "persona" that is endearing as well as humorous. This film is a keeper,and despite the datedness of the music,clothes and hairstyles,this film is timeless in its theme and as always enjoyable.

Ferris Bueller reportedly lives life on the edge, unplanned, spontaneous, spur-of-the-moment. But what we only later see are the clever little devices he has rigged up to precisely maintain an illusion of his sickness, and how he has carefully orchestrated a day for his friend to gain some self-worth and respect so that he may stand up to his father. It is easy for a viewer to take the opposite perspective in line with the dastardly Principal Rooney. Ferris is young, good looking, popular, has the girl; the sorts of things that are easy to be jealous of. And his sister, too, is not convinced like his legions of adoring fans, and in particular, his parents. We see then, how Hughes has magnified each and every close call because of this perspective, this needy desire to expose and ruin a teenager's fun. When Katie Bueller creeps up to her son's bedroom to check on her, the soundtrack takes a shrill, horror-influenced turn and the walls turn into something out of The Shining as she slowly approaches (and note that the fake arm is clearly in view; but these caricature parents are so endearing and loving that they never once question Ferris). And then as she is relieved, she skips down the steps and the score is once again pleasant. The same technique is used as Rooney attempts to trap Ferris in his tricks, only for a two way phone call to suddenly put into harsh light all the insults he has sprayed through the speaker. Again, this loud, ominous fanfare blasts as we zoom into his shocked realisation, and his bumbling attempts to patch up the situation milked all the way from Hughes, until the humorous reveal that Cameron is now on board with the day-trip. From the loathing tone in his voice you might have thought that Ferris was an escaped murdered on death row. But what we instead see are a series of innocent little adventures through the city of Chicago that are designed to slowly peel away at Cameron's shell. As they lean their heads on the glass of the Seers Tower and survey every tiny ant with their own lives, all he can think about is the coming rage of his father. Later, he nervously teeters as Ferris bluffs his way into a high-end restaurant before assisting him yet again by mimicking a police officer. In perhaps the most iconic sequence of the movie, they visit the Art Institute, and on the backdrop of a dreamy cover of Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want (a teenager's plea, if ever), they lose themselves and descend into playtime. Hughes freely admits this as a sort of self-indulgent nostalgia binge; a place of refuge and comfort for the youth of his time. And here they pose in mock pretense, they kiss like teenagers do in the silhouette of the beautiful blue glow of Chagall's America Windows, and it's just so soft and light- hearted. And like a teenager does, Cameron seems to find meaning in a grand Seurat, and through a series of axial cuts he focuses until the details are merely splotches of indistinct paint. There's no real meaning to be found in the canvas, but there is plenty of introspection that can be found in Cameron. And in the midst of these whirlwind events, there is a little side- plot that concerns Ferris' sister, whom is constantly pushed aside. While Broderick charms and addresses the audience directly and invites them along on his day off, we see reaction shots that tell us Jeannie has been enduring this farce for so long. She got the car, but what good is it if she cannot escape school like Ferris has the ability to? So while we are swept up in his adventures, there is a quiet, modest scene completely dedicated to Jeannie, where she voices her frustrations to a stranger played by Charlie Sheen. She bemoans the fact that he is always getting away with things that she cannot, and how unfair it is; anyone with a sibling will know this feeling. And then as he makes her come to the realisation that this says more about her than it does for Ferris, she becomes this giggling schoolgirl and her facade is shattered. This is handled extremely well without attacking Ferris, but allowing Jeannie to really show who she is, and that her problems are not really that bad. Another memorable scene is the parade that seemingly erupts in the middle of the day, to be high-jacked by Ferris. It seems like something of a daydream. Where did these people come from, and how do they have the time to dedicate to an elaborate dance and song? We see everyone drop their things like it is a pre-planned flash-mob, but it is anything but. The construction workers up above join in to a rousing rendition of Twist and Shout, and even Tom Bueller dances in his office. It's just pure, clean fun. And the iconic theme of Star Wars magnifies the slow- motion frenzy of two parking attendants who take the Ferrari for a joyride, where in some other film might result in a crash and a panicked hurried attempt to patch things together before Cameron's father reaches the front door. But that doesn't happen here. It seems that most people just need to take a Ferris Bueller day once in a while.

reviews.review_title: Taking a day off with Ferris
reviews.content: Matthew Broderick's breakout role about a bright schemer who will do anything to take a day off school. When John Huges say down to write the screenplay you could tell a lot of his heart and soul went into the role from the choreography, the locations and the enchanting characters he created.Ferris and Cameron's friendship brought out the chemistry in both actors as they play fight, taunt and reveal little secrets from childhood. Mia looked stunning as the "IT" girl of the 80a who's cool, hip and the girlfriend to our lead.They are my favorite trio to ever grace the screen and play off each other making the relationships believable.The breaking of the fourth wall for Ferris to address the audience added a lot of depth to a character who would otherwise be a stereotypical slacker. I haven't been this engaged since the rocky horror picture show.Two characters who deserve recognition are Ed Rooney and Jeannie both wanting to take the lead down.
