reviews.review_title: we all wish for a day off sometimes
reviews.content: SPOILERSI'll admit from the offset that this is a film I'd bought in curiousity, but for a long time had never felt like watching. A friend of mine had seen this ages before I'd made the effort to, and he condemned it, apparently for the facts that he hates Matthew Broderick and Jennifer Grey. Whilst in films like "Godzilla", I'd happily agree that Broderick is an unoriginal, relatively irritating actor, the reasoning for this is that in another life he was obviously Ferris Bueller.In this film, we are introduced to Ferris Bueller. A popular guy around school, Bueller one day decides to take the day off and sets up an elaborate scheme to allow himself, his girlfriend (the delectable Mia Sara in one of her first roles) and his best friend Cameron (played beautifully by Alan Ruck) to travel to Chicago and to have the time of their lives. Along the way Ferris will show Cameron the "best day of his life", punish people who deserved to be tortured, and allude and torment his principle Mr Rooney (performed by the outstanding Jeffrey Jones).It's hard to really criticise this film. The plot is generally brilliant and feels almost like the "missing link" between 1980's comedy and later films like "American Pie", the directing superb, and the acting ranging from middle of the road to 100% believable. Despite these though, two things from this film spring to mind I confess.Firstly, possibly the highlight of this film is the introduction of a young actor with an amazing father who was only in acting for two years when he produced this film. That actor was Charlie Sheen, and after Matt Broderick, he must take full honours for coming out of this movie the brightest.Secondly, and most importantly of all is perhaps a minor criticism. I stand by a previous comment that it is hard to criticise this film, simply because that's the truth. The one really serious moment when Alan Ruck's Cameron is forced to face upto his past is stunning. However, the one criticism with this film is more to do with the third of the partying trio, that being the stunning Mia Sara. Now Mia was new to the world of acting when she appeared in this movie (only previously featuring as Princess Lily in "Labyrinth" the last year), but in this film at times it does feel very much that her character is more attracted to Cameron than to Bueller. I confess I don't know whether this is intentional or not, but until her last scene when she mutters to herself that she loves & is going to marry Ferris, it feels incredibly like she is going to reject him in favour of Cameron who she seems to be increasingly friendly towards. Perhaps this is just me, either way, this point does not detract from the film in any way.I guess, to summarise, often this film when viewed anytime after 1995 (I'm viewing it in 2004!) is going to appear slightly 1980s, but irrelevant of this, we are presented with the heart warming, often hilarious, story of one 17 year old who one day decides he wants a day off. Ferris Bueller, we salute you.

This film has more or less interesting story and funny moments, and you can watch it if you want to spend an evening with some comedy, but it has some drawbacks. First is Ferris being an egoistic fool sometimes. I like Matthew Broderick as an actor, but in this movie his character isn't that good. Second is that his companions are badly represented. For me both Cameron and Sloane are poorly written and played, not to mention the actors who performed them. I think this is a miscast. Cameron is an irritating character and Alan Ruck is a bad choice for this role. His story is not finished as well, and I don't know what was the point of leaving it unfinished. Charlie Sheen in his cameo looks much better. And speaking of Mia Sara, she just doesn't look like the right actress for the part of Matthew Broderick's girlfriend. He looked much better with Ally Sheedy in WarGames. They had chemistry on the screen, which is abscent in this movie with Mia. In other respects films is quite funny, especially the moments with Ed Rooney. Thus I can give this film only 7/10, it could be better.

I went to see this movie in the theatre with my sister, and we cracked up! I just loved the classic "School-Itis" scene in the beginning and the love/hate between Ferris and his sister Jeannie! She knew he was faking but he totally fooled his parents! And then he winks at Jeannie and she gives him one of her hate-filled stares (which she did all through the movie,) and her expressions were just so evocative! She was GREAT in this movie! (And I've always had a thing for JG!) Her classic lines: "I KNEW IT! OHHHHHH!" when she finds Ferris' dummy under the covers in his bed - "And if you say Ferris Bueller you lose a testicle!" to Charlie Sheen in the police station - "My name is Jeannie but guys call me Shauna" - the same "You don't have to live with the little trouser-snake!"But I have to confess that I really despise Ferris. He thinks he's so funny, but he's nothing but a selfish little boy. He doesn't give a damn about anything but his own pleasure. Just look at the way he treated Cameron. He didn't give a POOP if Cameron was really sick, or if Ed Rooney caught Cameron ditching and he got in trouble for that, or much worse for a phony phone call, or if Cameron's old man beat the s**t out of him for taking the Ferrari, or anything else - he just manipulated and shamed and bullied Cameron until he got what he wanted. Then he burned rubber out of the school parking lot, he took his hands off the wheel a lot while driving, and then he left that priceless car with those two dirt-bags! Then he under-loaded the engine trying to run the speedometer back for 150 miles (which won't work on a Smiths-Jaeger speedometer-it's made to defeat that.) And he called Cameron's Subaru "a piece of s**t." You know, Sloane could do better than Ferris. I really hated the little b@st@ard!Poor Ed Rooney! I liked Grace, though! She was funny, especially her accent. I'm from Minnesota and the Chicago accent is really quite similar, and she did it perfectly. Classic Grace lines: "Sluts, dweebs, jocks, motor-heads, they all love him. He's a Righteous Dude!" (which she pronounced 'doooooooode," which cracked me up!) "Peterson home on Line 2 - and watch your mouth this time!" "Oh, Ed! You sound just like Dirty Harry!" Ed says "Ferris Bueller's behind this, I know it! And now he's got Sloane Peterson involved in it." and she says: "And her grandmother, too." Not to mention how she put down Jeannie when she got a little smart-mouthed.And now we come to Mia Sara... smoking hot is the best way to describe her. Dude, there are all kinds of nude pictures of her on the web and I've downloaded every single one of them. Like Beavis said: "Boingoingoingoingoingoing!!!!" How could a geek like Ferris land a girlfriend like that? Only by being a consummate bull-s**tter... It really cracked me up when the school nurse walked into the classroom and Sloane starts putting on her jacket (which was really ugly, by the way) and grabbing her purse EVEN BEFORE the teacher said anything! She knew!You know, the girl's clothes in the '80s were a lot more modest than the '70s. They looked better. Now - God! It's horrible!Classic Sloane Lines: Ferris says "do you have a kiss for Daddy?" and she says "are you kidding" (TOOOUUUUNNNNGGGGE!) and Ed Rooney is standing up there, just TOTALLY FREAKED OUT! Dude, I damn near died laughing!Bloopers: Every movie has at least one. When the dirt-bags are out seriously abusing the Ferrari, the speedometer they show is NOT the real one from the actual car. Ferris' parents supposedly didn't have the money to buy him a car, but between the synthesizer, the stereo and the computer, there's about $13,000 worth of electronics in his room (Back then, a car (like Jeannie's Fiero) was only about $9,000 (in 1986 prices.)So, it's a really fun movie and it'll go down in history as a classic, but I still say Ferris is a trouser-snake . . .

It is so unnecessary for anyone to make another comment about this film, really, but here I am! This is, of course, another nearly-timeless teen classic from John Hughes in his golden era. Unfortunately, this means it suffers from the same flaw most of this period does: after about the first third of the film you can probably turn it off since you've seen the best it's going to get. Aside from Principal Ed Rooney's very funny pursuit of Bueller through the remainder of the movie, the best moments for my money occur before Ferris leaves the house! I understand this excludes the well-known 'Danke Schoen'/'Twist & Shout' parade scene, but this is an overrated one anyway. Our insights into Ferris -- as well as into the excellent portrayal of what could easily have been a thoroughly irritating spoiled brat by Broderick -- chiefly occur in the first half-hour of the film, and much after that is filler. Not that I would dissuade anyone from watching this fun movie all the way through at least once, but be prepared to make your popcorn break about the time they show up to pick up the girlfriend.

reviews.review_title: One of the finest in it's kind

reviews.review_title: The Smash Hit Teen Comedy that became a blessing and curse for its star...
reviews.content: FERRIS BUELLER'S DAY OFF was the fresh and imaginative teen comedy that followed a smart-aleck high school senior through a series of amusing adventures when he decides to skip school for the day. This comedy was a smash hit at the box office that became an instant classic and made a star out of Matthew Broderick, who is absolute perfection in the title role. Broderick lights up the screen and tackles this role with an effortless charm that is quite engaging and even appears quite comfortable during the moments when Ferris talks directly to the camera. John Hughes' inventive direction is a plus and Broderick is given sterling support from Jeffrey Jones as Ed Rooney, the principal of Ferris' school who is determined to catch Ferris ditching school, Edie McClurg as Rooney's secretary, Alan Ruck as Ferris' best friend Cameron, Jennifer Grey as Ferris' jealous older sister, and Lyman Hall and Cindy Pickett as Ferris' parents. Yes, the screenplay is a little one-sided...all the adults in the film are made to look like idiots, but if you can accept that, this comic-fantasy adventure is one entertaining roller-coaster ride. The film made a star out of Broderick but he was so good in the film that he became type-cast for years to the point where no one would even think of casting him as an adult, but if you're gonna get typecast, be thankful it was due to a classic like this one. Followed years later by a brief TV series.

reviews.review_title: One of the best comedy movies ever made
reviews.content: When John Hughes was interviewed about the reason why he made movies in the first place and he said "To prove how stupid some teenagers can really be without even realizing it." For people who haven't watched his movies his reasoning may sound strange to them, but for some who have know for a fact that he puts his proof into comedy.In Ferris Bueller's Day Off he proves it with excellence. The movie stars Matthew Broderick as Ferris Bueller a senior in high-school who is determined to act sick so that he can ditch school for a ninth consecutive time so that he can some fun with his best friend Cameron (played by Alan Ruck), and his girlfriend Sloane (played by Mia Sara) for the whole day while his parents are away from home, while Ferris is on his so called sick day his school principal Ed Rooney (played by Jeffrey Jones) is determined to get him busted for ditching school. Writer-director John Hughes has written the perfect story for a well done teen comedy, and his direction and his cast try to prove that the stupid thing that teenagers do can be very laughable. the movie also includes a very good supporting cast which includes Jennifer Grey as his sister Jeanie who gets ticked off in the beginning of the movie when she knew all along that he was going to ditch school when her parents found his performance to be very convincing as well as the other 8 times that he ditched school to take a guess, and Cindy Pickett and Lyman Ward as their parents Katie and Tom Bueller the parents as I mentioned earlier got fooled by his prank. The movie itself is a film that I consider to be a must see for all people who like movies that not only make fun of teenagers in a laughable way, and for people who like comedy movies in general.

If there was an perfect actor for a movie, it would be Matthew Broderick in Ferris Bueller's day off. All that lovable cheek, and those classic facial expressions, one when looking straight to camera, sometimes before he delivers his insightful and colorful monologues. Ferris, the professional, shows us some tips for successful faking in front of the folks. There's absolutely no way you could hate this guy, unless you were Ferris's sister (Jennifer Grey) who envies him the way he always gets out of stuff, like school, and his award winning performances of a sick kid in bed, his parents taking the bait, where he gets to bludge his way through college. He takes no chances, making sure his operation is foolproof, where all avenues of his little charade, are backed up, if anyone should pay a visit or ring the house. He has a tape equipment, with a synthesizer of sounds, coughs, vomiting, or barfing up a lung. Only the headmaster, Ed Rooney is onto his little show, out to catch him if it's the last thing he does, even if it kills him, which it almost does, on a return bus trip back to school, in tattered garb. What this movie's message is, stands true to a few of Ferris's wise words. Everybody should relax and take a break every so often like a day off work, or in Ferris case, high school, though never as many days as Ferris. Being a wagging student myself, I did relate a bit to it, only I just went on and wagged school, especially in my last year in grade eleven, where I left a week before the end of the second term. Coincidentally, I left a week before this movie hit cinema. In home class, the last two or so months, I was absent almost every day, and my parents never got a call. In fact I was wagging subjects I didn't like and I had an assortment of grades ranging from A's down to E's. And to tell you the truth, I felt much better, liberated, and defiant. How I hated biology. Ferris's best friend, Cameron, worked and stressed to the max, with a real arse...e of a father, although we never see him, is a severe example of someone who needs to decompress, I was myself concerned for him, even though he was just a character. On Ferris's latest day off, he keeps hounding Cameron, to drive over and pick him up for a city trip. Cameron's sick in in bed, though Ferris tells us, it's only in his head, which I believe too. Cameron folds, helping Ferris too in a plan of phoney voices, that involves taking Ferris's girl (Mia Sara) out of school. You'll love how this plays off. So now they have the rest of the day, and how they spend it makes it a fun filled adventure. One scene in particular, that's unforgettable, is in a museum, with Cameron relating to a painting of void, that keeps minifying, where he feels so small. Ferris brazes out, and risks all, jumping up onto a float before live t.v. and sings Twist And Shout. Another potent scene involves Gray at the police station, pouring her troubles onto, a wasted teen, who else but Charlie Sheen, who makes her see with his insightful analogy, that Ferris is not the problem. And just when you think Ferris is about to be caught out, when making like a hare, crossing numerous backyards and jumping fences, in a hasty rush to beat his parents, returning home, guess who saves the day. Highly infectious comedy cult hit of 86, that I've heard favorable mentions from people here and there. One of Hughes's best, again another one with it's share of morals.

Matthew Broderick and Alan Ruck really did deserve Oscar nominations for Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor because they did a great job in this film. It was well written and funny. This is the film to see especially if you are about to go back to school. My Score: 8.6/10

reviews.review_title: Longing for the transvestite of humor
reviews.content: "Enjoying the adoidado vida" is not a great film just for its humor, sarcasm, direction and captivating personages, what makes this great work is its moral not explicit, its philosophy on the life to be fleeting and its ramifications on the perturbation of the head by cameron. The script that tells of the acts of rebellion of Ferris Bueller is opposed to the depression of cameron, the pair, along with the girlfriend of Ferris embarks on a journey of fun, after they leave class, in search of amusement and to enjoy life, but between these intervals each one understands a little more about life and about oneself. John Hughes is a director who knows how to talk and broadcast the dramas and yearnings of youth like no one, always dressed in comedy, his films take all audiences and always preach the philosophy of total entertainment, from beginning to end (not stopping even in the credits) , but John also uses his communication skills to talk to his audience (even though the feature of the breakdown of the fourth wall is widely used here), John creates a film of three characters discovering themselves, but of an emphasis mainly on Cameron , he is the character who understands his purpose and makes the biggest break of rupture of the film, the whole movie is based on trying to enter his mind and understand his personality -Vide the scene of the pictures- he is the real protagonist of the film, and John deserves all our respect for including all this layer on the long and cover of fun and comedy. But in addition to that, the feature has a wonderful technical direction, camera angles and cuts of the film are surgical, in addition to those against flat and long plans, not to mention the richness of screen compositions and costumes, and the striking soundtrack, speaking in remarkable things, we can not forget Mattehew Broderick, who plays the role of his life, although all the actors are great in their roles. Lastly, "Enjoying the Sweet Life" is a film that transcends generations with fun, good humor and intelligence.

Some say "The Breakfast Club" is Hughes best, but I enjoy his all out comedies a little more, so this ranks at the top.  The movie is just fun, with Broderick and company galavanting about Chicago going from one misadventure to another.  Hughes does manage to get great laughs from those having not such a great day as well, such as Grey and the most memorable high school principal in a movie, the luckless Jones.  The signature scene of the film is no doubt the "Twist and Shout" parade, with Broderick lip-syncing to the Beatles hit.  You can't help but rock along to the electrifying moment.  Tack on an excellent closing five minutes, where despite the lack of dialogue, you'll be left with a huge smile as the film fades out.  Broderick is perfect as the smooth operator, Ruck likable as his hapless friend and Sara as the cutesy girlfriend.  Hughes best work is sure to please anybody here.

reviews.review_title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off — The best way to skip school and have fun in the 80s
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a teen flick by John Hughes which became a cult movie and is now a classic.Its genius lies in the direct perspective of the teen mind. It's not an exaggerated view in the sense that it is not trashy. It's just a dream day any teen would love to be able to pull off and Ferris the coolest dude everybody wants to know. Great story, well developed characters, and cool dialogs.The only negative things I can say are that I find that Matthew Broderick's acting is sometime a bit off. While it gives his performance a certain flair and a very distinctive flavor, it can be distracting at time. Mia Sara is also part of the those little negative things. She's just not top notch in this film, unlike Alan Ruck and Jeffrey Jones. She had done better.If you don't mind a trip back to the 80s, I recommend it.

Matthew Broderick plays Ferris Bueller, a very popular high school senior who decides life is too short to waste a beautiful day in the classroom. He convinces his hypochondriac friend Cameron to join him and they call the principal and impersonate the father of Ferris' girlfriend Sloane in order to get her released from school for the day. Although the plot is simple, it is wonderfully executed. To make the plot more interesting, the principal is suspicious whether or not Ferris is really sick and is so jealous of Ferris' popularity, that he is determined to prevent Ferris from graduating. Jeffrey Jones is very good as the principal along with Jennifer Grey as Ferris' angry sister Jeanie. The film score is well chosen and the fashion, haircuts, and cars bring you back to the 1980s when it was filmed. I love this movie. Matthew Broderick is extremely likable and the idea of getting away with innocent fun before we take on life's responsibilities is deeper than you realize.

Not just an 80's classic. It's an all time comedy classic that just happens to be from a decade of great moviesThis is hilarious, easily Brodericks best movie. The games between Ferris and Mr Rooney are great. All of the actors do a top job but Jeffrey Jones steals the show as Edward Rooney, hilarious.Excellent comedy.

I think we all know Ferris Bueller is more of an embodiment of the envies of high school, and his best friend Cameron whom he manipulates is the outsider looking in. And perhaps there are other deep studies that could be made about many of the characters-- including the hilarious bit-role from Charlie Sheen-- but let's face it, that's not why we watch Ferris Bueller's Day Off. However, it is worth mentioning that the profiles made of all the characters work so well in the flow of the day and the interactions that take place.For those who haven't seen this movie that's considered a classic, you will not get laughs-a-minute where you consistently give small chuckles to clever lines. And those types of movies can be great (look at Airplane! and The Lego Movie), but that's not what this is. And that's okay. Instead, you have a fleshed out adventure in one day from John Hughes that gives situation after situation where he knows exactly what he wants. The slightly off-kilter vibe separates the movie from others like it, and the result is many genuine laughs. I'm not here to say it's a classic, but it is hard to deny that there are many elements that have worked their way into classic pop references.There's a lot that happens in this single day. And when I make statement like that, that is usually a very scary thing for a comedy, for everyone knows that the longer a comedy drags on, the worse it becomes. To its credit, this film is consistent in its type of humor while creating scenes that feel fresh-- even with subsequent viewings. From the Ferrari to the parade to the baseball game, some sequences are big and some are really only for a couple of seconds. It's this combination of build-up scenes for a great laugh or clever visual gags that keep the pace going; to sum it up, it works.I won't say this is one of my favorite movies or even one that everybody has to watch, but it is something that almost everybody will enjoy. Not to mention one thing I always appreciate is that films would copy the formula (obviously with less success in most cases), a sentiment to the status of this film.If nothing else, the recreation in Deadpool is enough to put a smile on your face.Bueller...Bueller......You can find this review and dozens of others at gillipediamoviereviews.blogspot.com

reviews.review_title: One of those movies you just CAN'T hate
reviews.content: There is no way in hell anyone could hate Ferris Bueller.There are so many funny, silly, random, great moments.Matthew Broderick gives the performance of his career as Ferris Bueller, the fun-loving, school-hating, technology savvy, sneaky, smart, witty protagonist of this light-hearted story. Ferris is one of those characters you just want to see win in the end.Alan Ruck was funny as Cameron Frye, the nervous, insecure, self-loathing, self-contradicting best friend of Ferris.Mia Sara was good as Slone Peterson, Ferris's girlfriend. But she didn't contribute all that much to the plot.Jeffrey Jones was hilarious as Ed Rooney, the obsessive, evil, witty, determined principle.There were many other great small performances, like Ben Stein "Bueller...Bueller...Bueller...Bueller...".Throw in a great music score, original jokes and lots of memorable lines and scenes, you have one of the funniest movies of the 80's.9/10.

Ferris Bueller. The coolest guy in his school, possibly in Chicago. After Ferris (Matthew Broderick) determines that he should have a day off he fakes sick and calls up his odd-ball, morbid friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) to come and pick him up in his fathers Ferrari 250GT California Spyder.After a few phone calls and smart designs, Ferris and Cameron are able to get his girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara) out of school. Now it is an all out adventure through downtown Chicago: going to a baseball game, singing in a parade, faking names at a restaurant and trying to solve Cameron's state of frozenness after seeing his car has an extra 100 miles on it. All the while Broderick brings the life out of the cool guy we always wanted to be in high school. Always on Ferris' tail is his high school principal,Mr. Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) and Ferris' hateful sister, Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) out to get him.The movie is funny and deals with high school life minus the drugs and sex involved in most high school films today. Broderick surprised me after seeing his work in Glory (1989) that he was able to do a comedy like this. This is the ultimate teenager film.Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Starring: Matthew Broderick, Mia Sara, Alan Ruck, Jeffrey Jones, and Jennifer Grey.4 out of 5 Stars.

I can see why so many adore this movie, it has a lot of heart to it and doesn't take itself to seriously, I can also imagine a lot of the older audience feeling delighted to experience how it once felt to be young and careless through the crazy, wacky shenanigans of our three main characters.Beyond all of the laughs, gags and unrealistic situations the movie is shallow and weak, it just feels like the director is trying to over indulge the viewers with happiness. The movie would have had a lot more depth to it if it concentrated on Cameron, how effective would it have been if instead of just showing us Bueller's morning it also contrasted with Cameron's morning to further show the audience just how much more Cameron needs live and let go. What about a scene where Cameron confronts his dad i mean i would have taken that over Bueller's sister snogging Charlie Sheen; that was not necessary at all towards anything other than magically changing her views on Ferris;i was like "wow Charlie managed to rearrange her brain with his tongue".Movie felt like a forced smile and can someone please tell me why there was so much unnecessary cringe when Ferris's mum and dad where pampering him i mean this kids almost going to college, also the trust relationship with his parents is just so damn strange if only my parents were that easy to manipulate. So much more wrong with this movie that could have been fixed if they replaced the numerous cheap laughs with more development of Cameron; i am right in thinking this movie is based around Cameron and not Ferris? anyways this movie is a good pass time but its nothing to marvel at i know I'm gonna hurt a lot of peoples childhoods with that statement but eh...

"Life moves pretty fast!"One of my all-time favourite films and the first time I can remember learning that Chicago existed - I was in Year Eight at the time, and we watched Ferris Bueller's Day off in English, thankfully our teacher was nothing like the ones in the movie ("something -doo economics...anyone? Voodoo economics"). Now, I'm a regular visitor to the Windy City and on the long flight over from Australia, I nearly always watch it. What a brilliant advertisement for CHicago itself, with scenes at Sears Tower, Wrigley Field, the Art Institute of Chicago, Glencoe Beach on the shores of Lake Michigan, a few shots of downtown Winnetka, and the parade scenes on Dearborn Street. It's weird seeing the city before Millennium Park!It's rare that a movie is legitimately funny in every scene. John Hughes strikes again, another masterpiece. You can't help but cheer for Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick, in the role that, unfortunately for him, typecast him - he was brilliant) enjoying his ninth sick day of the semester, matching wits with Edward R. Rooney, Dean of Students, who is desperate to make an example out of Ferris and his truancy. Ferris' ingenuity is brilliant, as he gets around Chicago, trying to avoid running into his dad, impersonating the Sausage King of Chicago, and performing in a parade - which might actually be the best part of the entire film. Or maybe the "Star Wars" scene - if you know, you know. No, scratch that, the final scene where Ferris has to race home ahead of his parents is the best part.The supporting cast: Alan Ruck as Ferris' reserved best friend Cameron is great, and so is Mia Sara as Ferris' girlfriend Sloane. And how can you look past Jennifer Grey as Ferris' sister Jeannie. There's even a cameo from Charlie Sheen at the police station where Jeannie has been taken, who is 50% responsible for some of the funniest exchanges of the film, talking to Jeannie about what she is doing there. Jeannie's own battle with Rooney is fantastic.Such a good movie. Makes me laugh every single time.

reviews.review_title: A great movie for your day off
reviews.content:
While most kid's skip school to just stay home to play video games nowadays, Ferris Bueller and his iconic 'sick keyboard' set the standard for skipping school in 1986 and any movie that will try and have the same plot. 
With a setting that goes across Chicago and it's suburbs, the film takes a small group high school friends as they skip school together and go to the Windy City for the day, going to all of the famous spots across the city.
Ferris Bueller's Day Off always make me feel like I am back in a much simpler time in life, where skipping a day of classes has little to no repercussions. It made me question the possibility of doing the journey he embarked on himself (Which by the way, is not possible given the time restraints, I did a paper on it before).
This movie fits very well in the genre of comedy, as the jokes are well distributed throughout the film and has the appropriate amount of fourth-wall breaks.
Very little can be improved about the film, but if something had to be changed, it would be making it a bit longer, giving the crew the opportunity to visit more places in the city.

reviews.review_title: John Hughes should be hailed the best writer for teen comedies
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986) Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara, Jeffrey Jones, Jennifer Grey, Cindy Pickett, Lyman Ward, Eddie McClurg, Charlie Sheen, Ben Stein, Kristy Swanson, D: John Hughes. Undemanding if hilarious coming-of-age teen comedy with Broderick the title character, a rascally, cocky teenager hamming up a cold to take an absence from his education one day where him, his best friend (Ruck), and girlfriend (Sara) have a set of escapades in Chicago, where anything can happen. Still pretty popular among diehard fans of Hughes, who is a master of writing sharp teen-dialogue, generating charm, and bringing on the bundle of laughs. Grey is good as Ferris's feisty older sibling, who will see to it that he gets caught. Running Time: 103 minutes and rated PG-13 for language. ***

reviews.review_title: A Great Comedy Film That Is Really Fun To Watch When You Are Not In School(SPOILERS)
reviews.content: SPOILERSWow, that was a lousy summary. Anyway, I had a very fun time watching Ferris Bueller's Day Off. It is one of the funniest movies ever made and is well, really, funny. When I watched this I felt like ditching school the very next day. I did not, but I felt like it. This movie contains some very famous scenes, like Ferris Bueller's trip back to his house, and the parade scene, and more. I also think that this Matthew Broderick's very best film, and funniest film.Here is the plot. The title pretty much says it all. A popular teenager named Ferris Bueller takes, well, the day off from school with his friend and his girlfriend. He pretends to be sick. Amazingly, his parents do think he is sick. He puts a dummy in his room. He takes a trip into the city of Chicago. The only problem is that his principal and his sister Jeanne do not think he is sick and they both try to prove that he is faking it. By the time he does everything he could possibly do he runs home to his house. His parents never found out that he skipped school.Overall, this is an excellent teenager movie. I also loved the very end of the film when Ferris Bueller asks the audience way they are still bothering him. The movie is over. Also, this is only Ben Stein's second film. He also has a great line, "Bueller? Bueller?" Anyway, anyone that is a fan of comedy would bound to love this film. This is definitely John Hughes's best movie.9/10Recommended Films: The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles.

reviews.review_title: If my eyes were bleeding you wouldn't let me stay home from school...
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller is your typical teenage boy.  He lives in a middle-class suburban home, has a sister and lives with her and his parents. One morning Ferris seems to be "under the weather".  When his parents discover this, being the concerned set that they are, decide that it would be best if Ferris stay home for the day. When they and his sister leave the house, that's when Ferris becomes "better".With his key tips on 'faking out the parents', his crazy ways of getting his girlfriend out of school, insulting the principal and getting away with it, and getting on top of a float in a parade in the middle of Chicago singing the lead song, are just several reasons why Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of the greatest teen comedies that will remain a classic forever.Matthew Brodrick plays Ferris, while Jennifer Grey takes the part of his sister and Jeffery Jones the role of the principal, whom no one could have done a better job portraying.From the famous car, his girlfriend and best friend, his restaraunt routine, to his sister constantly being berated with signs, banners and charity collections in the hallways of her school, saying, "Save Ferris", she about loses it. Hey---wasn't there a band called that?This movie is a great watch and fun for the whole family (no really, it is). I love it, and it's a personal favorite. If you haven't seen this movie you need to, and if you have, you need to see it again!A 10 out of 10 in my opinion.  I love it!And that's my review

reviews.review_title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off - Should Not Be Skipped!
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's simplistic view of faking out his parents is void. It's a lot more difficult than that nowadays, and the only way to get out of high school legitimately is actually being sick.Matthew Broderick is Ferris, with Alan Ruck as his sidekick, Cameron Frye.An interesting story, with a good cast, a kick butt musical number, witty remarks and a whole day of fun, there is no reason for anyone of any age to not love this classic.If you find one thing to despise about this film, point it out to me because I can't find anything to not like.

reviews.review_title: A classic from the great Hughes
reviews.content: This movie is really a must see if you dig other classics of John Hughes. My first John Hughes movie was the Breakfast Club which is one of my favorites but I have to say that this on is a slight funnier. Broderick, Sara, Ruck, Grey and the rest really make this movie unforgettable with their charm and wit. You can't help but smiling through the whole movie. With a great soundtrack, cinematography, acting, script and directing it's doomed to be an iconic movie you will never forget.I am not of the generation John Hughes movies take places but we can still laugh and feel a great connection to the characters feelings and their experiences, the only thing that separates us is the hair, clothing and music that was different in my high school era. This movie is a must-watch-movie everyone has to experience at least once! It will definitely cheer you up whenever!

reviews.review_title: Absolutely fantastic comedy classic - fun, sweet, and oh so righteous
reviews.content: John Hughes' 1986 classic comedy Ferris Bueller's Day Off is irresistible. It set the benchmark for teen comedies which few have matched, with its all out fun story.The story is simple enough. Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is everybody's favorite guy. He's handsome, cool, funny, fearless, and charming to no end. He has a beautiful girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara), and a very paranoid, yet lovable best friend, Cameron (Alan Ruck). One day, Ferris wakes up and decides that he doesn't want to go to school, thinking that spending the day in downtown Chicago sounds like a better idea. So Ferris whips up a clever scheme that fools his parents, and drives to pick up Cameron and then Sloane at school. However, 2 people are not fooled: over zealous and crazed school dean Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) and Ferris's sister, Jeanie (Jennifer Grey...yes the one that dated Matthew Broderick...weird, eh?).The character Ferris Bueller is simply irresistible. Matthew Broderick brings an unprecedented amount of cool to the character that will make him one of the most lovable rebels in film history. Each of our 3 main characters compliments the other. While Ferris has his wild and crazy moments, Mia Sara's character brings out the good guy in him, as they have great on screen chemistry. Alan Ruck is also great. Cameron is the exact opposite of Ferris...paranoid, by the book, afraid of confrontation, and unwelcome to change. But that's what makes them such excellent buddies. Ferris brings out the best in Cameron and vice versa. Jeffrey Jones is great as well, and the film features a priceless cameo from Charlie Sheen that may be his on screen breakout (prior to Platoon, of course). All in all, this movie is a great example of why Broderick and Sheen are as bankable and famous as they are today.John Hughes just knows teenagers and the 1980's. The spirits of both are alive and well here. The music is 80's, as are the characters. But the mark of how great a movie it is and how classic it is is that it can be enjoyed by anyone from any generation. It's a great movie that I'd recommend to everyone. Everybody should see Ferris Bueller's Day Off, because of the wonderfully fun experience it is.10/10 --spy
Great movie still holds up well today. Cinematography top notch, acting amazing from whole cast, directing on point, casting fantastic. Couldn't ask for anything better .

SPOILERS!I see this film differently as an older adult than as a young one.  When this first came out I was still a few years out of High School, so I revered Ferris and all of his slickness and charm.  Now as I near 40 (with a grad degree in Education Administration to boot) I'm a little leary of the mischevious Mr. Bueller.  Still this is a funny movie with plenty of crafty scenes (though some of the outlandish stuff has become thin through the years).Creator John Hughes stuffed this comedy full of clever details and quirky moments.  Broderick performs well in his tounge-in-cheek role, and one of the joys of the film is his sub rosa sides with the screen audience, culminating at the very end with a reminder that it is time to go home after all the film credits have fully finished.  For all the celebration of smart-alleck youths in this movie, it is two adults who steal the show--Edie McClurg as the pixilated secratary Grace (I have watched this numerous times and I have yet to not laugh at her enumeration of all the school cliques)and Jeffery Jones as the unforgetable arch-enemy of Ferris, Principal Ed Rooney. His antics in his quest to ruin the young truant are ultimately the picture's funniest moments.One side note- When I give educational presentations I often use the Ben Stein scene (discussing Taft/Hartley-Voodoo Economics) with all the bored students (that kid drooling on his desk is classic) as an opening ice-breaker.  I juxtapose it with a scene from "Better Off Dead"--where the kids are intently listening to a recondite physics lesson.  I then ask the educators which scene reminds them more of today's kids.

reviews.review_title: Ferris Beuller's Day Off = My Day Off!
reviews.content: I originally saw this movie shortly after it was released in 1986. Being a six year old at the time, I started taking Ferris' advice on how to fake an illness to get out of going to school....I owe so much to John Hughes. From first grade through my senior year of high school...same tactics and it worked every time.The writing in this film is classic John Hughes, but this time it's the popular kid who's the focus. It also contains several things that make this movie an enjoyable watch: A classic Ferrari, a musical number (or two), an over zealous principal, and Matthew Broderick.It's a must watch, as it is, and always will be a classic.

reviews.review_title: A film as care-free as any day off.
reviews.content: Matthew Broderick plays the title character in "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," a hilarious, congenial and timeless comedy from the 80's teen-flick king John Hughes ("The Breakfast Club," "Sixteen Candles"). When one sees the words "A John Hughes Film," one expects an 80's gem, a pure classic. In the case of "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," truer words were never spoken.Despite the fact that he is nearing the end of high school, Ferris will do anything for a day off. This means enlisting the aid of his depressed best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck), his too-nice-to-be-true girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) and a mint 1961 cherry red Ferrari. Cruising through downtown Chicago, taking in a baseball game, partaking in a parade, inspiring an outlandish dance routine, strolling through an art museum and playing grown-up at a classy French restaurant, Ferris is bound and determined to live it up, partly for himself, and partly for the benefit of his troubled friend. Along the way he must match wits with his principal (Jeffrey Jones) and his bitter sister, Jeannie (Jennifer Gray).Without a doubt, this is Broderick's signature role, the one he will be remembered for. Despite the fact that his character appears mildly psychotic – throwing caution to the wind one too many times, talking to imaginary people (a.k.a. the audience) – it's a well-written one that is as likable as it is life-like. If John Hughes was known for one thing, it was creating believable teenagers on film, and Ferris' best friend Cameron is perhaps his best example. Alan Ruck nearly steals the show as the character more people can relate to, but despite his serious tone, never drags down the film and the film never feels too melodramatic for it. The rest of the cast is superb as well. Jeffrey Jones is unforgettable as the mad principal holding a grudge, and even Charlie Sheen manages to sneak it a cameo as a charming junkie.The film is sharply written, brilliantly paced and most importantly: Timeless. The idea of skipping school (or work) is a fantasy we've all indulged in at one time or another. Surprisingly, it has not dated itself too badly either. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is simply a fun film that people from all walks of life can appreciate and which generations of teenagers will relate to many, many years down the line. To put it in a sentence, they sure don't make 'em like they used to.

reviews.review_title: highly entertaining film, definitely one of the greatest teen films ever made
reviews.content: Ferris Buellers' Day Off follows three adolescent teens who decide to take the day off school. Ferris Bueller, the executor of the plan, decides to fake an illness in order to trick his parents into taking the day off. Ferris convinces his sick friend, Cameron to also take the day off and bring his fathers Ferrari. As soon as the two unite they form a plan to bail Ferris' girlfriend Sloane out of school. The principal, Ed Rooney, is aware of Ferris' rebellious manner and is hot on Ferris' tail to expose him for wagging school. Fortunately Ferris is always a step ahead of Rooney as he gallivants around the city. Ferris' sister Jeanie, jealous that Ferris is able to get away with ditching school on a regular basis, decides to catch Ferris in the act when she finds out the entire school thinks Ferris has come down with a serious illness. Ferris and his friends throughout the day manage to dine at a prestigious restaurant, attend an art gallery, view a baseball match, and sing at a street parade and other escapades in which he almost encounters his father. Cameron, Ferris' friend, is a neurotic individual who is eventually set over the top after the miles on his fathers Ferrari are raised significantly by the hoodlums in charge of taking care of it throughout the day. Eventually he is set into a catatonic state of mind before the entire car is destroyed set off by his mental angst. Cameron learns a valuable lesson in life following these incidents. Following the days events, it's eventually time to head home. Ferris' sister Jeanie learns not to stick her nose where it doesn't belong and Ed Rooney is in the end outsmarted by Ferris and Jeanie. Ferris achieves his goal of having an enjoyable and fulfilling day. Many genres of music are featured in the film, notable songs are Twist and Shout by The Beatles (lip synched by Ferris at the parade), Oh Yeah by Yellow which is played throughout the film, Star Wars is parodied with the main theme song when the men in charge of the Ferrari accelerate it into the air.Interesting camera shots include: a long shot of Ferris on the top of the float singing at the parade, a mid shot approximately 24 minutes into the film of Ferris and Cameron's feet right before they gaze upon the Ferrari, mid shots of the dull looks on the children's faces in school at the beginning of the film. Hughes took his time when editing. Edited scenes such as Jeanie triple kicking Rooney came out nicely. There is also another scene where Ferris has disguised himself and he kisses Sloane while Rooney is watching. The kiss was in fact brief and because of the editing which switches back to shots of Rooney and the kiss, it is made to appear longer then it is. Other interesting production elements are the fake 1960 Ferrari which in actual fact was worth $350,000 at the time. Insurance for the car to stand still most of the time on a movie set would cost a fortune. Instead they had three cars with fiberglass bodies using the framework of a mustang. One for the stunt was a higher powered vehicle, one which was driven by Ferris and his friends, and one which was just a shell to be driven through the window towards the end of the film. Acting is the film is outstanding at times the characters express more through actions and expressions rather than dialogue. Alan Ruck is able to project his voice in an amusing manner for one particular prank call scene which is exceptional, Mathew Broderick is fantastic in his portrayal of a confident and charismatic young teen and Mia Sara is also strong on performance. Jeffery Jones plays a convincing principal who seems to be more of a villain. Jennifer Grey accurately portrays the jealous and spiteful sister. Overall the acting is excellent and the supporting casts are great. Charlie Sheen's brief cameo appearance as a drug addict is even brilliant.My favorite part of the film would have to be where Ferris takes Sloane and Cameron to the street parade and jumps on board the float and dedicates a lip synched solo to Cameron: "a young boy who thinks he hasn't seen anything good today". Ferris gets everybody dancing in a lively performance of Twist and Shout by the Beatles, with the band. This is my favorite scene because it's quite entertaining and shows just how much Ferris is able to influence those around him. There is a choreographed scene of the crowd dancing which is also quite good. My overall opinion of the film is that it is a highly entertaining film and definitely one of the greatest teen films ever made. Overall the scenes are well put together showing us what one can accomplish in one day with the right mind. The humor in the film works on a scale of different ages which makes this one suitable for the entire family. The acting and shots are definitely strong aspects making the film a highly enjoyable one. I give this film four stars and highly recommend it to anyone who wishes to get into films of the teen genre.

In my opinion John Hughes's best movie, great non-stop action, memorable scenes, well picked actors, good acting, this movie is definitely on of the best movies from the 80's. You can definitely see where John Hughes got the ideas for Home alone, since Ed Rooney got treated the way the thieves did in home alone. :D Ferris Bueller just could pull anything off, on the other hand his friend Cameron was scared to do anything. This is a great message, sometimes it is better to risk and try, not just sit around wasting your time and being bored. The things Ferris did were a little bit too hard to pull off in real life, but the point was, that with courage and confidence you can do so much and it is really one of the most important things in life.This movie, without a doubt, is a classic, definitely one of the greatest comedies ever. Remember, sometimes it is better to take a day off school and to something fun and memorable, but only sometimes ;)

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a worthwhile movie. High school senior Ferris Bueller (Matthew Roderick) brings his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) and his girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) on a trip around Chicago when they're supposed to be in school.My main problem with that movie is the title character, Ferris. He is super popular for some reason, but he doesn't seem to care about how what he does affects other people. However, you just can't help but like him more and more as the movie progresses, probably because of Roderick's acting.What saved this movie for me was Alan Ruck as Cameron. He did a terrific job, and I never would've guessed that he was in his late 20's. I just love the way Cameron and Sloane get along; while Ferris is off singing on a parade float, they are content to stand there chatting without seeming awkward at all.This might not be the best movie in the world, but it is still quality entertainment and in my top 20 favorite movies. Just rent it and see what you think.

I've been scanning reviews for various movies on this database and I am always a little surprised that in reviews for films, that are absolute tripe, you will find the odd person that loves it and vice-versa.  This got me thinking...ah Ferris, surely everyone must love Ferris, a simply superb cheer-me-up-feel-good movie, I was wrong.orb-2, I know we're all entitled to our opinion, but surely you're taking this film too seriously.  This film was a wonderfully done satire on student life and stereotypes, it was obviously ridiculous, but that was part of the point, this film was never meant to be taken literally or seriously it's just a wonderful fantasy film.Everyone wants to be super-cool, popular and in control, not to mention driving a Ferrari and singing beetles songs to everyone, but alas the world in not that way.  This, as films should do, is make us forget real life, the recession you mention, and indulge in our fantasies.   I for one have a big smile on my face when I watch this movie and it always cheers me up every time I watch it.  I would love to see more of the same. I suspect that if more people watched movies like this the world would be a better place.

reviews.review_title: Ten stars for "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".
reviews.content: Before all the slapstick, before re-writing "Home Alone" umpteen times and before selling his soul to "Disney Pictures Inc.", John Hughes was believed to be THE scribe for teen angst. He wrote eloquently of it in "Sixteen Candles", "The Breakfast Club" and "Pretty in Pink". And with "Ferris Bueller's Day Off", he creates a person and a time in life that just about anyone who's ever been a teenager can relate to.Who hasn't known someone like Ferris Bueller? Someone who always has a plan, someone who made loafing off an art form, someone who could fall in a barrel of you-know-what and come out smelling like a rose?All he wants to do is take a day off from school and enjoy the day in Chicago - simple enough, but he must also try and convince his best friend Cameron (Ruck) and his best girl (Sara) to join him and, in the process, learn to enjoy what life has to offer.Naturally, there is a tyrannical school dean (Jones) who is determined to catch Ferris in the act of hooky and Ferris' own sister (Grey, PR-nose job) who has it in for her brother, the "trouser-snake". There are funny situations throughout the movie, and the characters are ones that grow on you, especially Ruck's worry-wart portrayal of Cameron Frye, constantly fretting about his dyslectic, cursing his father and nearly drowning in a pool, all in the name of friendship.Sara has less to do, but she plays the object of desire well, and Ferris' passion for her is understandable. At least he thinks about the right things, like what their lives would be like after high school.All the way from beginning to end, this movie is a great trip in search of fun, relaxation, not taking life too seriously and how to sing Wayne Newton songs in the middle of a parade. You want to catch vintage John Hughes and classic '80s tendon at its best? Seize this "Day"!Ten stars for "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".

if you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it" says Ferris (Matthew Broderick). Twice. A wise statement. In the pop 80's, »the decade that made as« (as advertised in National Geographic). An era, where USA was in it's heights (pop culture were exported oversees), materialism was the name of the game (Ferrari GTO, stock market, slow food restaurants), the music was dance/pop/new wave (Ziggy Ziggy Sputnik, Yello,MTV was the channel, which actually aired music videos), John Hughes made the movie in which everyone around the world could adopt. I remember, that I was in elementary school, when it was in '86 played in our cinemas and it was a huge hit back than. Everybody wanted to be Ferris, skipping school and enjoying freedom in sunny day. Seeing this movie some 25 years laterit brought a lot of memories. At first, i was a little bit skeptic, if I would be still fond of it, but after seeing it, i can only say:« Kudos to John and the cast for making this masterpiece, still watchable and enjoyable some 30 years after«. It's one of that movies, which simply makes you feel good. It hasn't got any weak parts and after watching it, you are sad that is over. As for me, a critical viewer, i rate it 9/10. (It would be 10/10, if they put Micheal J. Fox in it, instead Matthew, but i guess he was too busy with Back to the Future trilogy). Sure, one could argue, that some scenes are highly unlikely and that it hasn't got a depth in the characters (like in »Breakfast club«), but all this is forgotten, when you dive in Ferris world of a free man and watch unforgettable "Twist & Shout" scene.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of my all time favourite comedies and one of my all time favourite movies over all. John Hughes was a great and underrated comedy writer and director and this is probably his best comedy overall. But I have to admit for "best John Hughes" movie it would be tough to beat "Trains, Planes and Automobiles" which is almost as funny and also incredibly touching, with a couple of John Candy's scenes almost making me cry.In Ferris Bueller the story is a simple one of a brilliant but underachieving student scheming his way out of going to school by convincing his parents and trying to convince his principal that he is sick. A running joke is that the students at the school are incredibly worried about him as if he is at death's door, which really annoys his sister who is stuck going to school and knows that he is completely healthy.He also gets his girlfriend out of school, as well as his hypochondriac friend Cameron who has serious daddy issues which come to a head at the end of the movie. That poor poor car!Super funny and just a fun movie to spend some time on.

reviews.review_title: What's wrong with this movie? Nothing!
reviews.content: This movie pretty much set the bar for all teen movies.It's proof that you can be funny and rebellious at the same time.There are too many reasons why it's almost unsellable once you've bought it, but I'll just name my top 5.Number 5: The famous parade float dance scene... you gotta have some pretty big balls to do that.Number 4: It's a movie with a great message: (Say it with me if you know it.) "Life moves pretty fast; if you don't stop and look around, you might miss it." Number 3: It's totally quotable.Number 2: Simply put, cult films kick ass.and finally, number 1: Everyone who has a pulse and a sense of humor has seen it and loved it! If you haven't seen this, (that's rare.) do it! you'll love this movie.10/10

Great movie. Certainly not your average high-school movie fare.Ferris knows every trick in the book (hey, he wrote the book) for skipping school, pulling the wool over his parents' eyes, having his way with people...yet he doesn't just use all this for selfish ends, to have a good time. (not only that, that is...) The whole point of the excursion is to spend more time with his best friend Cameron, try to get him to shake off his terminal melancholy. Ferris connives, schemes, lies...but is in fact a good-hearted kid. You get the feeling that Ferris and, by the end of the movie, Cameron have a better grip on what's important than the people they're supposed to be learning from.I don't know whether his parents' amazing gullibility, or the fact that the kids skip school to visit an art museum, is harder to believe...but 's OK, go along for the ride anyway.

reviews.review_title: The BEST cult classic film - EVER!!!!
reviews.content: This is the best classic 80's movie out there.  Many great one-liners that will be quoted for eternity!!!  A "must see" no matter what age you are.  Hilarious!!!  John Hughes is the comedy master!!!

John Hughes, master of teen films, hit a home run with Ferris Bueller. The purpose of a teen flick is to make teenagers glad to be one and to make adults reflect back on those years of their lives fondly. This movie does just that and more. Ferris Bueller is an amazing man in an awesome movie. The journey he goes on is spectacular and hilarious. Everyone should see this fabulous movie, with great performances by all Broderick and all the supporting characters (especially Jeffrey Jones). P.S. Also check out Charlie Sheen in one of his earliest roles.

reviews.review_title: Beware of Friendships That are Sugar-Coated B.S.
reviews.content: This movie is over-rated and uneven. I'm not even sure why it works, but it does. I think Reese was cast just for eye-candy, and I think the movie should have, instead, focused on the interaction between Ferris and Cameron: What does Ferris have to offer Cameron? Is it possible that Cameron has something of value for Ferris to learn? Because of Bueller's smug attitude, even toward his best friend, the manipulation disguised as "liberation" he offers Cameron comes to a destructive, suicidal head as Cameron acknowledges the lie he is living and seeks escape from both his unfeeling father and Bueller. There are some funny moments in the movie, don't get me wrong. Broderick also has charm and stage-presence. The supporting cast is wonderful, especially the High school administration members. Jennifer Grey is a fine actress and Charlie Sheen's cameo is memorable. In Ferris Bueller's Day Off, the main character gives us a somewhat potent illustration of the lesson many of us need to un-learn: How to project an illusion. As a testament to Cameron's character, he survived the "friendship", and hopefully, there-after, demanded a new level of authenticity from his social contacts.Even with Ferris's falsity and smugness, his manipulation and shallowness, we all find ourselves rooting for him during the movie; (even at the absurd, surreal end scene where the entire city is gathered at an indescript "parade", with Bueller doing an impromptu, amplified lip-synch to a rock n roll song. Screw the fact that he might have just ruined his only friend's life: He wants to be the center of attention and adulation.

I know he's supposed to be the antagonist but I actually preferred Mr Rooney over Ferris, his only mission through the entire movie is to catch Ferris and prove that he's missing school which is totally comprehensible considering the fact that it is his job and the 9 times Ferris has gone absent, the scene when Ferris and his friends trick Rooney via phone call was actually funny but then, the movie decides it wants to be a Tom and Jerry cartoon and starts using Rooney as some sort of Slapstick punching bag, at the end, Ferris the bratty, possibly spoiled child that got his way thru the entire movie with lies wins, and Rooney, who only wanted to make it clear the deceitful character that is Ferris, losses.
One of the best comedy movies ever made. It's ageless. Still works 35 years later.

I remember when I first saw the trailer in a railroad station hallway. I was there with a friend who had just spent a year in the States as an exchange student. He'd already seen it and urged me to go . The first week of its release I saw it 4 times. Couldn't stop grinning when I came out. At times I was the only one in the cinema who 'got' the puns, jokes and one-liners. Absolute teenage-classic. I'm planning on showing it to my 12-year old son in about a years time. I will have to keep my mouth shut, though, by this time I know it by heart. Hey, batter, batter......Laine

ferris bueller is the typical american teenager who hates school and will go through all costs to have the best day ever instead of sitting in school. with his worry-wart of a best friend and a girlfriend who is carefree, they go on a day on the town while the principal is determined to prove ferris not to sick and ruin the best day ever! this movie kept me laughing and hoping that ferris doesnt get caught and his friend just keeping worrying and worrying until he goes to a literal breakdown..  but dont worry about it being one of those dud movies that rely on being crude and rude, this movie is fun for the entire family and has lots of laughs!   (B+ B)

reviews.review_title: It's Still The Best Teen Comedy Of Them All
reviews.content:
Anyone who doesn't like this movie is crazy. What's not to like? I mean, it's a classic. It's a pretty light hearted and silly comedy that is very hard not to laugh at. John Hughs is a great comedy director, and he always will be (hopefully). The story is set mainly in Chicago, so you know that strange and unusual things will happen. This movie has a lot of running and chasing and tricking other people, so I ask again, what's not to like?
Matthew Broderick is Ferris Bueller, the coolest kid in school, who just wakes up one morning and decides he doesn't want to go to school, so he convinces his overly trusting parents that he is ver sick, so they tell him to stay in bed, and they head off to work, sure it's nieve, but who cares. Ferris then drags his up tight best friend Cameron, his equally mischievous girlfriend Sloane, and Cameron's father's rare Mustang for a day on the town filled with mis-adventures and some of the strangest people in Illinois.Ferris' angry sister Jeanie is hysterical. She and the nosey Principal Rooney are both out to get Ferris and put him in his place. Rooney is a very funny character just because of all of the situations he gets himself into. I recommend this movie to anyone who goes to or has gone to school, or who likes a good comedy. Matthew Broderick is really funny as fun-loving Ferris. Just watch it, and you'll see. 9/10
Charming and lighthearted comedy that takes us through an eventful day in the life of high school's most popular slacker.

A carefree teenager decides to skip school and enjoy the day with his girlfriend and best friend. His philosophy is that life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it. He takes advantage of every chance he gets to have fun during the day while his sister and the school principal are out to expose him.Fantastic concept and brilliant execution. This movie focuses on how high schoolers feel about school and life. It shows how sometimes you gotta take it easy and relax for a bit. Life will keep moving so you gotta stop and chill once in a while. Even though I'm far past my high school phase, I really enjoyed this movie.Matthew Broderick delivered a fantastic performance as the mischievous Ferris Bueller. His dialogue delivery and expressions were on point. His reluctant best friend Cameron Frye is played by Alan Ruck who also delivered an amazing performance. The principal Rooney played by Jeffrey Jones was also great. Jennifer Grey also did good as the sister of Ferris.John Hughes did a great job. His direction is beautiful and in my opinion, this movie is easily his best work. He did a brilliant job focusing on the city Chicago and shooting the film on location.This movie is a classic 80's comedy which will bring back a lot of nostalgia. It's a beautifully made comedy film which will make you laugh every few minutes throughout the whole movie. Whether you're a teenager or a middle aged adult, this movie can be enjoyed by anyone. I'm very fortunate to have come across this movie.After watching this movie, I finally understand why this movie has become a cult classic. Makes me wish I got to take advantage of all the chances I had to have fun during high school. This movie is definitely one of my all time favourites.

I saw this movie a while ago when I was much younger, and immediately fell in love with it.  I actually can't say that I've met someone who didn't like this film(I don't ask everyone I meet, but still..).  This movie stars a young Matthew Broderick, but the real star is Ben Stein.  His performance as the Economics Teacher was masterful.  I was shocked that he didn't receive an Oscar nomination.

reviews.review_title: It's all about the Ferrari for me
reviews.content: I don't remember the first time I watched Ferris Bueller's day off. I feel old because I was alive when the movie came out in theaters. I can't remember going to a theater to watch it.So I must have first watched it when it came out on VHS.My favorite scenes are the ones involving the 1961 Ferrari 250 GT california spider.When Ferris, his girlfriend and, cameron take the car to parking garage and hand it to the attendant and the attendant takes if for a joy ride with his friend. So funny.And the scene at the end of the movie where cameron freaks out when he sees the mileage on the car. And then they decided to try and take the mileage off by running the car in reverse while its on a jack running in reverse. When the car falls off the jack when cameron puts his foot on it. That is one of my favorite moments in moviesThe rest of the movie is good but, those two scenes make Ferris Bueller's day off a must watch movie for me.
That movie representas how happy we were before cellphones arrived our lives, thats fascinating, all past time was the best

reviews.review_title: Life moves pretty fast ...so take the Ferrari that smells like a diaper!
reviews.content: Before Matthew Broderick became typecast as a lukewarm simpleton, he was the epitome of 80s cool. British flag adorned doors be damned, Broderick was the natural heir to the throne of cineAmerican teendom. James Dean was rendered irrelevant the instant a Mohawked Matthew decided to sing in the shower. I mean this is a righteous dude who can eat pancreas, contemplate modern art, make downtown Chicago sing and dance all in one irresponsible day. Moreover, he is a pioneer of deception. Ferris' technological arsenal of tricks designed to dupe adults make anything that Kevin McCallister concocted look childish.But the best thing about Ferris Bueller's Day off is not Ferris Bueller. No! It's his best friend Cameron Prye! Cameron is a depressed hockey player (formerly of the Detroit Red Wings) who quite frankly deserved a sequel or prequel based solely around his plight. He lives in a house that looks like it was sponsored entirely by Sharper Image. For those too young to know about Sharper Image... you know... just Google it. Unlike Ferris, Cameron is a depressed teenager in desperate need of a Breakfast Club to call his own. This isn't a guy who can finesse his way into a swanky restaurant or emotionally manipulate people and hope that a sly smirk or a raised eyebrow will charm them into forgetting they've been played. That's what makes Cameron so much more endearing and relatable than Ferris. You get the sense that Bueller is a character designed, whereas his friend Cameron is happlessly conceived. It's easy to imagine that he is the unforseen result of a loveless marriage where two yuppie adults convinced themselves that a child would validate their lives. Ferris on the other hand, is that disgustingly perfect combination of boyish charm, good looks and juvenile idealism.Then you've got the girlfriend, Sloan. What's the point of Sloan? I'll leave that for you to decide. Perhaps just ask yourself if the plot would be affected in any way had she been edited out. Much like Ferris, her appeal is superficial at best. Much like Ferris, she is fully-realized. She has no concerns, no fears, no challenges and she's rediculously good-looking to boot. Oh the random intricacies of youth. Unlike Ferris and Cameron though, the result is a character that is somehow bland and boring. Her qualities are sincerity and enthusiasm but does that make her interesting in the least?Interestingly, Ferris' sister Jeannie is the only character besides Cameron to have a character arch. She comes across as hopelessly angry and jaded and she would be completely justified in getting what she wants, to see her brother go down. But when the chance comes to reveal him as the con artist that he is, she opts instead to become his ally. This arch feels a little baseless, but it is nevertheless, a healthy development. She has let go of her anger in favor of a more centered approach to life where she is the focus of her own life. Of course, this is all attributed to the sage advice of Prince Sheen in all his sweaty disheveled leathery glory as he looks like a permanent fixture of the police station waiting room.Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and steal your friend's dad's Ferrari and visit an art museum once in a while, you could run the risk of being lamer than a vest with no leopard print.

I love this movie - I will ALWAYS love it - because it has about EVERYTHING I want to be happy. Matthew Broderick and Alan Ruck - especially Alan - give the best performances of their lives. And adding the beautiful Ferrari only makes it better.'Ferris Bueller's Day Off' symbolises what many teenagers would consider thé perfect day off. But of course, who can do that without getting nailed? Right, no body but Ferris. He's cute, funny and er... smart. His best friend, Cameron Frye is the opposite of Ferris. Always thinking negative, acting negative and being depressive, he makes me feel sad. But the rest is cool: seeing mr. Rooney getting chased by the Bueller's dog is cool, Ferris singing at the parade is cool and Alan Ruck's fantastic blue eyes are really cool.What touched me most is the evolution in Alan's character - you can actually see Cameron change. He realises that it is silly to be down all the time. I'm not gonna say more, check it out yourself!

reviews.review_title: Please Ferris, tell me how you do it!
reviews.content: Oh, God- if only it were that easy. I try to ditch school and the teacher phones home to ask how I'm feeling, and... well. Yes, obviously it's no cinch for Ferris to not get caught, but as we learn, Ferris Bueller never gets caught. Sure it's no sophisticated Oscar winning comedy but I'll watch it over 'Shakespeare In Love' any day. Why? It's light, it's easy, you don't have to stop and think to understand the jokes, it's one of those stupid comedies that you can't resist. One of those movies that you keep in the video drawer and watch on a rainy day... it's also a movie you don't want your kids to get ideas from.I haven't seen many of Matthew Broderick's films but from those I did, this is my favorite (I mean Godzilla, eh ok, but Inspector Gadget, in the old Jewish words of wisdom: Oy Vay). Matthew Broderick is absolutely brilliant and Alan Ruck (Cameron) and Mia Sara (Sloane) are great too. I have many favorite lines, but one of them is in the beginning where Ferris explains the rules on how to ditch school without getting caught, after he finishes explaining- he then says: "It's a little childish and stupid but then- so is school". I also liked when he said: "I asked for a car, I got a computer. How's that for being born under a bad sign?", yes Ferris- we sympathize with you. But enough quotes.Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a great movie that can be enjoyed by anybody (even teachers, well maybe I'm going a bit too far now). It's one of my top ten favorites, a must see for all kids who wanna skip school and a reminder to parents of how naive they can be some... all the time.

reviews.review_title: Absolutely surreal and unrealistic, one of the worst movie was ever made
reviews.content: How is it possible that a kid can trick so many people with so many stupid gimmicks? That what happen in this movie is out of the world, in the real life those things would be ridiculous

reviews.review_title: Am I the only person that did not like this movie?
reviews.content: I really really did not like this movie.  I found  Ferris Bueller's character way too annoying as the know-it-all under achiever that gets away with everything and drags us along for the ride.As for Mathew Broderick well, he an actor much like Kevin Costner;  which means if Broderick is to be a scientist then it is Broderick as the scientist or if he is to play Robin Hood then it is Broderick as Robin Hood.  In other words he does not become the character the character becomes him.And I am beguiled as to how destroying your father's prized sports car will prove anything???The only movie I demanded by movie back for after watching it.

I don't really care if Ferris Bueller is annoying and always gets his way. That can be for entertainment value, if you find these kinds of pranks and villains entertaining. I rewatched this film for Cameron and Jeanie, to see if I remember the treatment of their characters correctly, but it was actually worse. I think Ferris's good intentions and care towards Cameron were his only redeemable quality as a character, but the realization of these intentions of course pretty much cancels that out. The point is not the sports car, the point is that the moment where Cameron seemingly wakes up from his long sleep he actually hands over to Ferris all power to define himself. Ferris has been right all along in refusing to realize Cameron is actually deprressed. This exasperating turn is echoed in the scene where Jeanie is told by a random dude that "she's the problem" and then left fluttering and giggling as the effect of his apparently masterful kisses. This after Jeanie has been victim blamed for being very legitimately scared by an intruder in her house. Ah, this is all so tiring. I read a few analyses of Jeanie where the writer seemed to attribute some sort of underlying feminist critique to Hughes himself. No way. Jeanie was "uptight" so she deserved all that, and the cure was a random guy making out with her. Also Sloane's prediction of her own future is "he's going to marry me", like she needs no say in that. Can't get more misogynistic than this in a feel-good, anti-hero teen movie.

"Life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."Such an obvious quote. But how many of us actually take the time to take stock of things and just pause?This movie is an absolute classic and has become my favourite comedy movie. It has so many laugh-out-loud moments and everything about this movie is amazing! From the impeccable planning from Ferris to Cameron letting things go and standing up for himself, it really is a wonderful watch.Definitely a must-watch.

reviews.review_title: How can you not like it?
reviews.content: The first time I saw this classic was in my 9th grade government class. Our teacher had brought it in for us to watch during class.  I'm not sure what her rational was...perhaps she thought our senior year was far enough away that we'd forget the movie and not borrow any ideas from it.I still know people who haven't seen Ferris (they're the same ones who haven't seen the original Star Wars or Titanic as well.)  You just need to watch this cinematic staple.  You don't see it for its drama or soulful enlightenment; you see it to enjoy yourself. Jeffrey Jones, as the bumbling principal hell-bent on destroying Ferris's day off, is hysterical.  Jennifer Gray, in her pre-Dirty Dancing days is dead-on as the envious sister.  And of course Ferris and Cameron are....well, just watch it.

The perfect film. Why? Because every thing that isn't supposed to happen, happens. His parents buying his story, the ferrari getting the chop, ferris getting away with it and still having time to go home and relax just before his parents check on him. What more can I say? Ferris is not a guy... he's a lifestile, a way of living the day to the fullest, without any regards for tomorrow. Without regrets.

I like good fantasies, and this is one of the best. Watching this film I become a seventeen-year-old again, only this time I have fun. For one thing, I get to live the most perfect day of my life. Of anybody's life. Cut school with my best friend and my best girl. Visit Chicago. Drive a Ferrari. A Ferrari convertible. A classic red Ferrari convertible. Look down on the city from the top of the Sears Tower. View great works of art. Catch a home run in Wrigley Field. Eat at an elegant restaurant. Humiliate the supercilious maitre d. Humiliate the pathetic school principal. Sing "Danke Schoen" and "Twist and Shout" from a parade float while downtown Chicago falls at my feet. Win my hateful sister over to my side. All this, and my loving parents never catch on. Oh wow. I think I'll stop writing this review and go watch it again. And this time, Ferris, can we visit "Pizzeria Uno?"

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a movie that is simply excellent in all the ways a teen-comedy-movie can be.
