Sympathetic characters, good story, funny jokes that aren't too predictable, good acting and a really great soundtrack, too (I was really amazed)...the list goes on and on.I am especially fond of the way Ferris sometimes looks directly into the camera and you feel like you're really part of what's going on.To be honest, I watched it for the first time a few weeks ago and even though the movie is as old as I am, I didn't find it boring in any way and neither did I think of it as an "old" movie.To conclude: even today, after almost twenty (completely unnoticeable) years have passed, this movie is awesome!

reviews.review_title: I first saw this in a high school class
reviews.content: I first saw this movie after a test in high school (believe it or not), and this what I call a classic movie. I will admit it does get slow at times, but the Ferris Bueller character has to have almost every teen's dream come true. First he fakes being sick to stay home, then takes his friends out on a wild cruse through the city using a car he practically swipes from his friend's rich father.The only part I didn't care much for is that it gets a little slow in the middle. One part of this was the scene with his sister coming home and the principle breaking into the house. It was also rather unbelievable when he tries to take the car's mileage out running the car in reverse, and accidentally breaks it through the window. But the movie does pick up at the end, when he goes running back to his house and fools his family again, all hot and sweaty (from his run), his parents think that he is still sick with a bad fever.

reviews.review_title: A family member dies... and you insult me, what the H*** is the matter with you????
reviews.content: If you've seen Ferris Bueller Day's Off, then you should recognize the above line as one of the funnier quotes and scenes in the movie. The way principal Rooney stumbles over himself in an effort to appease Mr. Peterson (that's not really Mr. Peterson... so that's how it is in their family!) is one of the many highlights. Even 14 years after the film release, my friends and co-workers still drop lines from this movie constantly, and always get great laughs with them... "Yes... call the police, this should be a HOOT!!!", "I asked for a car, and they got me a computer... how's that for living under a bad sign?", "When Cameron was in Egypt's land... let my Cameron goooooooo!!!!"So many great scenes, lines and situations in this movie, that to tell you about them all, would take... well, it would take 90 minutes at least! So, just go rent or buy Ferris Bueller Day's Off, as I certainly can't tell them the way Hughes, Broderick, and crew do! "Would you like some life savers? They've been in my pocket all day, they're warm and soft!"

reviews.review_title: One of MY top movies ever
reviews.content: Annoyed with Ferris??? Grow tired of his egoism???  All I can say is:"it's understanding that makes people like us tolerate a person such as yourself..."I saw this movie in the theaters when I was 14 and all I wanted was to BE Ferris. As it's turned out, my friends often refer to me as "ferris" because of my extraordinary luck and timing. More quaotable lines than I can list. Actors so perfectly cast I can't imagine any others playing these roles (Edie McClurg as Rooneys secratary RULES!) and a high schoolers state of mind that will always be in style! I have seen this move probably twenty five times and still  bust up when Grace sniffs White-out and pulls pencils out of her hair! FERRIS BUELLER RULES! SEE IT - THEN SEE IT AGAIN!! "Life moves pretty fast - If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it" "I'd like to dedicate this one to my friend Cameron.."

reviews.review_title: A Movie For ALL Seniors in High School
reviews.content: Ladies & Gentlemen from the Class of ____. (put your year here.)  Watch "Ferris Bueller".  Everything you need to know about life comes from this movie! Yes, "Ferris Bueller" does contain offensive language, but I'm telling you right now...every student should watch this movie before they graduate from high school.  Record it from TV and watch the TV edit! I don't care how you watch it, just do it!!!Now that's off my chest, I can actually comment on this movie.I don't know if it's just due to Matthew Broderick's likeableness (a word I just made up) or what, but you just can't help but love Ferris.  Ferris is the guy everyone wants to be with in high.  Heck, Ferris is the guy everyone wanted to be in high school...Get away with murder, get worshipped by your entire community and know all the words to "Danke Schoen".When I think back to my teenage years, I can honestly say that this movie epidomizes the 80's more than almost any other movie. (The only exception would be "Back to the Future".)  From the music to the clothes to the hair to the Ferrari, everything about this movie is 1980's!  Even Charlie Sheen is in this movie!I know that there are a lot of actors who don't want to be remembered for one certain role, but if I were Matthew Broderick, I would definitely accept that as a compliment that people know me as Ferris Bueller.  It's the ultimate role that I would do for free if I had the chance.Now, don't think that this movie is all about Broderick.  The supporting cast did a great job of pulling their own weight.  Jeffrey Jones, Alan Ruck, Jennifer "Yummy" Grey, and of course Edie McClurg.Ferris Bueller is just one of those movies that when you finish watching it, you can't help but walk out of the TV room with a smile on your face.  It's that enjoyable!  P.S.  I know you probably already know this, but don't stop the video until the credits are all done.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is known all over as a modern classic. It's true. When we talk about modern classics, this movie has to be mentioned. Teen movies are looked down upon because most of them don't live up to this one.The actors obviously weren't taken from the cast of Dawson's Creek, they didn't dig into Beverly Hills 90210, or Party of Five. They took real actors. These actors took on some hilarious roles and delivered.The music took me back to the 80s, the decade of my birth. I am only one year older than this movie, after all. Not only that, that Ferrari kicked ass! They don't make cars like that anymore.If you hate teen movies, this will be an exception. If you love teen movies, you will soon see them as inferior to this one. Ferris Bueller, you're my hero. 10/10.

Very 80s teen comedy worthy of many a rewatch for it's simple feel-good factor philosphy and moments of slapstick hilarity.The film centers around attempts by Ferris to uplift the life of his neurotic pal Cameron. The laughs mainly come from the hapless adults especially Dean of Students Ed Rooney (flip-up shades included)who becomes ever more obsessed with catching Ferris and thus having cause to flunk him for the year.  If ever you've wanted to break free from school/lectures/work for a day, especially in the heat of summer, then this is the film for you.

reviews.review_title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off rises above all other school mischeif movies!!
reviews.content: This is a hilarious film that i can watch again and again and again!!! Matthew Broderick and Alan Ruck are a great team, and "Sloan" fits perfectly into their little world of scheme and disaster. needless to say, the plot is great, the laughs: fantastic! ANd the actors deserve and pat on the back. TWO THUMBS UP!!
Why wasn't there a sequel to this movie? It was such a funny comedy I would have thought it deserved one. This movie is great fun and really is one you could watch over and over again.

reviews.review_title: An insightful, comedic masterpiece by the great John Hughes
reviews.content: "Life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop and look around every once in a while, you could miss it." Not only is Ferris Bueller's Day Off filled with plenty of insightful messages about life in itself and frankly, how to live a much better one, it is easily John Hughes' magnum opus (although, The Breakfast Club is a close second for me) and a hilarious comedy filled with wonderful performances. It follows high school senior, Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) who decides to skip school by faking sick and his parents easily buy into it. Right from the start, the movie breaks the 4th wall and Ferris talks directly to the audience and in my opinion, it is one of the best uses of 4th wall breaking in movies. It allows the audience to get right into the head of Ferris without it feeling forced and allows Ferris to constantly make small facial gestures at the camera throughout the movie in reaction to the things happening around him. He manages to convince his depressed friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) to join him and take a spin with Cameron's father's Ferrari. They also do some nice trickery to get Ferris' girlfriend, Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) out of school to join them. They go out into the city of Chicago in which is John Hughes' love letter to the wonderful city as we see great beautiful shots of it all. Mr. Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is the principal of the school and doesn't trust Ferris in anyway, he wants to catch him and prove that he isn't the guy everyone thinks he is. Everyone loves Ferris. He breaks the clichés of high school and is the guy that everyone just adores. Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) is Ferris' sister and also wants to prove he is faking sick and how he is always managing to skip out on school. So, throughout the film, three plot lines are going on. Ferris, Cameron, and Sloane's event filled day in Chicago from lip-synching to "Twist and Shout" by The Beatles or going to a Cubs game. Mr. Rooney trying to catch Ferris. And Jeanie trying to catch Ferris as well. These three plot lines all mesh together perfectly and let the film flow so well, allowing for what is in my opinion, a perfect film. Whether Ferris is saying something extremely insightful or extremely hilarious, Broderick does an amazing job with his performance. It's truly difficult for me to find a single real flaw in this movie. This has been my 2nd viewing of this film as I write this review and it really has quite possibly jumped into my top 10 films of all time. It seems to portray the aspects of high school so well without most of the film even taking place inside of a high school. The pointlessness of much of what you are learning. The boring teachers, the childishness coming from most of the people there (which is summed up fairly well by a single line), amongst other things. If anything, John Hughes gets it. He gets teenagers. Sure, most of his films are truly a more fantasy-esque thing as most of what happens in his films would almost never happen in real life, but that doesn't change the fact that he has such an understanding. He never belittles teenagers, he treats them like real human beings and it shows in all of his films. Ferris Bueller being the best in my opinion. If anything, thank you John Hughes for just getting it. Everyone should live a more Ferris Bueller lifeand well, that's about it.

When I was a kid, I grew up with the late legend John Hughes. I watched the first two "Home Alone" movies to the point of where I had the lines memorized, and that was before I was 12. Then came "The Breakfast Club," probably one of the best movies to watch regarding high school. (My middle brother saw it first and then talked me into it, but I do not regret it to this day.) After "The Breakfast Club" came "Pretty in Pink" and "Sixteen Candles," both of which I would only watch once. When I came to be a senior in high school, I was introduced to the awesome world of Ferris Bueller. If there is one movie that you should watch before you die, it would definitely have to be this one. It is also another movie that my middle brother and I know line for line and could watch it all day without getting tired of it. That's just the power that John Hughes has to this day, even after his death. A word to the wise, though: although this movie is fantastic with a capital F, do not show it around certain junior high and high school students, for they may actually get the wrong idea. Life does not work like fiction and you will get caught, no doubt about that. Having said that, enjoy this movie over and over.
This is simply a classic that really cannot be properly articulated. It's one of those movies that survives the passage of time in my opinion because it's not tied to any particular era.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is the quintessential hi-tech fantasy of the Eighties. It is not so much about the titular kid's day off but a extollation of 80's America and all its possibilities. It's really a sequel to Broderick's previous hit (War Games) about a teenage whiz kid's use of computer and electronic technology to enable him to live his live the way he wants. It is also a magical realist musical fantasy in the vein of The Blues Brothers. (Esp. the parade sequence and the restaurant scene ) and a comedy of superiority like Beverly Hills Cop (everything to do with Rooney) where the hero defies authority in the service of his friends and makes fools of the uptight and the unimaginative. 80's movies were all about the use of technology and extreme confidence to push the boundaries of existence. To defeat those who would defy your vision, limit your self belief and prevent the ultimate possibilites of reality from unfolding. And like any good 80s movie it has a cool car.

One of the best movies from 1986. Should be in top 250. Hilarious. My 10th favorite movie. I love this movie. Very, Very funny. Best movie from 1986. Very funny. it gets a 2 thumbs way up for me. Very Hilarious, It has a lot of things that makes this great. I have always loved this movie. If you haven't seen it, you must right now. Most people have seen this. Very Very Very Very funny. MPAA Rating:PG-13. My MPAA Rating:PG-13. Well, that was my top 10. I love love love love this movie. This is a great movie. Everyone who has not seen this needs to right now. It is that good. Very funny. I heard that this guy has written a sequel titled Ferris Bueller 2: Another Day Off. If it gets made, Hopefullly it will be good. But I doubt that it will be as good as this one. Well that is all. If you want to see the other reviews of my favorite movies then click on my user name. I give this film 8 out of 10 stars.

reviews.review_title: RUNNING TIME - 102 minutes STARRING - Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck and Mia Sara CERTIFICATE - 15
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller is an incredible student, respected by all the teenagers at his typical school, excluding his sister, who despised him for his lack of care and hated how he got away with everything all the time. One day when the sun is shining, Ferris decides there is no way he'd be seen and school on a day like that. He convinces his parents that he is terrible ill and calls his best friend Cameron to drive over so they can spend the day having first-class fun. After the two of them manage to sneak Ferris' girlfriend Sloane out of school, they plan a day of pure excitement and end up in a race against time to stay out of trouble.This film is a light entertaining feature with moments of embarrassment and hilarity. I can't imagine anyone being able to crown it a 'favourite' movie as it's not particularly memorable or unique. It's important to remember that it's essential to watch films apart from those. How can you call a film unique if all you watch is those which stand out? This is not unmissable movie but it's the best of it's kind. Late night in with a couple of friends and you're all pretty tired? Watch Ferris Bueller's Day Off.

This is a totally enjoyable film. I love the humor and the silliness. The Metascore should not stand in your way. The WSJ review resulted in a 0. Too liberal for them? I believe it has held up well! Give it a try.

reviews.review_title: 'life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop and look around once in a while you could miss it'
reviews.content: definitely in my top five favourite films of all time. I'm more of a tacky film lover but i love classics as well and this definitely is a classic. I remember seeing this film when i was about ten years old and i knew it was good even back then, this was one of those first classic comedy's i really remember watching from a early age. Ferris Bueller is one of those kids who can scam is way through anything, and decides he wants a day off school. He fakes his illness to his parents, gets his woman and his best mate and go on a day to remember. But head teacher Rooney knows Buellers up to no good and goes on a hunt looking for him, but buellers too smart and Rooney ends up in the dog-house. A must see film 10/10

Along with a great soundtrack comes again, the comedic genius of Ferris Bueller. His tone and dialogue fit perfectly into his character. The humor is appealing and doesn't offend anyone (how rare, especially in the 21st century!!) although in some places (particularly nearing the end) it plateaus.Overall, a good watch for some fun chuckles.

reviews.review_title: How could you not love this movie?
reviews.content: Dear God, has it been this long? Is this movie really fifteen years old? Well, Mathew Broderick hasn't aged a day since (must be drinking the same magic sauce as Dick Clark. I think it's called embalming fluid). I decided to watch this again the other day to see if it was as good as I remembered it. It had been about ten years since I had last seen it, and you know how movies from your youth are never as good as you remembered them. Well, this one is every bit as good now as it was then. I love this movie!There are just too many good things about this movie to mention. Broderick is instantly likeable as Ferris. Makes you wish you had a buddy like him back in school, if for no other reason than to get close to his hottie of a girlfriend (Mia Sara). For some reason, I keep thinking of Alan Ruck as being the most outstanding character in this movie. He gives a very sweet performance as Cameron, Ferris' loser friend. He actually has the most performance-intensive role in this one. And what a cast! I was most looking forward to seeing Ben Stein again, and a hilarious cameo by Charlie Sheen, and they didn't disapoint. Oh, but that's not all folks, we also have Jeffrey Jones as the principle ("Rooney Eats It!"). He's great. Even better is Jennifer Grey as Ferris' sister, Shawna-Jean'. I love her attitude.John Hughes, where for art thou? Seems he's been writing a lot for the last ten years. Yikes! I took a look at his resume and it's not a pretty sight. I think the 80's was his decade. Anyway, this one is easily his greatest film. Everything just clicks. This one is easily a 10/10 stars on my scale. G'night!
The movie is good but my main problem with the movie was Ferris' character. I just couldn't stand his character. Also I feel this movie is kind of overrated.

This movie is a classic, no matter how many times I see it I always enjoy it, it's fantastic. Ferris Bueller is a kid who is determined to take a day off and show his depressed friend Cameron a good time. He talks to the audience countless times, giving us tips on how to fool the parents, with the clammy palms trick and how to fool them into letting you stay home from schoolThis movie should be placed in the educational aids section in the video store.Very smart dialoge and the acting is great, Ferris is everyones best friend, and what a friend to have.
Of course. Way before it's time. Great actors who went the extra mile.
I liked the breaking 4th wall aspect but the film got cult film notoriety for reasons unknown to me. Not the best of its time but still an enjoyable watch

An interesting and stylish take on the years of then-contemporary American teenagers, that carries con finding new audiences due to its study of individualism. It's good, but... Nostalgic for a certain age group but otherwise unremarkable Offspring.

I've seen a lot of 80s teen films (The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles, St Elmo's Fire) but this isn't one of them. I can't really understand the hype for it. I do admit, it's a pretty funny premise, but I think they could have gone a lot further with it than what they did. It's more of a kids movie than a teens movie. Ferris is unlikable, along with his sister. Matthew Brodrick's acting is still wooden (though not as bad as some of his other films). I did get a laugh out of Charlie Sheen as the druggie in the station, but most of it was a bit bland. It reminds me of Home Alone. A family movie that adults like since they saw it as a kid, and kids like it because they like anything. It's just a bland, bad egg.

That's what this movie is, from the time Ferris wakes up until the end of the film where he addresses the audience and tells them to go home, it is one big funfest. Hughes outdid himself. I especially enjoyed Allan Ruck's (of Spin City) performance in this film. Also Edie McClurg is one righteous dudette in this. Let's not forget pre Dirty Dancing Jennifer Grey and a pre-fame Charlie Sheen. Can't ever forget the star of the movie, lovable Matthew Broderick!! One great film, see it!!!!

Oh my goodness, I love this movie! I rented it so long ago, but then I saw they were playing it on the WB so I taped it. Wow am I glad I did. This movie has everything you need. Comedy, romance, poignant humor, real-life issues, and an all-star line up. Matthew Broderick is *perfect* in his role as the witty wise-guy Ferris Bueller who plays hooky and goes into the City with his girlfriend Sloane and best friend Cameron to have some fun. Along the way he faces obstacle after obstacle with pure charm and ease, even when he's chased down by his older sister Jean (played by the wonderful Jennifer Grey) and the principle, Mr. Rooney. This movie is so much fun, and is great when you watch it in large groups or at parties. A winner! I rate it 9/10!

Whenever I was in the second or third grade, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" was one of THE movies to see. I caught it on one of those cable channels a few weeks ago and was surprised how much I still enjoyed it. That's odd. Most movie favorites from early elementary school loose their charm with age; but not "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," for some unknown reason.OK, the plot: Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is a young, sly con man; think of him as the Sergeant Bilko of high school. Anyway, he decides one day to elaborately fake illness, get his best friend and girlfriend out of school, and have a day on the town.It sounds simple enough, and it was good enough back when I was younger. Still, when I was watching it a few weeks ago I actually found a hidden underlying message. Ferris is just a person trying to help his nervous, paranoid friend gain some self-respect and maybe have a little fun in the process. I know it sounds kind of corny, but there might be a lot more to this film, which may be described by some as "just another high school comedy." I don't think it is, I think it's better than that. Rated PG-13. 98 minutes. 8 out of 10.

During the 1980s, filmmaker John Hughes made a considerable, almost shocking amount of brilliant work in a short span of time. There is of course "Thriller", his music video classic with Michael Jackson performing one of the defining songs of the 80s. He also made an impressive body of work with "Sixteen Candles," "Pretty in Pink," and "The Breakfast Club." While these movies are fantastic pieces blending a perfect synthesis of contemporary accuracy and thematic timelessness, there is one movie in his career which stands out above all others: "Ferris Bueller's Day Off." First off, the plot is very impressive. The four main threads - Cameron's insecurity, our hero Ferris with Sloan at his side, Rooney's dogged quest to bust Ferris the truant, and Jeanie's seething rage at her brother's successes - weave in and out of each other almost seamlessly. While there's been a long-controversial problem with Ferris's ability to do so many things in such a short amount of time, it should be at least clear that one could conceivably do what Ferris does, given determination and a little bit of luck. And anyway, time factors are not the point. Ferris set out to have an ideal day, and because he IS Ferris Bueller, he makes it happen despite the odds.As sophisticated and well-written a plot can be, it takes the actors themselves to give flesh to the bone. The casting was so flawless that it's hard to imagine anybody BUT Matthew Broderick as Ferris. The chemistry between all of the actors is quite genuine. Alan Ruck and Broderick were friends and colleagues on Broadway before the film, and given Jeffrey Jones' later criminal record as a sex offender, he is a perfect portrayal as the unnerving, oily law enforcer. Plus, Ben Stein in his brief role as an economics teacher is absolutely hysterical.The one thing that gives the film more depth than other John Hughes films, and what makes the film so stunning, is the philosophy behind it. Last year an Australian journalist wrote a piece declaring that he learned everything there is to know in life by watching the film. I don't have the link anymore, but you should be able to Google it. It's well worth the read, and only goes to show that Hughes wanted to illustrate a larger point about life. To paraphrase Cameron, we need to take control of our own lives when and where we can. Life is just too short to be miserable, and even one day of pure, unbridled freedom can make up for 18 years of insecurity and fear."It is a BEAUTIFUL day in Chicago." Truer words are rarely spoken.

reviews.review_title: This movie has only gotten better
reviews.content: I saw this movie the weekend it came out, and I've seen it maybe a half-dozen times since, most recently with my eldest son.The movie was very good when I first saw it, but remarkably it has held up very well and even gotten better. The performances are excellent, the script is perfect, and quite a lot of this film, like other John Hughes films, has entered the culture.But beyond the comedy this is a good coming-of-age story with fine performance not just from the main stars, but from all the supporting players as well. Who can forget, for example, Charlie Sheen's marvelous cameo?

I don't believe I've heard ONE negative comment about this movie.... It's been .... what? .... 14 years or so since I saw this movie.... For some reason or other, the tape still manages to find its way into my VCR at least 3 or 4 times every year, and still I (and whoever is sitting with me) end up in fits at the same places ("I Weep For The Future" and "You Killed The Car" still crack me up ... but only if I'm watching; seeing is giggling).I guess few movies can be "timeless" and even though this is an obviously-80s movie, few parts of it won't stand the test of Time.Movies like this are a lesson to the James Camerons of the world: You DON'T need a $350-gozillion-budget to make a great movie .... just actors who CAN act and a script they can deliver without appearing contrived.Ferris Bueller .... you're EVERYONE'S hero!!! :)

I first saw this movie on 12/31/97. It's has to be one of the best comedy selections in my collection. Matthew Broderick is brilliant as Ferris. Alan Ruck plays a great part as Cameron. Ferris's girlfriend is attractive, no more than that. Jeannie is also hilarious. This is just a great movie. It has a simple plot. A high school student who wants to take the day off with his friends. One of the best parts is when Ferris gives pointers on how to fake a sickness. You start moaning and wailing and you bend over and you lick your palms. I know it sounds a bit childish and stupid, but than so is high school. LOL! Here's the plot. The movie takes place on a beautiful day,  so Ferris decides to take the day off with his best firend Cameron (Ruck) and his girlfriend Sloane. Ferris tries to fake out his parents which he always does successfully and he fakes them out again. The only four people that know that he is not really sick is Sloane, Cameron, Jeannie, and the evil Mr. Rooney. Mr. Rooney would do anything to get Ferris caught. He tries to tell his parents, but neither of them believe him. While Mr. Rooney tries to get him, Ferris and his friends take a day down to Downtown, Chicago, where to have fun and stay away from getting caught. Not to mention they take a beautiful 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California. Less than 100 were made. That's one of my dream cars.  Anyway Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a great movie and hope they never make a sequel cause it would suck and would be to predictable. This one of John Hughes best. His other one would be Home Alone. This movie gets a 10/10.

One of the essential 80s movies that you have to listen at least once a year.It is like a ritual each time I saw this film.It is so good.Everything in this flick is so cool!.It's one of those movies that have a special place in my heart.I'll never get tired of this one!10/10

reviews.review_title: rich, spoiled kids take a day off from school.
reviews.content: Ferris Beuller's Day Off is a strange film. At the time of its release, everyone loved it and praised it for its slick and original style. Having a main character talk to the camera was a pretty fresh idea for mainstream movies. This doesn't mean it never happened before. This film has been influenced strangely enough, by Jean Luc Godard's "Breathless". Who would have thought that John Hughes even paid attention to the French New Wave? Maybe he didn't and it's all just purely coincidental. What else is bizarre about this film is its dated and exaggerated use of technology. Ferris Beuller uses his computer to hack into his high school transcript and alter his attendance record. And this was 1986..? Ferris Beuller's Day Off is a funny movie and it has a very sweet side to it but the upper class atmosphere of this movie is really annoying. Ferris and his friends take a day off from school to live the high life in the city of Chicago by going to expensive restaurants, going to a Cubs game, visiting a museum and as Ferris puts it" we saw priceless works of art!" and they also sit in a booth by the Chicago stock exchange. What were they doing there? Before going home, Ferris and his friends spend an hour at someone's swimming pool and jacuzzi. All of this just wouldn't be enough without Ferris friend's car, which happens to be a Ferrari. Now there's nothing wrong with being rich and granted, this is a comedy which is not supposed to be totally realistic. But the theme of the film seems to suggest that in order to really have fun, you need to have money and spend it. These kids just cannot see through the superficial and material world they live in. At one point Ferris's sister is heard complaining to herself about Ferris. "Maybe it's not so bad. After all, I got a car and he got a computer". Ferris Beuller's Day Off is a light comedy and if there's anything to learn from the story, its that its that getting a little support from your friends goes a long way. In some ways, "Ferris Beuller's Day Off" was the 80's version of Forrest Gump. They don't exactly have the same story but both films deal with how success can be earned even if you don't play by the rules. Forrest Gump had a learning disability but he became very successful. Ferris Beuller slacked off from school but everyone thought he was sick and was rooting for him. This theme has a strong resonance with today's standard of living. Look whose running the country! And isn't it ironic that "Ferris Beuller's Day Off" uses George H. W. Bush as a reference when the boring teacher played by the conservative, Ben Stein "something o-o economics. Voodoo economics." Well I guess you could say that John Hughes is a true visionary. Every plot and detail has a purpose. That I applaud him for. As for the spoiled kids, I could care less.

reviews.review_title: It's NOT the classic you think it is!
reviews.content: What an unrealistic and irritating film.  A spoiled younger brother plays his parents for idiots (which in this case they really are!), uses his computer to hack into his highschool to change his record, talks his poor, insecure best friend into swiping his sadistic father's expensive car, steals a millionaire's identity and eats at the priciest gourmet restaurant in town (there's no such thing as a free lunch, right?), and gets away with it all in the end, just like he knew he would!This just doesn't happen in the real world.  Hacking and identity theft are crimes, and dimwitted parents usually cannot afford to buy their kids computers since the smart people have all the good jobs.  No friend of mine would leave me in the mess Ferris left Cameron in.  The highschool principal is a heavy, I agree, but no girl can kick a principal in the face and not get herself and her parents into trouble (even if the principal breaks into her house, which you never hear about).  The principal's obstinate secretary would be fired on the spot for aiding and abetting a hacker.  I never heard of a parade going on during a school day, and parking valets just don't get away with abusing cars.  And wasn't there a RECESSION going on in 1986?This flick gives a bad name to brothers, boyfriends, computer users and students.  Many a sister or girlfriend has accused some poor guy of being a "freeloading Ferris".  And smart-aleck know-it-alls are never regared as "righteous dudes" by every other kid.  Besides getting on your nerves, it is also missing the comedic tension that makes good comedy work: Ferris Bueller can't lose, but if he could he would seem human and his antics would be truly funny.  This movie is not for all tastes, but if you like pancreas...

Often times, you forget about movies, until they're on TV again. I just saw it Sunday night on Comedy Central and it brought back memories of watching this film when I was younger. I always thought about taking my dad's 69 Chevelle out for a spin with a few friends when we should be in school, but living on a farm, he would notice if someone left with it in the middle of the day with his car. It's just a great anytime anyplace flick that's fun to watch.
Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a great 80's classic it has comedy, and charm! One question how did it get a PG-13?  It should be R because it has strong language, and some Adult Contact.

Having been a product of the 80s I never understood the infatuation with this movie. Sure, there are some funny parts. Most of them involve the school secretary, the sister and the principle. The rest is complete boredom and stupidity.

reviews.review_title: A classic for any good storyteller.
reviews.content: A little over a decade and a half ago a legend that would revolutionize movie making forever was created. Even today, you might just hear people referring to "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" as being one of the best movies that came out of the 80's. Or, on the other hand, you might hear how it's one of the best things that came out of the 80's overall! Complete with a great environment, interesting twists, and a perfect trio main cast, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" blows all the other teen movies out of the water to date; and even those that aren't teen movies. It's hard to believe that Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck and Mia Sara are actually acting in this movie. The movie shows yesterday's youth with solid and focused soul. One of which is totally accurate. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is a movie which any person with good taste would have in their collection.

reviews.review_title: This movie is way too overrated..
reviews.content:
I obviously had my impressions too high when seeing this movie. From what I read about it, it seemed like it would be a revolution, but I ended up being very disappointed. This movie did not mean as much to me as the other 80's teen flicks did. I found it dragged on: 103 minutes seemed like three hours. My attention could not keep up with the television screen.It did have its share of laughs, and its share of lame trash trash as well, like all teen movies. I can't see why so many people would faint if Ferris Bueller walked by.This movie is nowhere near as meaningful to me as John Hughes' other 80's movies (Pretty in Pink, The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles). However, it does not stink. It's just, well, average. 50%.
My rating: **1/2 (out of 5 *'s)

reviews.review_title: Fun Movie, Nice Light Entertainment, nice message.
reviews.content: I half-watched this movie a long time ago, probably when it was first shown on TV -I thought it was just another silly show and so I really didn't sit down with my kids and pay attention to it. This time, I watched it by myself and found that it was a fun movie, was funny and had a good message hidden in the funny stuff. Matthew Broderick was so cute! and fresh. He did a great job of acting innocent for his not-to-bright parents. Jennifer Grey (Dirty Dancing's "Baby Houseman) was great as Ferris' younger sister who was determined to prove that Ferris was up to no-good. Jeffry Jones as Mr. Rooney the principal and Edie McClug as Grace, Mr. Rooney's secretary, were hilarious and actually made the show with their characters. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is nice light entertainment with a message that life moves very fast and every once in a while we should all stop and "smell the roses" or take a Day Off like Ferris'!

To start off I think this film was great in visuals and I really enjoyed the moments where Ferris is talking to the camera because it seems he is also teaching the audience how to live spontaneously like himself.However, I did not like the pace of the film, if Ferris really was skipping school then there would be a sense of danger throughout the film, whether it was prominent or not. With a faster pace it would have kept me more involved and believed that the events are truly real. John Hughes failed to address this.It feels weird that Cameron developed more than Ferris. Ferris teaches Cameron how to live his life more enjoyably and eventually Cameron succeeds in feeling this way. He decides to take matters into his own hands rather than running away from them. Ferris is a smart-ass throughout the whole film and in the end he only learns that he should be more careful when he goes out and about.Another thing that bothered me is that we barely know anything about Sloane. We know she is Ferris' girlfriend but other than that I don't feel she has any other use in the film.Overall this film was not very good but it had a great theme attached. Live your life the best you can.

reviews.review_title: This movie is the template for my life
reviews.content: There are no errors in this movie. Sheer perfection.

The eighties had some dreadful stuff, and some truly brilliant works.  This is one of the latter.  The first time I saw it, I didn't think much of it, but when I saw it for the second time, I loved it. I got slightly caught up in the `Save Ferris' hype, even though I saw it when it was 11 years old.  Nonetheless, it's timeless.  The hairdos and clothes don't appear that dated, and it's still enjoyable for all. If you love a good comedy, check this one out. Now.

reviews.review_title: I Would Def Rewatch This On My Day Off
reviews.content: Such a fun, light-hearted movie that I can watch no matter what my mood is. This movie easily became one of my comfort movies and even 30+ years later, the movie still translate well. Minus two stars because I was genuinely worried about Charlie Sheen being an odd shade of purple.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of those movies that sticks in your mind for a long time. I first watched this movie back in 2002 when I was 17 so I guess at the time I could relate to the characters in the script who were based on a similar age to me. I enjoyed this so much that I watched it over and over and then 9 years later I stumbled across it again, you don't realisze when your a teenager how important things are and how good some memories are, but once you get older you begin to appreciate life and realize how much fun you had watching this. All the characters play good roles in the movie, Matthew Broderick really does a good job as the lead role Ferris.To sum it up, 9 years down the road and this movie is still definitely enjoyable but not as much as when I was a teen, however if you are a teenager then this is a great film to watch especially with a bunch of friends.

"Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is one of the defining teen movies of the 1980's. It has stood the test of time and is still popular even today.  It is easy to see why.  Matthew Broderick gives one of his best on-screen performances in the title role. I can't imagine anyone else playing the part.  Alan Rucjk is great as his friend Cameron.  Jeffrey Jones really shines as Mr. Mooney, the school's principal.  One highlight in the film is the performance of Jennifer Grey, in her first stand out role.  She steals almost every scene she is in.  Her second best performance to date after "Dirty Dancing", in my opinion.  She is underrated and terrific here.  Overall Grade: B+

(For you people who are wondering, the first is Back to the Future and the second is Raiders of the Lost Ark).I have a poster over my bed from Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Its a poster of Ferris laying back with his feet up and in big letters over top, it says "Leisure Rules." There is not a school day that goes by without me debating with myself, after looking at the poster, weather or not I should lick my palms.This is one of the best movies you will ever see because it indulges in a teenage fantasy: beating your parents, beating the school, and overall just beating the system to have fun when you aren't supposed to. "Just think, if we played by the rules right now, we'd be in gym." That sums up the movie pretty much. Ferris has a great amount of magic in him: his presence is magnetic. Watching Ferris and Cameron trick Mr. Rooney into releasing Sloane is hilairious. I always wished I could pull something like that. I used to want to be Ferris and do everything he does, but I think now I realize that it is just a fantasy, and the audience will identify more with Cameron ("Ferris can handle anything. I can't handle a thing."). But it is still great fun to indulge in the fantasy every once in a while.Everything about this movie is memorable and is treasured, even though now i tend to skip the scene in Cameron's garage. Only Ferris could beat the waiter at his own game, turn a typical parade into a block party, turn off his stereo with a baseball and get home in time to be sick in bed, gaining sympathy for his parents.THis movie rules and I haven't met anyone who can honsetly admit they didn't like it. Buy yourself a copy today and on your next REAL sick day, take a trip into Chicago in a Ferrari with Ferris Bueller and see if you don't feel better.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a must-see for any teenager. This film attracts more teens to see it and like it because of it's teenager content. Ferris Bueller (Matthew Brocerick) decides to have a little fun around town by faking that he has a cold to his parents and not going to school. This has a lot of fun parts in it and many risks that Bueller takes.

This movie, along with a handful of others of a similar genre, falls into a category of the movies that bring back memories of high school. As someone who grew up in the 80's, these movies speak to my younger self, evoking memories of good times with friends, and simpler time in life.Ferris Bueller is one of those people who seems to just have things always go his way. No matter what sort of shenanigans he gets into, his friends, acquaintances, family, and teachers all think he hung the moon - all but 2 people that is - Mr. Rooney, his principal, and Jeanie, his sister.When Ferris decides to fake being sick toward the end of his senior year, dragging his best friend and girlfriend into skipping school and heading out for a day of adventure, Rooney knows something's up, but can't prove it. He makes it his mission to catch Ferris in the act, and will do whatever it takes to expose his escapades.But Ferris seems to always be one step ahead of him, and as the day wears on, and Ferris and co have lots of near misses, Rooney keeps coming up short.The movie is filmed in Chicago and includes some iconic landmarks and events. One of my favorites is the parade where Ferris does an impromptu (via lip-sinking) version of "Twist and Shout" up on a float. The filming of this, and other parts of the movie, has been written about, and is actually a really interesting read if you ever get the chance. They way they filmed movies back then could never happen today.Anyway, If you've never seen Ferris Bueller, all I can say is...Bueller? Bueller? Bueller? Where have you been? It's a feel-good movie, and one that I nearly have memorized from seeing it so many times - it's that good.

It took me 35 years to see this the second time. I was 19 when I saw it the first time here in Sweden and at that time back in the 80s most teenagers loved it, including myself. I'm now 55 years old and decided took watch it again but being afraid it would alter my history. Though it wasn't close to how I remembered it the value now lies in pure nostalgia in the music, clothes and just the happy atmosphere. It's a great way of getting the vibe back of those happy and easy going times of the 80s. If you were a teenager in the mid 80s you'll know what I'm talking about. Cheers.

This has to be one of the greatest teen comedies of the 80's and possibly of all time.  These unknown actors at the time did a wonderful job of bringing out the characters. I still quote Ferris to this day.80/100

reviews.review_title: Ferris isn't exactly a good role model...
reviews.content: Why do I say that?  Well, because basically Ferris makes his living by lying, scamming, and taking advantage of others.  Now, given the character of some of our recently-retired political leaders, while that might qualify one to hold high office, I'm not sure its a good character trait for ordinary folks.That said, this isn't a bad movie.  It's a kind of blend of high school hijinks and teenage angst, the former supplied by Ferris and the latter by his friend Cameron.  The viewer is taken for a dizzying ride through Ferris' "day off" school (playing hookey) courtesy of Cameron's father's sports car. Its kind of fun to watch the various tight spots and scrapes Ferris manages to get himself into and then extricated from, again mostly by lying and conniving.  But, in spite of knowing better, you find yourself pulling for Ferris, who is basically a decent person but a bit full of himself.The movie is more a vehicle for showing off the beguiling charm of the young Matthrew Brodderick, who is fine in his leading role.  Actor Jeffrey Jones is his foil as the uptight school principal.  And Mia Sara does what she does best:  portray a beautiful young woman, this time as Ferris' girlfriend (naturally, the charming rogues get the best-looking girls, which I am convinced is really the type of guy girls want in spite of what today's women say about wanting an intelligent and "sensitive" man).  But the best roles are those of Alan Ruck (Cameron) and, as others have noted, Jennifer Grey (Jeanie).So give "Ferris" a look if you need a little time for relaxation and distraction, and maybe a chance to live vicariously the kind of "day off" we all wish we could have had at least once in our lives.

The epitome of cool, Ferris Bueller is the kid everyone knows/wanted to be in high school.  The film centers on a day when he and his girlfriend and best friend ditch school.  Zany, hilarious, slapstick adventures ensue. Many ridiculous things happen but you go with the flow cause ya really do like Ferris.Plus this film has a lot of things most films don't: BEN STEIN!  He is the coolest person alive!A.J.

This movie is pretty good. It's funny and has a good plot. It was good acting and a good script. I think everyone should see this movie. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a classic and everyone will like it (mainly teens, but thats just my opinion). Check it out! I give it an 8.5/ 10

reviews.review_title: One Mans Struggle To Take It Easy
reviews.content: In 1985 I saw this film on a plane. An after that it became part of my life. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is not just a film, but its an instruction manual for a teenager to real life, guiding them to become a success. Its true, FBDO is a film that can build confidence, cure depression and make you realize that everyday of your life should be filled with as much fun, learning and excitement as you possibly can, and in many cases not even spend a penny. Successful people in the world are those who are confident, speak clearly and know how to plan and have great time management. Ferris Buellers Day off will be the cheapest MBA you could ever pay for, and perhaps be just as good. Trust me I have one from Oxford. Since 1985, 20 years later, I have seen FBDO 109 times, and know the dialogue by heart and even the entire cast including the extras. And I could put it on right now and watch it again. By 1996, with the scope of the Internet, it was only then I realized that I was not alone. Millions of people where Ferris fans and the film had a strong cult following. A TV serial was made, but without the originals charm, its popularity died. Matthew Broderick played Ferris Bueller as if he was born for the part. His on screen presence portrayed true charisma and charm. Broderick has never played a role more perfect since. 20 years on the film still does not look dated, in spite of DOS operated computers and the use of payphones (no mobiles / cell phones invented then) as John Hughes used classic cars and posh surrounding that fit in well even in the year 2005 and beyond. Save Ferris!!

In the 1986 film, "Farris Bueller's Day Off", one determined teenager pushes every limit to the max, with his sites set on the goal of having the day off from his own form of prison, high school. Farris is the ultimate wise guy. He outsmarts everyone who may potentially get in his way of skipping school. And, while doing so, creates many laughs for the audience along the way. This film incorporates great acting along with an entertaining plot that makes for a great comedy, just maybe not one for all ages. It seems as though every character was hand picked to perfectly fill their part. Matthew Broderick has the complete package for his role as the main character, Farris Bueller. His performance captures the essence of the crazy, free-spirited teenager who just wants to live life to the fullest. Starring alongside Broderick is Alan Ruck, or better known as Ferris's best friend, Cameron Frye. Ruck's drone voice and tense facial expressions mimic the characteristics of the up-tight personality his character is supposed to represent. Together the two actor's juxtaposition and spectacular performances make for a hilarious comedy of pranks and lies. Though the film will produce many laughs, my hope would be that those laughs are produced only from the mouths of those 14 and up. The plot is centered around lies that snowball throughout the storyline. At first it's one little lie, and then one more, until it seems as though it is the only dialogue being used. Younger children may process the message of this film to be finding it acceptable behavior to skip school, lie to their parents and authority figures, and steal a car with ultimately no consequences. But, these over-the-top lies and inflated situations are what make for such an amusing plot. With that being said, the film is rated PG-13 mostly for its language. Swear words flow loosely from the lips of some of the young characters. But, then again, the dialogue is part of what makes the movie so funny. The smarta** kids, the monotone teacher, and the naïve parents are all needed to add cohesion to the piece. Director John Hughes seems to stay in his line of fire with this movie, filming the different perspectives of life viewed from the rebellious, love stricken teenagers, as he does in his other timeless films, "The Breakfast Club" (1985) and "Sixteen Candles" (1984). Though Hughes doesn't incorporate any flashy special effects or amazing scenery in the film, it isn't needed. It allows the audience to focus on, and enjoy, the classic story of the young man who fakes sick to skip school and, in turn, makes the best out of his "free" day. If you are looking for a good laugh from a classic movie, it should be a must see on your list.

An absolutely overrated movie with many plotholes. I recon the high rating comes from nostalgic fans who watched it back in the 80's when it came out. I could manage myself to give it a 6.0, but only because I was still entertained. It's not all bad, but not very good either. A mediocre but yet entertaining comedy.

reviews.review_title: So great and not dated a bit!
reviews.content: Oh my gosh!!!! What a movie!!!This movie is so excellent.  It is the apex of virtually everything: the careers of Matthew Broderick and Jennifer Grey (although she was good in Dirty Dancing the next year), the apex of John Hughes' career and not to mention the apex of teen comedies.  They just don't make 'em like this anymore.  Show me a hundred Jennifer Love Hewitt films and I promise you that none of them will match or even come close to the greatness this film possesses.From beginning to end, it's a non stop ride through a teenager's day as he decides to play hooky from school.  And unlike many of today's teen "comedies" it isn't superficial; Ferris has more in mind than skipping.  He wants to help his best friend gain some confidence, although it is really the audience that feels the best in the end.This is the ultimate feel-good movie and is one that never gets old!  It is very funny and heart-warming!! 12/10

One of the Greatest movie ever made. Probably one of the Funniest ever made. i also think that Mathew Brodrick and Alan Ruck did a great job in this movie. Plus with that valet guy who steals the car was great. i give this movie 10 out of 10 stars. I highly recommend it to everyone who hasn't seen it.

reviews.review_title: Amazing, funny, and full of heart. 80's classic.
reviews.content: I don't know why this is my favorite movie but it is. Yes, I mean favorite movie of all time. What does this movie do that others don't? Not much. But it gives you that warm-fuzzy feeling John Hughes movies usually do. The dialogue is witty and funny and Ferris's view of life is uplifting. This movie has so many quotes and is incredibly charming. I'll end this quick review with some words from Bueller himself. "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."

There isn't much I can really say about this movie, but I love it. It has to be one of my all time favorites, it's really funny. I thought Alan Ruck was great as the wussy friend of Matthew Broderick. Overall a great movie to watch over and over again. 9/10.

I know that the fact that I'm writing this review is contradictory to my summary, because it says that the movie is a  classic. Period. But if you've seen the movie, I'm sure you'll agree with me that that is just not enough to say about the one-and-only, unremakable, funny, just-for-fun and, like I said before, classic, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off." This is a high school movie with girls and dating and referances to nudity and many curses, but just in case you're wondering, it's far from the 1982 classic "Fast Times at Ridgemont High." There are no drugs and nothing really along the lines of sex like in that movie. This is also a classic, but it deals with a totally different aspect of high school. The point of the movie, the main plot, whatever, is ditching school. It is about how the very cool, slick, popular Ferris Beuller makes a hobby (technically, not literally) out of ditching. To add to the funniness, the producers add in Ferris's best friend Cameron Fry, played by Alan Ruck. Cameron's parents run their household "like a museum. It's cold, very beautiful, and you're not allowed to touch anything."-Ferris Beuller. It's funny how slick Ferris tries to manage and convince Cameron, who is very law abident, into ditching with him. The ultimate is when Ferris insists on taking Cameron's father's Ferrari out to Chicago. Wait to see what happens there. Another funny part, probably the funniest of the funny parts and the real plot of the movie, is how Ed Rooney tries to nail Ferris for ditching, and how he fails at everything he tries to do. If you are in high school, or even in  middle school, you are sure to love this movie. If you haven't seen it, make sure you do.

Ferris Bueller is probably the worst friend, brother, and certainly the most popular kid in the state of Chicago. From the very opening image of the film he exhibits the pretty boy, handed- everything-on-a-silver-platter attitude you'd see from the bustiest blond in your own high school. But as much as you can try to hate him, everyone else loves him. I probably wouldn't have been in Ferris's entourage if we went to high school together, but I'd likely revel at the chance to hang out and try to steal Mia Sara from him (probably to no avail). The choice of name (Ferris, as in Ferris wheel) is symbolic of this arcade-like world of Chicago, where everything plays under Ferris's rules (like carnival or casino odds). Ferris even takes over the conventions of the cinema world by breaking the fourth wall. He kinda breaks bro-code too in the film's most emotional driven side-story. The most entertaining side-story is the Tom & Jerry chase between Ferris and the principal. Mr. Rooney is everyone's imagination running wild, while sitting and being "justly" punished in the principal's office. We feel their punishments are cruel and sometimes unique to us, and we all dream that someday we can have our own German Shepherd give them hell. Contrary to traditional Hollywood film and storytelling, Ferris Bueller faces little to no drama on his day-off. He does every fun thing under the sun- till dinner time, so no booze and strippers, high school remember- with the apotheosis of high school sweetheart, Sloane Peterson, and a friend willing to lend his daddy's Ferrari because, why would Ferris need a car? Their youth is beautifully captured on this day through Prank calls, visits to Art Museums, Wrigley's Field, and promises to get married. The ambiguity of their "I love you" confessions brought me back to the innocence of my high school days. Jeanie Bueller, Bueller's sister, is the moral figure in the story. She's smarter than everyone else and can see through Bueller's b/s. Actually, Jeanie is "us", the viewer, looking in with the "normal-world" goggles. But the one person who can expose Ferris's 9th absence (because we know Tom usually never gets Jerry) being his sister makes for a clean resolution that even though we may think, here's a guy who got away with everything and learned nothing, we expect Ferris Bueller won't be skipping school anymore. 8/10

John Hughes (The Breakfast Club) writes and directs this 80's cult comedy with Matthew Broderick in the title role of Ferris Bueller.One of the most energetic, fun and entertaining movies I have ever seen. Matthew Broderick is perfect as cheeky Ferris Bueller, Alan Ruck is brilliant in the role of Cameron Frye who is always ill and worried. Even Charlie Sheen pops up as a teenager on drugs (he likes to stay in character long after filming is done). Ferris Buellers Day Off is one of the funniest most entertaining films I have ever seen and never at any point while watching was I bored. This is one of my favourite movies and definitely in my Top 50. I recommend Ferris Buellers Day Off to everyone. The highlight of the film is the parade scene where Ferris creates the first flash mob.Ferris Buellers Day Off - 8.9/10 and ****.

Viewing this film now (2000), you can see that it has dated a bit on the surface, with the early MTV, Cabaret Volitaire posters and the ancient computers.  However its theme of not letting the world pass you by still rings true, and it's still great entertainment. Also, Charlie Sheen's drugged up character is, apart from Platoon, the best thing he's done in his career (and certainly the funniest).

I was 15 when this movie was released, and it was my very favorite movie for a couple of years after that. In my senior year of high school, a friend and I decided that, like Ferris, we needed a day off.Of course, our day off was a huge disappointment compared to Mr. Bueller's. Which is in some ways instructive; the movie basically tells you to live for today, don't wait for tomorrow. But it's a fantasy. Living for today, in real life, spells disaster as often as not. I still wish I could be as cool and confident as Ferris Bueller, but I think there is some physical law against that many coolness particles occupying any one person's body. Oh well.It's really just light, frothy fun, in retrospect. The highlight may well be watching Ferris's friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) react in his super-pessimist way to Ferris's infuriatingly just-do-it nature  a classic performance.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a Cult classic that I watched since I was 5. This Movie has an excellent Story, Cast, Screenplay, and Directing. This Is Matthew Broderick's Best Movie in my Opinion. This Movie is hilarious with Comments and Scenes that are funny. The Movie Is about a Teenager who lies to his parents that he is sick and they believe him and he gets his girlfriend Sloane Peterson and his nervous negative Friend Cameron Frye to have a day off with him until his High School Principal Ed Rooney played by Jeffrey Jones who was later in Beetlejuice chases Ferris through Chicago to his house. Movies to recommend for after you have seen the movie. The Breakfast Club, The Goonies, Sixteen Candles, Meatballs and Dazed and Confused.

reviews.review_title: Not because it's the best thing on celluloid...
reviews.content: But because it's one the the most entertaining movies of the 80's. Just have fun and be sucked in. Marvelous interaction of characters and even Jennifer Beals (PNJ - pre nose job) is entertaining.I gave it a 10 for simply the fun.

Let's just put it this way. If an alien crash landed on my front lawn, and if he wanted to know about the 80's perchance; I'd recommend it watch this movie. This movie has style! It's a primer for 80's music, 80's fashion, and 80's education. I could never get enough of this movie as a kid. It is absolutely hilarious. This is definitely one of John Hughes' more perfect and offbeat comedies. Not only was Ferris Bueller cool in his own high school, but if he were real he'd have a statue made out of him in Chicago. One of the funniest things about this movie is how much of a mythological status Bueller has in his own high school. People talk about how uncool the 80's were. That's not true, and this movie proves it.
This classic film is just pure fun. Broderick just owns this role and his addresses to the camera are hilarious and memorable.

reviews.review_title: When Cameron was in Egypt's land...
reviews.content: This is my favorite movie. There are better films, yes, and there are more popular films...perhaps. But Ferris Bueller has always been on the top of my list. This movie succeeds on so many different levels: a teen comedy, a satire, a social commentary, even a promotional film for the city of Chicago. I've seen it a few dozen times and every time I notice things in a whole different way.The movie, on the surface, is of course the account of how an impossibly carefree senior named Ferris Bueller decides to skip a day of school and take his girl and his best friend out on the town, while setting clever traps and ruses to foil his clueless parents, his nosy sister and even nosier dean. Even on this level the movie is fantastic. But to me, and probably to many others, the movie is not really about Ferris skipping school and having fun. It's really about Ferris skipping school and trying to get his depressed buddy, Cameron Frye, to have fun and learn to have confidence in himself. Cameron is probably the character most people identify with; uptight, unsure of himself, afraid to stand up to his parents. Everyone has part of Cameron inside them at some point in their lives. No one is ever really Ferris. Ferris is the unblemished perfect soul that the Camerons of the world have to put up with: he gets away with everything, has perfect grades, perfect family, perfect girl, and he's always happy. The great thing about Ferris is, he knows all of that, and he's taking this day off to make it up to Cameron.The film has great characters (very few films capture the true nature of high school like this one; Ben Stein was born for this role), and even better directing: I love the camera work; the quick, rapid establishing shots are priceless. Even the story is excellent; it's sharp and intelligent (though Ferris sure seems to fit quite a lot of activity into one day). I sincerely doubt there's anyone who wouldn't like this movie. It's just great.

This has to be one of my favorite comedies of all time.  While there are really very few laugh out loud hilarious moments in this movie it is still great.  (possible spoilers)  Ferris is the most popular Senior in school who decides to take the day off.  He semi-bullies his best friend Cameron into joining him and then breaks his girlfriend out of school.  They spend the rest of the day eating at fine restaurants, going to a Cubs game, visiting an Art gallery, and generally a lot of things you wouldn't expect the average teen to do on a day of skipped school.  Despite their somewhat dry sounding itinerary, Ferris and company still have lots of fun and do take time to do some wild and crazy things.  The principal Mr. Rooney is hilarious at his horribly inept attempts to catch Ferris.  All in all a wonderfully fun movie and one of the best films of the 80's.
"Gentlemen, you can't fight in here! This is the war room!"

reviews.review_title: I would not be able to recommend this movie highly enough.
reviews.content:
This is a truly wonderful film from the 1980s that brings back fond memories for me and it just becomes even more wonderful every time that I view it. I would consider `Ferris Bueller's Day Off' to be one of the classic movies of the 1980s and probably one of the most profoundly entertaining, enjoyable, hilarious and poignant movies of all time. This movie has everything in it to make it a success a wonderful storyline, a strong script, a wonderfully talented array of highly qualified main actors and supporting cast and naturally flowing dialogue. If some of the producers of today could learn from movies of the 1980s, this world would be a much better place.
Matthew Broderick delivers high quality, first class and believable acting to his role as Ferris Bueller. Portraying Ferris Bueller seems to be a strong point for him and I would consider it as a defining moment in his acting career. He gives Bueller's character a lot of depth and personality that tends to be missing from the vast majority of movies. Alan Ruck and Mia Sara also provide wonderful portrayals of Ferris's friends Cameron and Sloane. Jeffrey Jones is priceless in his excellent portrayal of constantly beleaguered headmaster Ed Rooney and Jennifer Grey shines as Ferris's disgruntled sister Jeannie Bueller. Even the supporting cast such as Ferris's parents down to school attendant Florence Sparrow down to the garage mechanic who `looks after' the car-give wonderful performances that make the film even more wonderful than it already is.The storyline is entertaining, enjoyable and gripping enough to keep you hanging on to the end. It's portrayal of youth, innocence and having a good time is truly a class act. The dialogue is witty, catchy and contains some priceless one liners that are still popular catchphrases today. It had me laughing hysterically even watching it for the tenth time. Everything down to the music and scenery works for this movie.My advice would be to go and see it. You won't regret it and will come away with a warm, nostalgic, feel good and wonderful feeling. They don't make movies this good anymore

A must have for any DVD collection! It's great stuff and a lot more fun than nowadays 'comedys'My personal experience with Ferris Bueller: about 20 years ago, I used to be like 10 years old, my brother had a copy on VHS. I must've watched it between 15 to 20 times and never got bored with it.On the forum I see suggestions for a remake, but this movie doesn't need a remake. The original still stands tough as a rock. My favourite moment: when Ferris'sister and mr. Rooney meet in the house. This had had me rolling over the floor. Go look on the internet for a copy. If you're unfamilliar with it, look up a preview on the tube or something.

Based on the average IMDB rating, I was expecting a hilarious comedy. I found this film to be mostly a succession of bland, childish humor. Even for the time, it is slow and there is little development in the characters. The film tries to convince us that Ferris is a likable guy, but I began to find him increasingly irritating. The events the principal experiences are just poorly executed slapstick. And there is a questionable moral: enjoying life is more important than going to school.Don't get me wrong: I can imagine people finding this a fun movie, especially if you first saw it in your teens. But I'm surprised that so many people gave it a 10 out of 10. There are so many films from the same era that are much better.

I was in high school when this came out so I appreciated it more than most. Love the plot, love the characters and love the writing. There is no bad part to this movie and even the song & dance scene has you laughing. The only real fault is that you must not keep track of time. That had to be one of the longest school days of all time. I don't know about you but an MLB game would take nearly 80% of my high school day.

This movie is ssssoooooo cool!  If you haven't seen it, you need to. Especially if you are rebellious.  Ferris, his best bud, and his chick go out on a day off from school.  And all whole time they are dodging parents, siblings, and mean-a** principals, while driving around the big city.  My favorite part is when Ferris is lip-syncing on the float.  A must see.

It's every kid's fantasy that they can skip a day of school, have a ton of fun, not get caught, and hey, while we're at it, screw over the principal and get lots of people to think that you're deathly ill! Matthew Broderick is absolutely adorable as Ferris, and Jennifer Grey is hilarious as the understandably bitter younger sister. Though this movie is first and foremost a madcap comedy, there are some cute, sentimental (but not mushy) moments between Ferris and his girlfriend Sloane and his best friend Cameron. And of course, the best scene is hands down, when Ferris lipsynches to the Beatles' "Twist and Shout." This movie should be required viewing for all high school seniors everywhere!

After being told that at my age I should have seen this film, i felt very disappointed that I had never even heard of it. So I decided to watch and I am really grateful that I was told about this film. I enjoyed this a lot and the laughs I had were a joy.Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck and Mia Sara compliment this film very well and add so much energy and enthusiasm into the story line. The acting is superb and the facial expression are timed to perfection.A must watch for anyone, and I mean anyone. This film is perfect in so many ways and I can not compliment it enough.Go watch now!! I beg you to!! My Rating 11/10

This musically-inspired film is probably one of the funniest and cleverest shows I have ever seen. When I was in high school, I probably would never have gotten away with it, but then again, very few people are as clever as Ferris Bueller. Matthew Broderich in his prime, young years where he was attractive and charming, stole the hearts of young girls who saw this film. And the whole Wayne Newton Dancle Shane thing was HILARIOUS.

reviews.review_title: Take your day off , to watch this masterpiece!
reviews.content: Highschool "kid",Matthew Broderick, tries to skip a school day by pretending he is ill.What follows is fun fun fun!Excellent comedy that does not let you down or gets boring! Very nice acting by all the cast and a beautifully written script along with all the puns! Plus Mia Sara ,as the girl every movie needs.Just sit back and enjoy the ride !!! I promise you it will lead only in fun places!P.S. Another proof that Matthew Broderick can act.P.S.#2 I would go back in time for Mia Sara.P.S.#3 Don't skip this movie if you want the definition of real comedy :D

My god! Where to start! Matthew Broderick is EXCELLENT in this movie! His boyish good looks and charm have perfectly set him in the role for Ferris! Faking an illness to hang out with friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) and Sloane (Mia Sara) is geneous! Though I wouldn't recommend doing it! Sight-seeing and pretending and parent-dodging, oh my! The parade and Ferris singing 'Twist and Shout' is awesome! The close call with Ferris's dad in the taxi, edge-of-your-seat comedy! I'm younger than this movie is and I LOVE it! I'd love to Sloane and have Ferris as a boyfriend and do that. SO FUN!!

reviews.review_title: THE BEST JOHN HUGHES MOVIE EVER!
reviews.content: I don't understand what has gotten into John Hughes. The man responsible for such definitive and great teen films such as this one and PRETTY IN PINK, and THE BREAKFAST CLUB is still possessed by the HOME ALONE formula. I mean after HOME ALONE hit it big, he made HOME ALONE 2: LOST IN NEW YORK which was the same slapstick formula but set against the background of NEW YORK, DENNIS THE MENACE the same slapstick formula set against the background of a Hank Ketcham comic strip, BABY's DAY OUT the same slapstick formula only with a BABY!!! 101 DALMATIONS, the same slapstick formula only this time with Glenn Close and a bunch of dogs tagged on, FLUBBER the same slapstick formula only this time it has Robin Williams to make funny faces and green snot. The list goes on. Back in the 80's, John Hughes was an icon. He truly complemented the teenage experience with his terrific movies with Molly Ringwald and Anthony Michael Hall. But his greatest movie is FERRIS BUELLER'S DAY OFF! This is the movie everyone remembers to the fullest and can fully quote scenes. Its just such a feel good teen movie, unlike the crap we see today with Jennifer Love Hewitt. Matthew Broderick is awesome and charismatic as the title character. He gives us inspiration to take things easy and not treat life too seriously. I loved Jeffrey Jones' portrayal of Mr.Rooney. The scenes with him in it are pure comic gold. He's perfect as the evil principal who'd do anything to see Ferris fail. Jennifer Grey is terrific as the sister who hates Ferris' existence because he gets away with everything. She's hilarious. She should have never got that nose job. There are so many memorable scenes in this movie. John Hughes knows how to direct. I liked the scene that focused on the faces of the students in the classroom as they hear a boring lecture from none other than Ben Stein. I liked the riotously scenes with Mr.Rooney and his assistant Grace. The parade sequence where Ferris Bueller lip syncs is a classic. I rewind that part at least 15 times every time I see it. And I love the dance those people do on the steps. MY FAVORITE SCENE OF ALL TIME IN THAT MOVIE: the kicking scene. Every Ferris Bueller fan should know what I'm talking about. It's just so hilarious and the perfect comic timing is so there. It's just hysterical. FERRIS BUELLER is a movie that defined our generation and I'll never forget it. Thank you John Hughes for such a great movie Quit the Disney movie remakes do something GREAT like you used to.

Directed by John Hughes. One of my favourite childhood directors. It got released in 1986. Its been 32 years. So you haven't seen before then have to time travel pretty much back to be in a mindset to watch this. And from that point of view, this movie has some incredible new things. I am surprised by the usage of voice over narration technique in those time. I came to know about this movie through deadpool credit scenes. I have to accept that I had different expection than what movie offered. It was a little let down. I liked the message of the movie that "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it." Its funny that how time passed quickly and its been 32 years since movie got releasedd. But I feel that this movie failed to deliver this idea clearly. I felt sometimes, the movie is heading no where and kind of not meaningful. Hey still its from 80's what more you can expect. Coming to the postive things, it explained how the schools were making students dumb and not being very much useful. I liked how bueller know his existence in the movie and his interaction with the audience. Thats simply brilliant. And he kind of guy where everyone knows him and care him. Ofcourse everyone would have crossed this kind people in our school days. So for me it is kind of interesting to know the teenage culture of US in 80's. Coming to cast, everyone did a great job. Maththew, Alan, Mia, Jennifer and Jefferey quite made a impression. The screenplay was sloppy sometimes. The movie has mixed pace. But make you sit through the whole.My rating:
(Each worth a point)1 - Story (main theme)
2 - Cast(Acting) 
3 - Screenplay
4 - Emotion
5 - Cinematography
6 - Impression
7 - Characterization
8 - Dialogues
9 - Sound
10 - EditingStory, Screenplay(Voice over narration nailed it), Cast(Acting), Cinematography, Dialogues -> Checked5/10 
Verdict: One time watchable.

What is there left to say about this movie,I mean really its an essential 1980's classic and yes it has its flaws every film does no matter how much praise some uptight critic gives it,It has the that's a lot of fish guy (Broderick) as Feris and trust me this role is far superior to the travesty that is Godzilla (2000) and its the basic plot of a teen fakes being sick so they can take the day off but it goes too far when other events occur and so on but overall a good film worth checking out its definitely a nostalgia trip for me to be entirely honest with you ill watch this twice in a row (its that nostalgic for me) but really 8/10 it has its flaws but overall a good film that I think any and everyone should see

Broderick banked off that boyish charm that made him so popular on the Broadway stage (Brighton Beach Memoirs) and brought it to this witty laugh ride about a high schooler who one day, just didn't want to go to school and puts himself and his friends in constant mayhem and jeopardy. Broderick is perfect, but it is Jeffrey Jones who gives a searing comic potryal of Ed Rooney, a Mr. Weatherbee-like principal wanting to catch Ferris in only act of treachery; holding him back for one more year of high school. John Hughes is at his best here. The dialogue for this film has received such a following that it has even been printed on shirts and recited at parties by true fans of the film. I don't blame them. It's a classic!

reviews.review_title: it would be nice if they didn't use so much profanities...
reviews.content: I thought this movie was hysterically funny, but I do wish that the characters didn't use so much profanity. Ironically this wasn't the first movie that I ever saw Matthew Broderick in, but instead "Faerie Tale Theatre" was the first project that I ever saw Matthew Broderick's face in.
