Everything about this movie is great, except of course all the profanity. I thought the scene where Ferris, Sloane, and Cameron were at the restaurant was too funny.  Abe Frohman?  Who would have a name like that?  Especially a seventeen year old. It's too bad Matthew Broderick was typecast for a long time after this since he looks so young for his age.  He's almost forty now, and he definitely does not look it! Overall I thought this movie was funny.

The plot is very simple. A high school senior takes a day off from school and uses plenty of tricks to cover it up from his parents. This is possibly the best comedy of all time. The reason for this is that not only does this film make you laugh until your throat hurts but it is very smart and has a heart. It is smarter than most oscar winning movies. This film can make your life better if you listen to its main message. I will not spoil the message for you but pay carefull attention to its script because it is absolutely brilliant.

Danke Shon, Merci Beaucoup, Muchoes Gracais, no matter now you say it, you gotta give John Hughes credit for this one, picking the perfect cast, screenwriter, and all-around atmosphere for the movie. Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick is a devishly-handsome young man who decides to play hookey one day to enjoy all the sights of Chicago bringing his best friend (Alan Ruck) and his girlfried (Mia Sara). Together, they go through the lessons of love and milage loss. Perfect movie.

reviews.review_title: This will be one of your favourite films, plain & simple!!
reviews.content: From start to finish this film was utterly amazing. There may not be lots of action, but contrary to belief a great film does not need to be full of action. The simplicity of this film is it's genius, Ferris is a rule breaker. But he is certainly a very likeable character & along with the growth of his best friend during the film Cameron. The relationship between these characters & the constant chase from the head teacher Rooney, give this film a real depth. I can guarantee this film will bring a smile to anyone's face. No matter what mood you may be in, this is a film that will always lighten your mood. It is one of those films that everyone needs to make sure they see at least once in there life.

Do all of this and get away with it?  Skip school with the most implausible of illnesses.  Hack in and adjust your attendance records.  Con your faithful, but weak-willed friend into driving you in his father's Ferrari. Collect your Girl (sxhwing-bada-bada) from school. Have a great day in the city. Sing to the entire north american continent. Humiliate the school Principal. Have everyone in the world wish you well. I want to be this guy. So will you.

reviews.review_title: Broderick is still Ferris, that's how good this is
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is so 1980s, so John Hughes and so important amongst the coming of age genre that every time I see Matthew Broderick I think of Ferris Bueller and every time I see Alan Ruck, I get "when Cameron lived in Egypt's land..." stuck in my head for the remainder of the day. Both actors are wonderfully drenched in those characters because of this movie's impact.I was way too young to see this in 1986, but my friend had a copy of his older sister's and, when we discovered it, the tape (yes tape) nearly got worn out. This would have been 10 years after it's theatrical release and, even though this movie is the 1980s personified, it felt new, exciting and relevant when we watched it as 13 year old kids in 1996.It's impact on pop culture and big musical numbers in films is still felt today and don't we wish a film as strong as this would come around more often?

I believe this movie to be very entertaining and for pure enjoyment.The thrill of escaping your regular boring high-school and venturing off into the busy streets of downtown Chicago compiles together one hilarious film. Meanwhile, Ferris and his gang try to do everything there is to do in Chicago while evading the constant interruptions of his annoying principal who tries to catch Ferris skipping school. The movie also consists of well done chemistry between Ferris and his girlfriend Sloan. Tagging along with the two is Ferris's best friend, Cameron. Despite Cameron's constant worrying of being caught, the gang lets loose in 2 extremely entertaining hours. It isn't an Oscar winner by any means however it was made to be a box-office hit, not a drama. In all, it is an extremely entertaining, funny, and enjoyable film (directed towards ages 11-25).

In terms of events, a day off for just about anyone is a welcome break - an oasis of freedom in this mad-cap world.  As Ferris puts it: "Life moves fast - if you don't stop to look around, you might just miss it."  And this is where "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" succeeds. The premise is simple: Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) decides to skip school and heads for downtown Chicago.  With girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) and Cameron (Alan Ruck)in tow, the trio travel to art galleries, restaurants and even view a carnival.  But Principal Ed Rooney is in pursuit of evidence to prove Bueller has been skipping class and therefore can hold him back a year. Hence follows a collection of superb slap-stick incidents and other visual and dialogue gags.  This is a top class, feel good movie.  Watch it with a smile from ear to ear.

I have loved this since I first saw it in 1987.  A hilarious story of a high school senior who goes through drastic measures just to have one relaxing day off.  It is one of those types of slapstick comedies in which the scenes are so incredibly stupid, you cannot help but laugh at them.  Excellent performances by all of the cast, especially Jeffrey Jones who portrays Rooney, the "evil" dean who has spent four years trying to destroy Ferris (and who really needs to get a LIFE!!!).  All in all, a true comedy gem which should be considered a classic for years to come.
I know I could look back at this movie and find plenty wrong with it, but for what it is, it's pretty good. An essential 80's film.

Ferris Bueller's Day off is by far the greatest movie of all time. I loved watching it as a teen and I love watching it as an adult. Every time I watch the movie my wife has to make sure that I stay at work the next day (ha,ha).From time to time i find myself quoting Buellerisms such as, "You killed the car" , "Where's your brain?" , "I did not achieve this position in life by having some snot-nosed punk leave my cheese out in the wind." and my all time favorite "You guys got nothing to worry about, I'm a professional." All I can say is thanks to this movie I was able to stop and look around once in a while and not get caught doing it.

reviews.review_title: This movie actually has Depth! Ain't Ferris Cool Too!
reviews.content: I saw this movie originally in the theatre way back in 1986.  I even remember my friend saying, " one for Ferris Booger's day off " and this made me laugh hysterically.  This obviously demonstrates my young age when I saw this movie back then.  Now when I watch Ferris Bueller's Day Off, now much older, it gains a timeless quality as I still love it just as much, or more than I did originally in 1986.  I strongly believe it is one of John Hughe's finest films.  Ferris Bueller's character (Matthew Broderick) demonstrates a heroic quality, with his charm, cunning and zest for life.  He displays a confidence that many of us could only dream of.  His friend Cameron on the other hand is the anti-thesis to Ferris' high strung personality, as this character is contrastedly low spirited and worrisome about life and his possible future after high school.  And this is the beauty of the movie, Ferris allows Cameron to finally bust out of his nervous shell and take hold of the reins of life. The plot is simple, Ferris a high school student is pretending to be home sick with the flu so he can enjoy a kick ass day o' fun.  His parents buy into his ploy but Ferris must do a little tampering with his attendance record (to avoid being caught by the nasty Mr. Rooney, Dean of Students played by Jeffrey Jones) by hacking into the school computer.  He is successful and notifies his good friend Cameron (Alan Ruck) of his plan to have an incredible day in the city of Chicago.  Cameron is wallowing in his own self pity and this situates his character symbolically as an everyman who we can all relate to, he is a person who is scared of life and would rather hide than face the bitterness of reality.  Therefore it is Ferris' job to aid Cameron in his voyage towards self realization.  And you thought Ferris Bueller's Day Off had no depth, think again!  But first they must rescue Ferris' hottie girl friend Sloan (Mia Sara) from the drudgery of her high school English class so they can escape to the city.  The fun begins once the trio take off to the city and many hilarious and wonderful scenes take place.  One particularly excellent scene takes place in the art gallery where Cameron is galvanized by one particular painting.  He cannot take his eyes off this painting and this scene strongly signifies his transformation towards self realization.Mr. Rooney is continually on a quest to defile the academic career of Ferris Bueller in his hilarious performance.  He remains the huge obstacle that stands in the way of our hero's enjoyment of a kick ass day 'o fun in the city. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a fascinating romp of hilarity with true moments of tenderness to keep every viewer happy.   Look for a young Jennifer Grey (from " Dirty Dancing " fame), she is fabulous in this movie as Ferris' despising sister Jeanie, all she wants is for her brother to be ruined in this whimsical tale of spiritual renewal.I give this movie *** out of 5 stars!  A very good film.

reviews.review_title: This film will change your life.......
reviews.content: This is a brilliant, politically incorrect teen comedy, written with blazing originality and off-beat irreverence. Told in a stylistically slick narrative that surprises and enlightens, with characters that are portrayed with staggering comedic timing and sometimes shocking depth. This will remain the pinnacle of John Hughes' career. Though considered such an '80s classic, the movie is extremely timeless, even though now-a-days, the actions the students commit in the film would probably get them thrown in jail. Students today will find much to identify with in the always-fresh and touching "unknown future" themes. But the most identifiable element in the film is the farcically bureaucratic characters. In other words, there will always be Ed Rooneys roaming the hallways in this modern educational environment. And as long as it stays that way, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" will remain one of the most entertaining, satirical, and accessible comedies around. 10/10

reviews.review_title: A great movie and a guilty pleasure.
reviews.content: The guilty pleasures continue with this 1986 classic starring Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, and Mia Sara. the story follows a carefree and amazingly lucky high school student named Ferris Bueller (Broderick) as he attempts to give his girlfriend Sloane (Sara) and best friend Cameron (Ruck) the best day ever. To do so he has to get himself and his girlfriend out of school and get Cameron out of bed. From there on its one adventure after another as they head to Chicago in Cameron's father's pristine Ferrari. The trio is out for some fun but they have the principal and Ferris's sister hot on their heels. In the end they'll have the best day ever or get caught trying.This is one of my favorite movies ever. The story line is fun and full of great moments. Jeffrey Jones does a great job playing the principal who always seems to be one step behind Ferris. Additionally Jennifer Grey is amazing as Ferris's sister who can't accept the fact that her brother gets away with so much.The cast is wonderfully put together in a film written and directed by the late great John Hughes. Hughes is responsible for some of the best remembered films of my generation some of which include Home Alone, The Breakfast Club, The Great Outdoors and Mr. Mom. This film has some of those great signature moments that define some of Hughes films. Hughes also makes great use of music in creating one of the most memorable scenes of the film.I would suggest this film to anyone and everyone. If you haven't seen it I would hope you might take the time.Remember this: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it." – Ferris Bueller I give this a 3.7 out of 5 stars. (Remember that this is a guilty pleasure and one of my favorite films.)

This is an example of an all-around great comedy.  It is subtle, understated comedy for the most part, but the dialog really shines, except where it is not needed.  I.e., the entire ending of this movie is a classic; almost no dialog, and nonstop laughs.  9 out of 10 .

reviews.review_title: Suburbia comes to the big city
reviews.content: It seems that my childhood was filled with a bunch of movies with the same plot: suburban teens come to the big city to find adventure.  Of course Hollywood does everything in multiples so this is no surprise.  The two other movies I remember with this theme are Adventures in Babysitting and The Night Before (Keanu Reeves in I think the most bizarre prom-night movies ever made.)Ferris Bueller is perhaps the only one of these three that actually works. The conflicts are engaging, the action shots are funny, and one actually gets a chance to care about the characters.  Of course this film is also a big nostalgia kick for me.

This movie was simply comic work of genius. Unlike alot of corny teenage "Let's skip school" movies, Ferris Beuller's Day Off isn't full of Velveeta. And even though this movie was made in the 1980's I know that Ferris would still be the most popular boy in school at the present time!
I remember renting this movie for the first time when I was 8 years old. Well my parents rented it rather, and they almost peed themselves from laughing. I of course thought that it was funny but wasnt able to appreciate the subtle comic quirks that it possessed. The thing that I love the most about this movie was the random humor. Though Hugh's had alot of humor in Sixteen Candles, the humor was more bubblegum than anything else. Ferris' humor is a little more edgy and sarcastic...call it quirky if you will but shows for a more mature sense of humor.Things like Ben Stein as the history teacher announcing someone's name over and over until they acknowledged their presence for the attendance that day. "Bueller, Bueller, Bueller". Or how Ferris made a floppy disk of sick/vomiting noises that he would play over the phone to his friends at school. Even the "Save Ferris" posted on the Water Tower was a riot. It was the little things that made this film so great. Along with a great cast, this film is going to remain a real 1980's cult classic!

reviews.review_title: One of my all time favourite movies.
reviews.content: When this movie came out, I was just finishing high school myself. It was every high school guy's fantasy. Grown men want to be like James Bond, high school guys want to be like Ferris Bueller. He's cool, smart, and in control in every situation. One of the best movie characters ever created.The movie itself was brilliant. There's not a real strong plot, but like Seinfeld, the story is about the characters, their interaction, and the circumstances they find themselves in.This movie really did a great job of bringing together a lot of cool stuff. Maybe not all firsts, but the first time all these things were integrated and accomplished so well. For example, including the audience. Talking to the camera, documentary like sidebars with overlay texts, etc.The directing and cinematography were also excellent and the soundtrack was brilliantly matched to the content. For example the shot of the Ferrari jumping over the railroad tracks in slow-motion to the StarWars theme was brilliant. Also this is first movie I remember to make use of the cool sounds of the band "Yello" in it's sound-track. After FB made such brilliant use of Yello, many movies and TV shows started using them. Especially the cool track "oh yeah" (You know, shhhe-bow bow, cha chigga) See http://www.yello.ch/ to hear what I mean.There's just so many brilliant scenes in this movie, it's as near a 10 as I could vote. If IMDb allowed decimal voting, which I think they should, I'd give it a 9.8.Matthew Broderick is one of the great unsung actors of our time. He's amazing. I just saw him in "The Producers" and am reminded again how good he is. He's a throwback from the days of _real_ entertainers. When they could not only act, but they could do everything. Act, sing, dance, etc.Alan Ruck also put in a memorable performance as Cameron. I loved the "he'll keep calling me" and "Sloan's dad" scenes especially.Jennifer Grey also was great as "Shauna" and her scenes with Charlie Sheen in his cameo were a nice contrast to her angry sister performance.I love the quirky parents performances by Cindy Pickett and Lyman Ward. I really love when Tom Bueller is listening to the parade, and when he's behind the old lady in the car.Well, anyway, if you haven't seen this, you don't deserve access to IMDb as you are a movie infidel. This is a must see classic.One of the most entertaining movies ever made, especially if you ever went to high-school.

I'm 30 and this is the first time I've seen this flick. I have no nostalgia whatsoever, though I think I have seen parts of the movie some time before when I was a kid.FBDO has such a huge status even today (the running scene in Spider-man: Homecoming is proof of this) and I thought I was going to be way, waaaaay more entertained by this movie. The film has a lot of charm and it is a well made movie that uses lots of music and scores to its advantage as well as having lots of well-filmed scenes etc.Part of the humor comes from how unrealistic Bueller's tricks and plans are and the insane amount of effort it must go into to pull certain technological stunts off (e.g. all the tapes) - wouldn't it been easier to just go to school? The message of the movie that we all should take a day off and experience life is also a very nice one and deserves to be lived out once in a while (though in FBDO comes from a place of privilegie and the rich main characters shouldn't have much to complain about...)But honestly, at least 60% of the movie is boring. So many of the "good jokes" (the ones from the Ferris/Sloane/Cameron-parts) didn't make me laugh or even smile. Then the movie has a lot of pure garbage-scenes involving the principal that tries to get back at Bueller but is forced to endure some incredibly boring and unoriginal slapstick. The scenes with Jeannie aren't that great either, which is too bad because the first scenes we see her in she seems like a real funny, badass character, a perfect contrast to Ferris - but no, there is not much payoff with that character at all.The sidestory with Cameron didn't resonate with me at all. When Cameron decides to confront his dad instead of being angry at Ferris it comes more off like the script is giving Ferris an easy way out. Though I like the multiple personality theory that some fans have (but it doesn't work because two people are calling the principal in the beginning...)Anyway, I can admit that hype probably plays some part in my disappointment with this movie. But if a movie is this hyped up and it doesn't deliver, then I think it deserves to be taken down a notch. 4/10

wellll, ok, maybe it's NOT the "best movie ever made," but it IS my favorite movie of all time.  I've seen it a billion times, I can recite the movie out loud, and I'm still laughing at everything I laughed at the first time I saw it.  It's the perfect laugh-fest movie, and definitely the best movie that came out the 1980's. What's NOT to love about "Ferris Bueller's Day Off"?

I remember seeing this movie at home...being I was 6 yrs old when it came out. We taped it from the tv...eventually bought the VHS and worn it out...lol. Even my parents loved this movie...and my dad into his 70s would watch it and still laugh. I am watching it on right now as I type this...and have to point out...it far surpasses todays garbage. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of those perfectly put together stories.  The dialogue is hilarious!  I can recite most of the movie.  The casting is perfect.  Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara as the three friends who take the day off and have fun in Chicago.  And Charlie Sheen has a small part in the movie, but he's the funniest character in it.  If you hate school, and who doesn't, you'll love this movie

I'm sure by now you've heard of this wildly popular John Hughes film. Yeah, you know the one. The one with the teenagers who do a bunch of funny teenager things that every other teen wishes they were doing. Oh, you don't know the one I'm talking about? That's because he's made movies with this plot more times than teenage-you actually did any of these things. But guess what? He did it again with Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986).
I've seen many a teen movie in my lifetime, so by now I've seen plenty of these plot-lines belly flop harder than my chubby Mexican cousin. This time around it's Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick), the popular class clown type, and his partners in crime. He easily gets his girlfriend, Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara), to go along with his latest scheme, but his best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) is a different story. He is informed by Ferris that they will be taking his father's prized possession: a 1961 Ferrari 250 GT. Ferris easily convinced his clueless parents he was on the brink of death to stay home "sick" from school, but not his younger sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey). Along with her being out to get him, Principal Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) is also on his tail, fed up with his antics. Headed to downtown Chicago for the day, what could possibly go wrong?
Any movie aimed at a younger audience needs that one special ingredient to keep their attention, or they will undoubtedly lose interest. You know what I'm talking about, right? Ok, say it with me now: comedy! This film is chock full of one-liners, sarcasm, and witty remarks. There is no way anyone could watch it without laughing at least once. At times the delivery is a bit much, (*cough cough* Principal Rooney -a grown man- growling many times throughout the movie), but in general the script does a good job of keeping the audience entertained.
One of the most memorable features of the movie is the setting. The film is set in Chicago, and it was actually mostly shot there. Their whole adventure through Chicago was all shot in Chicago, at such famous locations like Wrigley Field, the Art Institute of Chicago, and Willis Tower. Seeing that the setting in the film is true to the shooting location is refreshing to see and gives viewers a sense of authenticity.
Adding to authenticity, the acting was all there. Not counting how Cameron started out very sick and somehow just... magically got better? The interactions between the characters were extremely convincing. If I were to ever meet Matthew Broderick in person, I would expect him to be the eccentric extrovert I saw in the film. And Jennifer Grey? She would roll her eyes and walk away. Even though at the time of filming, none of these "high school students" were really in high school, they managed to make it feel like we were ditching school right along with them.
All in all, I did truly enjoy this movie. It didn't feel like just another one of those cheesy teen movies that keep getting pushed out to make money. Compared to other movies John Hughes has done, like Sixteen Candles, this appeals to a much wider audience and was overall more impactful. I recommend this movie to anyone for a good time. Even if it's not your type you might as well watch it because after all, "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it".

I loved Ferris Bueller's Day Off...but I must say that Alan Ruck is sooo much better than Matt Broderick.  He brings Cameron to life beautifully. This is a boy who is in a lot of pain and wisecracks to forget about it, and Alan really WAS Cam. Mia Sara is annoyingly bland..they could have gotten a better actress to play Sloane.  She appears to force any emotions she is required to show. Also, the part that has me on the floor every time is the English (?) teacher going "Inn...whaaaat...waaaayyyy....does the author's use...offf...prison!...symboliiiiize...."

Ferris Bueller's Day Off came out when I was two.  From the first time I saw it, I was instantly in love.  FBDO has characters you can really care about, a fabulous script, magnificent cast, and so much more. Matthew Broderick is at his best.  Ferris is, without a doubt, my favorite movie of all time.  I can't get enough, and no matter what my mood, when Ferris lip synchs on the float, I smile from ear-to-ear. I give Ferris a 10 out of 10.  If you haven't seen this movie, run like hell to the video store and pick it up, I assure you that it will be an instant favorite.  If I continued to express my feelings on Ferris, you'd sit at your computer all day, so I'll finish by saying LONG LIVE FERRIS!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: This doesn't hold up very well
reviews.content: This was an iconic must see aspirational movie in the 80:s. Who wouldn't want to be Ferris and his crew being self consciously cool playing hookey in Chicago.But years later it leaves a lot to be desired. And the whole parental angst with the car is just really lame.Jennifer Grey, Edie McClurg and Jeffrey Jones are still fun though.

I love this movie!!!! It's so funny and it's a cute story! It's one of my all time favorite movies!!!!! This is a great movie for teens and adults but it's family friendly too! The older audience might enjoy it more though.

SEE THE MOVIE BEFORE READING ON, OK? OK!!The second of Hughes' two classic teen flicks of all time. The wisecracking, wisdom offering, laid back Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) decides that it's time to take a day off. But not just any day off. Not a lay around at home playing video games sort of day off. We're talking the best day off ever.Taking his best friend, Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck), who is forever wound up tight and his girlfriend, Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara), who is about the only person who can keep Ferris in check, to Chicago. But it's not Ferris style to go in Cameron's old car. No no no. The best way by far is in Cameron's dad's Ferrari. 1961 Ferrari 250GT California to be exact. It doesn't bother Ferris one bit that less than a hundred were made and that Cameron's dad keeps a close eye on the mileage. The car is sheer Ferris and it's something that he has to drive.But it isn't just a day off. It helps Cameron from being uptight all his life, it helps Ferris from screwing his life up and makes Sloane realize that Ferris loves her.Hughes directs this movie superbly. It has everything needed to make a successful comedy. A young cast, great camera shots and a 'hero' everyone wants to be like. Broderick's camera shots when he talks to the audience or gives them sly looks are classic and help the audience identify with a guy who gets his kicks from skipping school. We see everything from Ferris's eyes and how he views the world.Once again Hughes uses teen pyschology, mainly with Cameron in this movie. The film shows how Cameron goes from a guy who flips out because he's being forced to do something he doesn't want to, to someone who does what he likes and fights for what he believes in. The scene when the three go to the art museum is clever as it shows how Cameron feels inside. Staring at a piece of art Cam notices that the closer you look the less you see and believes that this is how people are going to see him.It's Ferris' intention to liven Cameron up before the go their seperate ways, off to college and work. That's the real reason of taking the day off. Of course it's for Ferris' own pleasure too. A trip to the Sears tower, a posh restaurant and a parade ensure that Ferris can make sure that Cam, Sloane and himself have fun.But it's not as simple as that. Ferris has Mr. Rooney, dean of students, on his tail. If Rooney has his way Ferris will be spending the next year at school resitting everything subject. But Rooney doesn't know when to stop. He leaves the school grounds in pursuit of Ferris and keeps going one step too far in his goal. This is his downfall as the more he tries the more of an ass he makes himself look. The faces the kids on the late bus pull when a bedraggled Mr. Rooney walks on is great. Ferris' other enemy is his sister, Jeannie, who feels that Ferris shouldn't get the day off when he's not really sick and does everything she can to catch him in the act. She too goes over the top and ends up in a police station, making out with Charlie Sheen's character, Garth Volbeck, who offers her advice on her troubles.
Once again Hughes manages to combine teen humor with slapstick comedy and it blends perfectly. As in Weird Science and The Breakfast Club the authority figures are ridiculed and mocked to the point of extreme, in this case the ever trying, ever failing Mr. Rooney.The reason this movie was more successful than Hughes previous films (Sixteen Candles, The Breakfast Club and Weird Science) is because it has a wider appeal than say, surrealistic Weird Science. As in true Hughes tradition it has a cast of unknowns who later went on to become part of the Eighties brat pack, including Broderick and a cameo by Charlie Sheen.
Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a feel good movie. There's not a real plot, it's just pure entertainment, and Hughes directs it this way. If you're looking for fun then you can't go wrong with a John Hughes movie, and this movie in particular. If you have the chance I highly recommend you watch this.Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while you could miss it.

For me this was the film of the eighties.  It encapsulates a lot of the humor, values and style of the teen comedy films of that period without resorting to the more vulgar aspects common to other films of it's type.  A decent light hearted film that I still enjoy watching today.

If you didn't get around to seeing it in the 80's, it's never too late to watch Ferris Bueller.  I recommend the DVD, with an interesting commentary by Hughes.  This movie is a great homage to the decade, to Chicago, and to unloved or misunderstood teenagers everywhere.

reviews.review_title: "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."
reviews.content: This is not only one of the funniest movies I've ever seen, it's also one of the most inspiring, life-affirming movies I've ever seen. If somebody were simply told this was the story of a teenager skipping school to go on a fun-filled journey through Chicago, many would expect Ferris Bueller to be a reckless teenager that doesn't take his life seriously. These people would then be shocked to find Ferris is taking a day off because he IS taking his life very seriously. Ferris is the person we'd all love to be – free from worries and problems and simply living life to the fullest. School faculties will hate me for saying this, but it's very exhilarating to see this happy-go-lucky character escape from the mind-numbing prison that is high school, and live his life in absolute freedom. If there was ever a convincing case for truancy, this is it.When I first saw this movie, I immediately related to Ferris's friend, Cameron – a worried and nervous person who "feels better when he's sick." I have an anxiety disorder, and every now and then find myself in complete fear and panic when faced with a situation that I'm not used to. So to see this character's emotional journey throughout the film was probably one of the most meaningful moments in my history of watching movies. All of the supporting characters are well-crafted, with the principal being the anti-thesis of Ferris(a stressed and gullible man), and his sister being jealous of Ferris's annoying habit of getting away with everything. This film is one of John Hughes's best achievements as a director. He is renowned for having amazing soundtracks that fit beautifully with the images shown. One great example off the top of my head is the art museum scene with an instrumental version of The Smiths' "Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want." The parade scene is the best scene in the film, showing exuberant joy on an enormous scale. Critic Richard Roeper called this film "a form of suicide prevention," and he's right. This film is the ultimate feel-good, laugh-out-loud movie; it might as well be used for therapy. This is definitely John Hughes's best movie, I love it and admire it so much that I want this to be the last film I watch before I die – that way, I can go out saying that life certainly was worth it.

Let me tell you, I hate teen movies. I hate them, hate them, HATE THEM!!!! All the characters seem to only see their future at the latest keg party, love to get high, get knocked up, and for the most part, screw up their entire lives. And you know what? I AM A TEENAGER! But let me put it this way....Ferris Bueller's is the king of not only 'teen movies' but of all Comedy's!Ferris Bueller's Day Off came out a year before I was born. Though I don't necessarily care for a ton of 80's movies for the fact that all the huge hair and cheesy teenage love stories annoy me, but this movie has got to be one of my all-time favorites.I distinctively remember the first time my mom and I rented Ferris Buellers Day off together. I think I was 5...and I loved every Matthew Broderick movie I had seen (and still do...with the exception of The Cable Guy...that movie was a brick) So, naturally, I knew I was going to like this one...Within 2 minutes of the movie I was laughing so hard I was crying. And not only that, I realized it was a movie that was made in an era that I was not at all too familiar with. But I didn't care, all I knew was that I loved the movie. And of course...I STILL DO!!!!Now here I am, a high school Freshman, and I've heard tons of adults tell me to remember my highschool years, because they are some of the best years of your life. Well, I'm starting to feel that. And not only am I now gaining good memories from high school, but good memories from a great movie, that I will carry with me for the rest of my life.10+++++++++++/10

Ferris Bueller is the guy you'd love to know in high school. Charismatic, good looking, smart, and popular with "The sportos, the motorheads, geeks, sluts, bloods, waistoids, dweebies, dickheads. .  . they all think he's a righteous dude" This movie is hysterical, though unrealistic (HOW did Ferris manage to get himself on that float? well, I guess he is Ferris Bueller. ..) Matthew Broderick is perfect as the title role, and Jennifer Gray is hysterical as his hateful scheming sister. Alan Ruck is also great as the paranoid best friend of Ferris. All in all, this movie is a must see and has been enjoyed by people from all age groups. I don't know a single person who doesn't think Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of the best movies of all time.

reviews.review_title: A must for anyone who ever went to high school
reviews.content: This film is one of director John Hughes' best efforts. It captures some of the ethos of the 1980's, as well as the timeless pathos of the passage to adulthood. Matthew Broderick is superb in the title role, mixing the wise guy with the nice guy in the perfect proportions, so well that he may never truly escape from this role. The supporting cast is equally up to the task, with Alan Ruck, Jennifer Grey and Jeffrey Jones especially noteworthy. Charlie Sheen also makes the most of a small role late in the movie. There are an abundance of laughs from beginning to end, and like all of Hughes' films, it also has a heart, and a serious moment or two. This movie has been a part of my collection for many years, and will continue to provide enjoyment for as long as I am able to watch it.

I love this movie, I got it about 1 or 2 years ago and bought it. Since then I have watched this movie At least 7 times. No joke. I have never watched any movie more then 3 times except this movie. I will keep watching always. This movie is great, it will always be great, I still will watch it, I will still like it, I will watch it 100 times more! Awesome, funny, great, hilarious, cool, fun! -Harrison Houde

Ferris Bueller's day off is an inspiration to everyone that understands the complexity of high school. Ferris Bueller (Mathew Broderick) is an American Idol to all in this country. Everyone can appreciate the movie magic that is created when he takes of in the red car. The ingenuity of a moving, mechanical sleep dummy gets him started and on the right path to a truly successful day off. The plot is carefully orchestrated with Ferris Bueller (Broderick) as a wise-cracking high school senior from the fictional northern Chicago suburb of Shermer, Illinois (in reality, Lake Forest, Illinois), who decides to skip school (Lake Forest High School) for a day on the town by pretending to be sick. He convinces his nervous friend, Cameron (Ruck) to take his father's carefully restored 1961 Ferrari 250 GT California out for a spin, although Cameron's father has so little trust in him that he has memorized the car's mileage. Ferris makes the promise to erase any miles they put on the car by running the car in reverse when they return. Masquerading as her father, Ferris springs his junior girlfriend Sloane (Sara) from school on the premise that her grandmother has died. this is a truly remarkable film.

I just got to college, and the school offered a big-screen presentation to my class, and 350 people could fit.  No one ever stopped laughing.  This movie has got such outstanding dialogue throughout, it gets better every time.  Anyone who doesn't think this movie is hilarious is someone I just don't want to be around....

I love this movie. It has got to be the funniest teen movie that was ever made. I never get tired of watching it. It really makes you wish you could be in this movie, skipping school in that gorgeous car and having someone as funny and clever as Ferris for a friend. Everyone who has been in a dull classroom, looking outside at the sun has wanted to be Ferris. Everyone who ever skipped school only to do nothing has wanted to be Ferris. Everyone who has ever seen this movie has wanted to be Ferris.The seminal teen movie of the last 20 years, no disrespect to the Breakfast Club. If you don't like it, you're dead from the shoulders down and the neck up.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is, in my opinion, the ultimate teen comedy. Matthew Broderick is absolutely hilarious in his portrayal as Ferris, and Alan Ruck is hysterical as well. Even the smaller roles - Jennifer Grey as Jeannie, Charlie Sheen as "The boy in the police station" - are acted wonderfully. This is a fun, happy, funny movie that people of all ages will enjoy - it's just great!

This movie gets better every time I see it. The first time I saw it, I recall liking it, but nothing spectacular. I still can't put my finger on why this movie is so popular today. Perhaps it's the fact that every character, from Matthew Broderick to the bit parts (Charlie Sheen and Ben Stein) are so well-developed and portrayed.Perhaps one example of the popularity of this movie is the fact that, 15 years later, Ben Stein is still capitalising on his "boring teacher" character. "Anyone? Anyone? Bueller?"

reviews.review_title: The best of its genre, "Ferris" amuses and entertains at the same level it did 15 years ago.
reviews.content: This is a film that has aged well-- rather better than most of its viewers, in fact (take a look around your office).  Indeed, "Ferris" continues to amuse and entertain precisely because all of us, whether we admit it or not, still want to identify with the victories of the hero and his friends over the adults we have long since become.  Or perhaps already were in 1986...Beyond the steadily successful development of its plot-driven (or maybe "plot"-driven) situational humor, "Ferris" impresses as a film of wonderful isolated moments; many of these have drawn well-deserved praise-- Ben Stein now *defines* the classic feckless teacher for a generation, and Charlie Sheen (appearing unbilled) managed an inspired James Dean homage for the 80's kids to guess the origins of-- but some have (apparently) escaped general notice.  Has there ever been a better, more believable Irritable Best Friend character than that created in Alan Ruck's sulking-Cameron scenes?  Or consider Richard Edson ("Joey Breaker", "Do the Right Thing") as the swarth-enhanced parking garage attendant; when Ferris asks "Do you speak English?", Edson simply masterfully doles out incredulity via a raised eyebrow and the now-classic response (today so daringly un-PC) "What country do you think this *is*?"Briefly put, "Ferris" continues to do credit to all who created and appeared in it--and rewards the home viewer over multiple screenings.  The fact that this film has drawn a paltry 2 1/2-star rating from a standard (and usually reliable) source such as Maltin remains a Bermuda Triangle-sized anomaly...

This is a movie that you get or you don't. It's heavily saturated with satire & parody of how life really is, versus how any teenage joe schmoe sees this movie as the epitome of his dreams. Ferris Bueller lives out his perfect sick day from school; every scheme he pulls works out and leaves him spotless at the end of the day. I think it's one of the most hilarious movies I've ever seen.Ferris Bueller is a hero for anybody who goes through themonotonous routine of daily life we can find ourselves in. "If you don't look around once in while, you can miss it."If you find this movie enjoyable, try Office Space.

This movie was excellent! First of all, Ferris is so smart to know how to trick his parents! It is fun to watch what he will do next! I have watched this movie about 20 times and I'm still not bored of it! I feel so sorry for Cameron being the third wheel and all. It was so funny at the end when Jeanie comes out and saves Ferris's butt! It serves Mr. Rooney right for sneaking into their house! This boy has everything an 18-year-old guy could ask for! A jelous sister, a great best friend, a pretty girlfriend, a principal who he can make a fool of, popularity and parents who are easy to fool! What a great movie! 12/10!!!

Ferris Bueller was either loved or hated by his peers for always getting away with anything he'd do. Some would want him expelled, others want him for Class President. On this extremely eventful day, the audience is invited to follow Ferris, his best pal and his girlfriend from morning to afternoon (when they all should have been in school), enjoying a holiday declared by the resourceful Ferris Bueller.They get to speed on the freeway in a Ferrari, sing "Danke Schoen" on an Octoberfest Float, eat at the most exclusive restaurant in town and always keep just one step ahead of a furious principal in hot pursuit. With fake computer grade and attendance records, Ferris has it made.The scene where the principal hitches a ride on a school bus after having been "torn up" by Doberman watch dogs is worth the ticket price (Oh Yeah!). This is one of the funniest "high school prankster movies" ever! Has it been 20 years already? This is a definite Cult Classic! Right up there with Animal House and Caddy Shack.

Wow this is a great movie. A summary of teenage life and a trigger of memories for anyone who's ever been a teenager. A true-to-life and timeless plot, made all the more realistic by its wonderfully crafted characters. Cameron always seems to get mixed up in Ferris' schemes, whether he knows it or not. Everyone knows a Cameron, after all, what would life be like without someone to worry for you and make fake phone calls? Sloane just goes along with whatever plan she's presented with, and always adds a little extra fun to the adventure. You can't help but fall in love with the witty,and rule- "bending" Ferris, who also shows us that life is more than our work and responsibilities, we can have a whole lot of fun on the way!! So remember, "Life moves pretty fast, and if you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you might miss it" So take a break, you wouldn't want to miss your "Day Off"

This film is definitely the best of Mattathew Broderick's, along with 'Glory'; it definitely gives a message of having fun and enjoy life to many teenagers. Matthew Broderick is definitely a legend at playing his role as a college student who just wants to escape school and have a whole day's fun with a Ferrari alongside with his girl and his best friend. what is very enjoyable are the humorous parts where Ferris has to hide or escape from certain conditions which would ruin his day of fun; along with various humors of his principal Rooney while chasing Ferris. reviews.review_title: Laugh out loud from start to finish
reviews.content: When this film first came out, I stayed away, figuring it was another brainless, made-for-teens date night flick.  It took several recommendations from people in their 30's and 40's to get me to go, and I've seen it six times since.  Every single time I watch it, I start laughing even before the payoff scenes, and laugh even louder when they arrive than when I first was surprised by them in the theatre:Note Ferris's inventive "breaking the fourth wall" manner of talking directly to the audience;Ferris's endlessly creative ways of avoiding school on a beautiful Chicago afternoon;The hilarious juxtaposition of chant-like music and set props when his hypochondriac friend, Cameron, first appears;The roadrunner-and-coyote matching of wits between Ferris and the bumbling school principal and his equally clueless secretary, culminating early on in a phone call that had me falling out of my theatre seat;The first movie appearance of the now-familiar, but hilariously deadpan, Ben Stein ("Anyone?...Anyone?" as a drone-like teacher;The fun-filled escapades around downtown and near-north Chicago, which play like a travelogue of that wonderful city;The unforgettable reaction of Cameron when he discovers what the parking guys have done to his dad's prized sports car (I almost choked to death on that one);The prinicipal's mishap-laden visit to Ferris's home;Charlie Sheen's subtle, yet hilarious, reaction to Jennifer Gray's profane suggestion at the police station;... ...and on and on.It may seem odd that a 46-year old man can call a high school flick from 1986 as the funniest film he's ever seen, but this is it.As the closing-credits music puts it, "Ooooohhhhhhh...... ......yyyeeeeeeaaaaahhhhhhh!"

After many years of wearing out my VHS copy I finally bought it on DVD, looking forward to an excellent treatment of the menu system. Sadly, there isn't one. Such a classic 80's movie should be given a fully interactive menu system. Surely the film company has made enough cash on this to warrant one.This is a cracking movie that may make you wish you where Ferris.How I wish they would make a follow up and make him a senator. Does anyone know if one was ever written?

This film has all the magic of any 80's teen comedy; brat packish actors, great soundtrack and most importantly John Hughes. Ferris is a kid, an underdog, which we can all relate to; a clever kid, who just finds the system so boring and inept that he fails it for being "a righteous dude". His quest is to show his audience the big picture; what can be done if you chill out, take out your friends, and borrow you friends' dads ferrari. Throughout the film you cannot help but root for Ferris and his swashbuckling determination to have fun, whilst not getting caught. Witty, clever and a great way to cherish the fondness of your schooldays. "Go Ferris."10/10

reviews.review_title: Perfect film for a day off
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller is what we all wanted to be in our younger days: Witty, funny, methodical, and has the hot girlfriend. Hes a protagonist that manages to keep troubles at the calm through his mischief.The film is very well put together. Apart from Ferris, the film explores a plethora of characters who all sort through their day centered around him. Its easy to make formulations on what kinda of characters they are as generic characters but its nonetheless hilarious and accurate.Growing up and gaining independence is stressed as more than simply skipping class. The day off symbolizes the current period of the now and how despite the revolving world around them, friends and experiences can still be kept. Its an absolutely wonderful message that pierces what would appear to be a simple skit.The exposition is clear, concise and best of all necessary. There isn't any useless bits that feel like a timewaster, it accurately depicts the quick tempo of the film along with it's more serious moments.

if you are still at school watch and learn. 'Ferris Bueller' is a well executed trip on how to bunk off and in that action totally enjoy your day off, the film language is quite basic, but the performance of broderick make this film stand out its still probably his best performance. all i want to do now is jump on a float in chicago and i'll be sorted

It has been a long time since I've seen this movie. I saw the DVD yesterday on a flee market, so I decided to go ahead and buy it.After watching it again after such a long time, I still think this is a good comedy. The performance of Broderick, Jones and especially Alan Ruck are great.The movie isn't hilarious all the time, but it has some really good (practical) jokes in it.Especially the creative ways in which Ferris manages to skip school are well found.7 out of 10

Am I the only woman out there who thinks that Ferris is the hottest guy EVER? Well, maybe I'm a little biased because I grew up in the Chicago area where the movie was filmed. Most of the scenes in the movie were shot in Winnetka and Northbrook and as you can tell those towns are absolutely beautiful. I unfortunately grew up in a neighboring town called Evanston and often longed of going to the famous New Trier HS in Winnetka and living the life of Ferris' girl friend Sloan. You see my Ferris, we'll call him Mr. E to protect the innocent grew up in the area and went to New Trier. He was so cute and was totally like Ferris. I used to sit in class and write his name over and over in my notes, Emma + Erik, oops I let it slip. Oh well, I can't help it, he's just so dreamy!! As Cameron famously says after Ferris saves him from the pool "Ferris Bueller, you're my hero" Erik ....., is my hero. I often used to drive by his parents house and pretended that I was going to meet him for a date, then it was back to boring old Evanston. He talked to me once, and said "can I have some napkins" when he was ordering some food at this restaurant Buffalo Joe's in my town where I used to work. I touched his hand, it was the greatest day of my life. Unfortunately I'm a plump old housewife now living on the west coast, but at least I always have this movie to remind me of the good old days. Oh did I mention, Erik, I mean Ferris, is totally hot. So, like yeah see the movie. It is way rad!!

reviews.review_title: The movie that helped us enjoy high school a little bit more!
reviews.content: Even if you don't like 80s music, you can't help but find the soundtrack to this movie infectious (track listings are posted on fan websites all over the Internet though there was never an official soundtrack).  Matthew Broderick is an extremely likeable character as Ferris Bueller: an intensely popular high school student with a close circle of friends.  I'm not advocating ditching high school classes and dodging parents, but this movie conveys a true sense of anxiety and excitement while skipping classes and barely making it home in time to finish off a day that could not have gone better.  A cult classic that belongs in the adventure/comedy section of a video collection.

reviews.review_title: Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck) is the real hero of this movie!
reviews.content: Ferris BEuller's Day Off, My favorite movie,(besides Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back) features a young man named Ferris BEuller ditching school for a day with his best friend, Cameron Frye, and his girl, Sloan Peterson. all the while, Principal Ed Rooney is on their tail, trying to catch Ferris ditching school. Very humorous movie. But I still like Cameron better than Ferris! If you don't already, you should OWN THIS MOVIE!!!

reviews.review_title: Ferris was the Master of Skipping School...
reviews.content: Only if John Hughes made sequels and more movies like this...why weren't any movies like this one made when I was in school?I was six years old when this movie came out, I think by the time I first saw it I was a little older, like 8 or 9, but I'm in my twenties now, it would have been fun to see movies like this, but this one is a classic for any high schooler. I wasn't successful in skipping school, and never tried it in high school (by that time I made a commitment not to even get into serious trouble, and it worked all four years).

Don't take this the wrong way, i like some of the "brat pack" movies, especially st. elmos fire.I have seen this movie three times, i still can't see what makes this movie great. How many principles would chase a student who skips school?My answer is zero, but if you think other wise, then by all means watch it, please do, it's your loss!

reviews.review_title: the best movie of the 80's decade
reviews.content: And my favorite movie of all time. John Hughes was brilliant. I love how simple the movie was...yet it was so well put together. Alan Ruck is the best at doing impressions. There were different events in the movie in a short amount of time, which was even better because it wasn't boring to watch. I find it amusing how the mom did not even notice the dummy in Ferris' bed...but hey, that would have ruined the whole movie! And another thing that is far-fetched is when Slone kisses Ferris when he is picking her up from school making it so obvious for Rooney to figure everything out. See...you never know what will happen next while you're watching it, and i have watched it over a dozen times. It's too bad that movies today aren't as good as they used to be.

In 1987, while on vacation in Ireland with "Dirty Dancing" star Jennifer Grey (not pictured), a car driven by Broderick collided head-on with a Volvo. Broderick and Grey survived, but the two passengers in the other vehicle died. Broderick was faced with serving up to 10 years in prison for causing "death by dangerous driving." However, the actor was later fined just $175 and convicted of the lesser charge of "careless driving."

Cameron's parents did not appear so it felt like his story was superficial and there was no real resolution. Ferris is really smart but annoying.It's just slapstick comedy with the Principal which wasn't entertaining to me.
This movie was one of my favorites!! A classic that I highly recommend you to watch!!!!

reviews.review_title: A movie to see more than once
reviews.content:
This is the kind of movie we always remember in some life situations. Although they make a caricature of reality as in class and the reactions of children, it is almost a perfect description of many real situations for example.
The script was well assembled so as not to leave future actions so explicit. It was recorded in an engaging way with some narratives directed to the viewer made by the main actor himself without making it seem strange.
The roles put in the film are common characters for students and make them identify real people from their lives. A great movie to see again from time to time.

reviews.review_title: the bueller bueller edition of ferris bueller
reviews.content: a crisper looking version of one of the more enjoyable teen movies of the 1980's complete with a plethora of interesting extras! recent interviews of the stars, give new insights to the making of the film, and it was interesting to see how they have aged in the years since the movie. some have aged well, some, not so well! a big disappointment, was the absence of a recent interview by Mia Sara, and her memories of making ferris bueller! has she sunk so far below the radar of show business revelence, that the producers of this edition did'nt even bother to include her! still, all i all a worthwhile new DVD of a funny 1980's movie that can be enjoyed ore then once!

A definition of a good movie is one that impacts people generation after generation. That never gets old to no matter who is watching. Like a good series over years, Star Wars for example Continue to be popular years after they come out. A movie that isn't apart of a series that has done this for many years and will continue to do so for many years is Ferris Bueller's Day Off. 
 It has become one of the most classic comedy movies of all time and the main reason we all love it is because we all wish we could be Ferris Bueller for a little bit. For most of high school there are moments when I dream of not having to worry about the homework and absences of school. Ferris bueller has the guts to not care about all this and make the most of his time and live to the fullest unlike his buddy Cameron. Although for this one day Ferris gets rid of all doubt and fear and takes of course big risks. Although being caught almost everyday Ferris still risks it for the biscuit and gets bolder and bolder as the day goes on. Absolutely forgetting the fact Ferris could not graduate if he gets caught he still goes on and has a blast per usual. With Cameron leading their day it would have only lasted an hour or so but with Ferris they get the opportunity to go to a baseball game and lead a parade in Chicago and much much more while celebrating his life with his girlfriend and best friend and continue to live life with Ferris's crazy sister and very oblivious parents running around and living life while they can to the most of their ability and living by his own quote "life moves pretty fast, if you don't slow down every once in a while, you might miss it."
 Matthew Broderick (Ferris) is extremely comical and very smooth throughout The Whole movie. He even connects with the audience on a whole new level when he directly talks to them at the beginning of the movie and multiple times throughout. This allows us to see in what Ferris sees and how he plans things and what he wants to happen and helps you better comprehend the movie. It shows him better that a lot of time and thought are put into his plans and that he is not just a big lazy bum and slacker throughout school and life but rather very smart and hardworking when he wants to be. Ferris throughout the movie seems to be the person that everyone is jealous of and wants to be who Ferris is. Even his sister who plots against him The Whole movie but when it becomes the middle of the movie and towards the end you come to realize that almost everyone who conspires against Ferris is actually jealous and respects what he has accomplished and almost envy him.
 Another thing that was really impactful throughout this film was the music and sounds. For example during the parade in downtown Chicago they used the song "Twist and Shout" by the Beatles and shows how cheerful and what a great time they are all having. The thing about songs and music is it can emphasize the mood of the movie and how the characters are feeling during certain scenes. Like when it would show his sister it would be a kinda darker slower music because she was always trying to catch him. Also the sounds emphasize where you are for example when the dean of students, Mr. Rooney is in the arcade it is a lot of noise and random objects emphasizing chaos and lots of confusion for him making him make mistakes and mistake a girl for Ferris. Sounds can change entire aspects of a movie making it fearful or joyful and throughout this movie the majority of the sounds are cheerful and show joy for Ferris and Cameron, whereas for Mr. Rooney and Ferris's sister are negative and dull. The sounds in this movie really help emphasize the mood and do a really good job making it the movie it is to be.
 One thing about this movie that could have been better I believe is the plot. I couldn't seem to find a point as to what the whole point is. I thought they could have shortened up the scene with Ferris's sister because I didn't understand really where she came in at the end and tried giving her more apart of the movie but I didn't think she really had a meaning or a purpose in the moving rather than trying to get Ferris in trouble. I think John Hughes the director should have cut that scene and maybe focused more on Ferris and almost getting caught by Edward Rooney the Dean of students. Although this is just a monitor flaw in this movie all in all I think it is a class act film.
 John Hughes who directs this movie does a wonderful job emphasizing that kids should live your life to the fullest and have fun while you are young. He shows don't care what other people think just do what you think is right and have fun while your doing it even if getting out of school is what is right. This movie is so good it will continue to be a gem for years to come as it has been since it left the box office.

reviews.review_title: Stands the test of time - gets better with each viewing
reviews.content: The first time I saw Ferris Bueller I was 30 - not exactly the target audience. I thought it was corny but, for lack of a better description, strangely uplifting. I've seen it lots of times since and it never fails to have that effect. It makes me laugh and cheers me up. What more could one ask from a movie?  It's become my all-time favorite comedy, flaws and all. I give it a 10.

reviews.review_title: Simply the best of a clutch of 80s teen movies
reviews.content: In the 70s, it was cool for directors to look back to earlier times to create feel good films - Grease, American Graffiti being examples.#John Hughes took a different approach in the 80s. His films were about the 80s and its values. As someone who was 18 in 1985, these films mean a lot to me. They sum up the work hard play hard ethic. Except Ferris Bueller - he worked smart and played hard.Ferris Bueller was how we all wanted to be. The guy could bluff his way out of any situation. He had a gorgeous girlfriend, a best friend who idolised him, and access to a Ferrari. In order to cheer up said best friend, he decides to take the day off and show him the outside world. Of course he is being pursued along the way by school principal.The film is witty, artistic (compared to others in the genre), has a great 80s sound track, and really does capture the mood of the times.The funniest character in my opinion is the nutty secretary at the high school. This actress (who played Eunice in Whats up Doc) should have got an oscar. Her 'righteous dude' and 'horses ass' lines crack me up every time (if you want to here them, visit the Ferris Bueller Web Site)

Although the film's characters are based purely on stereotypes, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of the best films I've ever seen.Everyone can relate to at least one of the characters, be it the depressed Cameron or smarty-pants Ferris.  Throw in some clever jokes and a couple of situations that we'd all like to find ourselves in and John Hughes has made the perfect teen-flick.This has obviously been the inspiration for more recent films, 'Ten Things I Hate About You' works on similar conventions.  I could almost guarantee that if this film was re-released it would rake it in at the box offices.

Ferris Bueller's day off is one of those films that can be taken off the shelf and watched 20 times yet still retains its original luster. When the character Ferris Bueller talks into the camera you almost feel like your right there with him looking over your shoulder every step of the way, not knowing when or where "ROONEY" will pop up. This film provides an hour and a half of quality entertainment, very few films can captivate the youth of america but Ferris Bueller's day off proves strong 2 generations in a row and still going. If your attending high school I suggest renting this, the tips for faking out parents and always staying a half a step ahead of your teachers should come in handy. I think Ferris says it best "Life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop to look around once in awhile you might miss it".

reviews.review_title: Ferris needs one day of freedom, how hard can that be.
reviews.content: Matthew Broderick plays the most popular guy in school, a smart fellow who wants a day of freedom, how is he going to do it, play the good old "I'm sick trick". I think every kid in the United States has tried this and it works. Well his name is Ferris and this movie made by John Hughes the king of directing movies in the 80's, Hughes shows slapstick comedy the right way. Well Mr.Rooney the principal spends his whole work day looking for Ferris and he usually fails. Ferris and his girlfriend have a wonderful time and the same for friend Cameron, played by Alan Ruck who I think did better then Broderick. Overall the movie is perfect and unique, kids follow this movie it will teach you a lot.

I always saw the FBDO box in the comedy section at the videostore, but I never rented it, thinking it would be some sort of cheesy 80's movie. One day though, I had a "3 for the price of 1" coupon, and having already seen everything decent at the videostore, I decided to give it a go.Well, wow. A clean teen comedy that's not about getting laid. I dont know if I was in a good mood, but I remember laughing hysterically throughout the movie. Ferris, his friend Cameron, and his girlfriend (forgot her name)decide to take the day off...but unbeknownst to the trio , but beknownst to us, the principal is after them, because he is obsessed with catching Ferris. reviews.review_title: Possibly the greatest movie of all time?
reviews.content: The first time I saw it I wasn't that impressed, then for some reason I watched it again a few months later and it had morphed into what I would think is the best John Hughes film and very possibly the greatest teen movie of the eighties, great acting, a fresh new plot superb actors and a fantastic soundtrack all come together to produce a masterpeiceAnd you can quote me on that.

this movie is an absolute classic. It stands as a true 80's icon, and lets you know that a good movie can exist, that isn't restricted by complex plots and useless dialogue, as some movies possess. It's a great movie, everyone will love it.

reviews.review_title: One of the all-time classic school movies... about skipping school.
reviews.content: An all-time comedy classic, "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" has something for everyone. The witty, scathing character of Ferris will keep anybody amused for one and a half hours.The premise is that the wily high=schooler Ferris Bueller decides that since it's such a beautiful day outside, he'll take a day off school by feigning illness. And despite his performance being "one of his worst", he still succeeds in convincing his parents that he needs rest.Cue lots of antics involving him and his best friend Cameron, involving "borrowing" Cameron's father's Ferrari, going to the top of the Sears Tower and foxing his poor put-upon principal at every turn.The movie is full of fantastic scenes, and is a fantastic movie to sit and watch again and again. It reminds you to either enjoy your youth while you have it, or reminds you what it was like to be young. A truly joyous movie.

reviews.review_title: He may not be the walrus, but he'll always be Ferris!
reviews.content: When Ferris Bueller's Day Off was first released, I was already into my 20's, so obviously it's been a long time since I was a teenager. Nonetheless, this has always been one of my very favourite movies, and remains so today. Ferris is a teenager who decides to take the day off school and goes to incredible lengths to cover his tracks, right down to recording a fake "Funeral Home" answering machine message! Matthew Broderick is, of course, wonderful as the title character and Alan Ruck is absolutely brilliant (even upstaging Broderick at times) as the anal-retentive Cameron. The supporting roles are all very well done, especially Cindy Pickett and Lyman Ward as Ferris' dim-bulb parents, Jennifer Grey as his wonderfully bitchy sister, Edie McClurg as the scatterbrained secretary Grace, and especially Jeffrey Jones as the hapless principal Ed Rooney. Also worth a giggle are the hilarious cameo performances by Kristy Swanson, Ben Stein and Charlie Sheen.  Best scene of the movie: the "Twist and Shout" scene. This movie is filled with some terrific one-liners, such as "I weep for the future", "I think we should shoot her" and my personal favourite "what country do you think this is?" Matthew Broderick may be making it big on Broadway these days but to me he'll always be Ferris.

reviews.review_title: A film to get you through a hangover !
reviews.content: As I write I'm watching this fantastic film. I'm laughing my head off too. If you're having an awful day watch this film and see the sun come out. Marvellous performances from everyone and a deep recognition that there is a little bit of Ferris in all of us. ( After all I am watching this on a day I'm having a sickie from work ).

reviews.review_title: Ferris Bueller's Day Off - Living in the Moment
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is directed by John Hughes and it stars Matthew Broderick, Alan Ruck, Mia Sara, and Jeffrey Jones.Ferris Bueller contains many different themes in this movie, but the most important theme is "Living in the Moment". Throughout the entirety of this movie, Ferris and his two friends are skipping school to try and have a good time before the end of their senior years (except for Sloane).Ferris, Cameron, and Sloane have created created a lifetime of special memories in their lives together. None of these characters are perfect people, especially Ferris, but all of them care deeply about each other. For example, throughout the entirety of the movie Cameron is constantly worried about his father's Ferrari and Ferris is always trying to cheer him up. Ferris is definitely not a good role model, but he does care about making others happy.Even though this movie is mostly a comedy, I think one of the central focuses of this movie is on Cameron. Cameron is always worried about what his father thinks about him and feels like he is all alone. It is hinted in the movie that his father cares more about materials like his Ferrari, instead of his own son. Cameron eventually overcomes his fear of his father by crashing the Ferrari out of anger. Ferris tries to take the blame for the incident, but Cameron decides to take the blame because he is tired of being afraid of his father. His growth as a character is really shined on in throughout the movie and it is well executed by John Hughes.Another praise I have for this movie is the acting from Matthew Broderick as Ferris Bueller. He really shows his talents as an actor in this movie and has a special charm to his performance. Broderick also has a ton of fantastic comedic moments throughout the entire movie and breaks the fourth wall on multiple occasions.The soundtrack is also quite amazing in this movie too. One of the main features in this movie is "Oh Yeah" by Yello and also features "Danke Schoen" from Wayne Newton. The soundtrack helps create a sense of uniqueness to this movie and helps elevate it to a new level.Ferris Bueller has had a major impact on the world today. It is mentioned in numerous of movies throughout the years. For example, "Spiderman: Homecoming" and "Deadpool" both have referenced this iconic movie. Ferris Bueller has set its mark on the world and will stand the test of time.This movie is simply incredible and is one of my favorite comedies of all time.Ferris: Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it.

I know it's slapstick, wherein one expects exaggeration for effect. However, to put approximately 3000 miles on the car would have required, say, an *average* speed of 100mph for 30 hours straight -- quite a bit too much for the joyrider to have accomplished.

reviews.review_title: I have seen it about sixteen times...
reviews.content: And we all have seen it, so let's celebrate it with cheerful reminiscing. Because, what's NOT to like about this, John Hughes, cult- epic. Except for the fact it never got a sequel! Only the television show, which lasted only one season and was poorly cast ed. And besides that, a series is not a good format and wouldn't do justice to the Day Off concept. Although I did enjoy 'Parker Lewis can't loose' as a kid. Which is a direct rip-off in my perspective. Ferris Bueller however is timeless. The Characters are great but the idea of the Day Off was most inspiring. I often say to myself the words "How can u possible handle "school" on a day like this" and then change 'school' for 'work' or 'social family obligations'. In the 80's I related mostly to Cameron (Ferris's loser friend). And I still (now twenty odd years later) when I don't like to get up, I hear his song in my head "When Cameron was in Egypt land, let my people go". This was so abstract for me, back then, and at the same time so perfectly clear. When you liked this one, you also should see; Better of Dead and The Breakfast Club.

reviews.review_title: If you haven't seen Ferris Buller, you haven't seen a great comedy!
reviews.content: Being a child of the 80's, I grew up with this movie, and I loved it since the first time I saw it! It's my favorite comedy and 80's flick, and for what better reason? This movie is hilarious, and all of us can only dream of sneaking out of school and having a day off like Ferris does! (And we can only dream of our most hated principal/teacher always getting the worst of it while trying to catch us.) My favorite scenes are where they're trying to get into the restaurant with the snobby waiter, ("I weep for the future!") and Jeannie's chat with the guy in the police station. The only thing I don't like about this movie is how Ferris seems to slightly manipulate Cameron, his best friend, but despite that, this movie must be seen if you love 80's flicks. If you haven't seen Ferris Buller's Day off, then you haven't seen a great comedy! Rent it, buy it, catch it on T.V, but whatever you do, you gotta see this movie!

Who wouldn't want to be Ferris, at least for one day? And especially if it could be the day he takes off from school, with friends Cameron and Sloane, journeying into downtown Chicago impersonating the rich and famous while capturing the hearts of an entire city? Ferris represents everything all high school boys want to be: funny, good-looking, quick, charming, conniving yet smart, and popular. Having a girlfriend as hot as Sloan Peterson doesn't hurt either. And driving a Ferrari helps. What really won me over about his character was Ferris' ability to talk his way through conflicts and problems. Perhaps it is his strategic way of thinking I envy. When faced with similar confrontations (i.e. the restaurant scene with the `snooty' host), I'd probably crack and then wet my pants. Ferris was able to, though non-violently and painlessly, deceive people, achieve his goal, and make himself look like the good guy all while doing so. It's this ability I find so intriguing and sexy. In a way, yes, this movie told kids it's okay to lie and do the wrong thing. But it also taught kids not to give up in the face of opposition. But who really cares what the underlying message is? Movies are made to help one escape miserable reality for 2 hours. In those two hours I imagined myself as Ferris Bueller, conquering the world, singing in a parade, being ogled by beautiful dancers, and tooling around in a Ferrari. This life is a dream come true- as long as you ignore the final scene, which I suppose the director/writer John Hughes included to help movie-goers prepare for re-entry back into their pathetic and dreary lives.
Just perfect in every way possible in the way of acting, directing, writing and comedy.

reviews.review_title: Absolutely favorite movie of all time
reviews.content: If you list the greatest movies of all time, Ferris Bueller makes the cut. From the pale lighting in the school to the large grandiose shots of downtown Chicago, This movie has it all. In what could be Matthew Broderick breakout performance, this movie was a portrayal of one man's effort to just take it easy. The lighting in this movie is worth mentioning, when they are in the high school the lighting is very pale and boring. Much like the school they are in, the natural silence in the classroom is what carries over the boredom in your head as well as the character's learning about "voodoo economics". Also one thing to mention is Ferris bueller's foil in the story, Edward Rooney. Ed is a man who takes his job too seriously and his attempt to finally catch ferris in the act of ditching led for some of the film's more funnier moments. One of the thing that really gets to me is the character development of Ferris' friend Cameron. Cam is a very troubled young man who lives in a very troubled household. My favorite part of the movie is him finding himself and his confidence when he destroyed that beautiful Ferrari and said that his dad and him will have a chat when they get home. His self discovery is something a lot of people can relate to. Overall the story of ferris bueller is one about living life to the fullest and not wasting opportunities. As ferris says "life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop to look around every once and awhile, you might miss it." This movie is a classic and one I can watch a million times over. I suggest that if you are fan of comedy and teenage high school films then this movie is the one for you
