I hadn't really watched this movie in a while, but I just finished it again. Good lord, man, it's some quality film making.  I mean, honestly, I was surprised.Don't get me wrong, I mean, It's always had a special place in my heart. But I never thought of it as real 'art,' or even as a 'film.'  It was just some amusing little footnote.  But lo, I was wrong.  Not only is this an exceptionally well assembled film (noting accomplished film editor Paul Hirsch), but there is some real merit to the subject matter.  The writing is smart and pointed in criticism of the mundane.  I don't wish to deeply examine the metaphors here, but the inter-cutting between Cameron (Alan Ruck) and "sunday afternoon in the park," by Seurat (actually, I'm not sure about the painting, but that sounds right) was a particularlly nice touch.And since I mentioned him, Alan Ruck delivered an amazing performance as Cameron.  All of the actors were in fine form here, and subtle measures including shots of pivoting feet or hand gestures show the director Alan Hughes' expertise in the craft;  however Alan Ruck is particularly noteworthy.  The character of Cameron is a quietly multi-dimensional one. Whatever his situation throughout the film, he retains another level of, well, pain.  He is the suffering one.  He has had a loveless childhood.  He is nervous about having stolen his father's car.  He is resentful of Ferris for having all the luck.  All of these things are apparent throughout the performance.  Not once does Ruck let you forget that he is unhappy, even if he might crack a smile or two.  Truly impressive.I was very sad to discover the fates of those who worked on this film.  At the time of this commentary, John Hughes has written Home Alone 3.  Ruck is wasting his talent on an ABC sitcom (albeit an amusing one).  Broderick most recently starred in the farsical slaughter of one of the big screen's most beloved monsters (Godzilla) and is currently at work on the Hollywood adaptation of Inspector Gadget.Whatever will be, I suppose.

reviews.review_title: A film everyone who was young once needs to see

reviews.review_title: No other movie embodies the 80's like this one.
reviews.content: If I were to pick ONE  movie that embodied the 80's, it would be "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".  Ferris' asides to the camera add to his charm and wit, the soundtrack is right on key, the casting dead on, and the entire movie flows with the pace of someone who got up 1/2 hour late for school in the morning.  Ferris' ability to get away with it all is kept very much alive throughout the film.John Hughes has crafted a delightful film that's funny all over, touching where it needs to be, and has the many signature elements that Hughes films are known for (the impending doom at the front door, teen angst, a number of great cameos, but, alas, no Molly Ringwald).  This film also gave us a number of the sound bytes that you hear so often today (Ben Stein's "Bueller...Bueller" and the spoken-in-one-breath update on Ferris' condition by then not-quite-known Kristy Swanson).This film is Hughes at his best, and Broderick in probably his biggest, best role (or at least his most memorable).  How they could try to follow this with a sitcom was beyond me.  This is definitely not a movie that could be sequelized - Let this one stand alone.  It's fine the way it is.  If it ain't broke, don't fix it.

The negative comments that I'm reading is that the life of Ferris and his buddies isn't realistic. NO KIDDING! That really isn't the point of the film; in fact, one of the most striking characteristics about FBDO is that it makes a point of reminding you that you're watching a movie. Ferris addresses the audience (one of the first to ever do so as a regular feature of the film); film sequences are tweaked to emphasize certain scenes (such as Jeannie kicking Rooney in the face and then bolting upstairs before he seemingly hits the ground), and the Ferrarri getting about 5 feet of air. None of this is the slightest bit realistic, but it's great fun to watch, and so is the rest of this movie. It's *supposed* to be over-the-top. That's the whole point.The great thing about this movie is that it uses all its elements in perfect harmony. The clothing is '80s, but not *too* '80s--miniskirts and hockey jerseys will always be in. The music is classic, not overly-familiar, overplayed '80s anthems. The scenery is pure Chicago. Ferris and Cameron are very believable as long-time buddies, and the other characters play off each other perfectly. The dialogue is brilliant. The comic scenes are hilarious, and the parade scene makes you want to shake it up right along with the movie. It's a great film by a great movie-maker who was smart enough to know exactly how far to go, unlike today's directors who would undoubtedly have sequeled and merchandised it to death. (Not that they didn't try to make a TV show out of it back in the day.) It is the quintessence of everything that was good about the '80s, and that's why it's a classic.

reviews.review_title: Get a Life,go take a DAY-OFF
reviews.content: I went about watching this flick after a lot of persuasion from one of my friends,and boy,did I enjoy it! I generally don't write Comments and just rate them,but for this flick,well it was different.This movie isn't your run of the mill teenage comedy stuff like the American Pie series, but actually makes you believe that this genre can also be entertaining without the raunchy humor that typifies such flicks.Ferris is the kind of person that makes it impossible for you not to desire to be his friend. He's fun to hang out with,he can make you get rid of your problems,and if not,take the blame on his shoulder,just as Cameron discovers. If you had a friend like Ferris during your high school years, you should definitely consider yourself very fortunate.Ferris,in his fun trip around Chicago,takes his girlfriend and best friend along and tries to make it special for Cameron,who leads a very mundane life. He tries to relieve him of his fears and as we see towards the end,Cameron learns to stand up for himself.A thoroughly enjoyable movie,and a must see when you get your day off.My Rating, 4 n a 1/2 out of 5.

This movie simply cannot be subjected to being graded by the same criteria as any other movie. It is completely original. To attempt to assess the acting in this movie is just stupid and pretentious. I have yet to see a movie that stands out in my collection (which is considerably large) as does this. Whether you are looking for depth or just comedy, which i think this movie achieves with class. Aimed at a younger generation of the time, it's truly surprising how much credit this movie gives to its audience; the esoteric conversations, the humor-in-dialogue-form, and the lack of crudeness is significantly above meant-for-the-average. This movie delivers any message a viewer may wish to find with class such that the movie/characters establish(es) an almost intimate relationship with the audience which must feel flattered by the highly intelligent work of art this movie is. It's a compliment to its viewer. Ten out of ten.

Not exactly the greatest movie ever made and not the funniest movie ever made. Those would be the Godfather and Airplane!, respectively. It's just a feel good movie about a likeable and heroic kid. I know most of this movie by heart and have made some of my friends fans. One of the best things to come out of the 80s and an indespensible(?) classic.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of my all time favorites. It is an Excellent movie about seeing your own personal value and realizing your potential. I think a little bit of every character lives inside us and it is that constant struggle that makes this life fun. At times we are much like Cameron; conservative, unhappy, and insecure. Other times we are like Ferris; uninhibited, fun-loving, and relaxed. We all need to realize that we control our lives and determine our future. I think Cameron put it best when he said, "I am not going to sit on my ass as the events that affect me unfold to determine the course of my life. I'm going to take a stand. I'm going to defend it. Right or wrong, I'm going to defend it." We should all strive to be memorable in this life, to take some advice from Ferris. "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it."I think John Hughes knew what he was doing when he made this movie and I'm grateful to him for it.I give it a 10 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Age is just a number-not a limit to the imagination!
reviews.content: Such a feel good film! This masterpiece is absolutely brilliant! It encapsulates perfectly the feelings of thousands of teens who can only dream of ditching a whole day of school-simply because they don't 'feel' like learning today...I definitely know how it feels: you've had to get up at some silly time in the morning just to attend registration, (*cough* scare small children as you look like a Shaun of the dead extra *cough*); you end up sitting next to some poor child who has an unfortunate bodily odour beast of a problem, and the plan of attempting suicide with a ruler or launching yourself out the window gradually becomes more appealing when your teacher is about as exciting as a pile of mud. Ferris Bueller is a role model to those who's only wish is to live on the edge and take every opportunity that is thrown your way! Everyone should act like Ferris Bueller in some way or another-just to make life that bit more interesting. This film has made me promise myself that I will NEVER become a boring adult with a monotone voice, and that, no matter how old I am, if there's a chance for me to sing whilst on a parade float, I will definitely take that chance! :D

reviews.review_title: Best movie I've seen this year
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) just can't take it and needs a ninth day off from school--so after tricking his parents into thinking he was sick, forcing help from his hypochondriac best friend, Cameron (Alan Ruck), and sneaking his girlfriend (Mia Sara) out of school, Ferris is ready to wreak havoc in Chicago. But, of course, it's all fun and games until someone puts a Ferrari in danger.I'm from the generation of High School Musical and Hannah Montana, so seeing a movie with this kind of quality was a big surprise. My friend made me watch it with her, but I ended up being the one who forced her to wait and watch the end because I loved it so much. It has real, good, clean comedy that doesn't need to use dirty or offensive jokes to make people laugh. This is real entertainment.

"Ferris Bueller's Day Off" was one of the greatest comedies from the 80's. It still holds up great to this day. The comedy was great, I love all the characters and they are all relate-able (the guy who gets off scott free, the neurotic, the asshole teacher, etc.), and this is the third Matthew Broderick film that I enjoyed him in (The Lion King & Bee Movie are the other two)! But I think the teachers were too mean spirited and there were some parts in the movie that could have been cut out. For what it is though, it was a great film. If you happen to find a copy of "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," pick it up and give it a try.Also Ben Steins sandpaper emotions are funnier here than they were in Casper and Son of the Mask.

reviews.review_title: On the face of it, a hilarious comedy but something deeper is what makes this a classic
reviews.content: While there are many hilarious scenes within this film such as prank calling the head of the school, singing in a chicago parade or the constant references to ferris dying and the entire city rooting for him, the real stand out factor of this film is the relationship between the main trio and what it presents.Cameroon fry is a depressed high school kid who's father neglects him compared to a car. He is not interested in anything and doesn't believe he is capable of anything. Compared to this, Ferris Bueller is the kid that always gets everything right and to people like Cameroon, it seems they can never get anything wrong. While we may not all have faced neglect by our parents, at some point we can all say that we related to Cameroon feeling down and out with no prospects and wanted to be like Ferris, the guy with the gorgeous girlfriend, supporting and loving parents and loads of popularity and confidence.Whats so great about the chemistry between the trio, apart from the great acting by all three actors, is that Sloane and Ferris are not arrogant in their popularity. They have a loyal and loving relationship together and are supportive and caring for Cameroon even in his strangest or lowest moments (the pool scene). Their main concern towards the last 20 minutes of the film is about Cameroon and if he's truly going to be ok without them.The triumphant ending for all three is a great one and the museam scene is absolutely iconic.
This is a classic. Good for any day off. Kanye used this character in "Gotta Have It". Pure gold.
Looking back at high school, I see how pointless and what a joke it was.  I just wish I had used Ferris' attitude when the time was right...

This is one of my favorite all time films.  It`s not one of those big money, action non-stop, Hollywood productions - it`s just a classic film that has everything you could want.  Humor.  Excellent characters.  Good Acting.  I  first watched it at college, about 8/9 years ago. We used to put it on every day and watch our favorite bits (another good thing about it is that you can just watch various scenes if you like) my favorite being the one where Cameron makes the phone call to Ed Rooney. If you`ve not seen this film, you really must.

Watchable and infinitely re-watchable. Loved it when it first came out nearly (gulp) 20 years ago and whenever airing on television (unexpurgated version, please). Great journey into the day of the life of a high school anti-hero and his escapades throughout Chicago. Entire cast shines (especially Broderick, Jeffrey Jones--as his belabored principal, Jennifer Grey as Ferris' hissy-fit sister, the pencil-headed Edie McClurg, and Charlie Sheen as a young hoodlum). John Hughes' best film, hands down. One of the best comedies of the 1980s and still fresh as ever. A great DVD rental, too, particularly when double-billed with ELECTION, Alexander Payne's dark comedy in which Broderick, now cast as a high school teacher, meets his match with a conniving student--a much darker Ferris.

I loved this movie, of course.  Hilarious.  But has anyone else noticed how Cameron Frye(Alan Ruck) is the only character who undergoes any change in character of any sort?  Without him, the film would consist of one really clever guy to be jealous of, and that's it.  We can relate to Cameron(him and that girl in the Seurat painting).  We understand his pain.  Let's face it: we love him.  He makes the movie what it is.  Way to go, Cameron!

reviews.review_title: The feel-good film of all time
reviews.content: Ferris is my hero.  He lives life the way it should be lived, and the world is a better place for it.  Occasionally profound, always likeable and funny, this is a film that everyone should see.  Especially on a wet Wednesday afternoon, because it will cheer you up - guaranteed.The performances by the lead actors are superb, and Broderick gives his lifetime best portrayal.  The direction is spot on, although quintessentially a Hughes 1980s film.  The editing is also good, as short set piece scenes give the film an upbeat  rhythm.A friend of mine compared this film to Wayne's World.  But Ferris' talks to camera are infinitely more assured than Wayne, and Cameron is a believable character.  Minor criticisms are the overdose of slapstick and the fact that the day seems to last for ever.  But we want it to last forever.Make everyone you know see this film.

reviews.review_title: An integral part of my 80's upbringing
reviews.content: This movie is a modern day classic. My childhood, and the 80's, would not have been the same without it. I never get sick of watching this movie. We all wish we could pack as much into one day as Ferris, Cameron and Sloane do. I love Ferris - we all love Ferris - save Ferris!

reviews.review_title: a wonderful, hilarious and entertaining film.
reviews.content: i loved this movie- it was so funny! in fact, it is my favorite movie. ferris bueller is the guy that every kid wants to be. he is popular and cute and everything seems to work out for him. i suggest seeing this movie because it is very entertaining!

Ahh, Ferris Bueller's Day Off.  This is one of "those" films.  You know the ones.  Like "The Adventures of Ford Fairlane" and the Star Wars Trilogy, this is one of those compulsory films that every healthy young'un should have already seen at least once by the time I'm writing this.  A brilliant post-modern, post-generation-x comedy that I think Kevin Smith has looked to as inspiration and influence for his films Clerks, Mallrats, Chasing Amy and Dogma.  Just go rent it.  If you have taste, you won't be disappointed. And if you are disappointed, well, you're a fool.  Simple.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is my favorite movie ever. I've seen it about 40 times.  As a side note, I think it's a good thing that the 1990 tv series (with Jennifer Aniston as Jeanie) failed. I never saw it, but it couldn't possibly have done John Hughes' wonderful movie any justice.  I can't think of anything else intelligent to say about it right now, because I'm really tired.

reviews.review_title: I've watched this film so many times it's a part of who I am!
reviews.content: Ferris Bueller's Day Off is the best movie ever made. It's at once hilarious and heart-rending, absurd and down-to-earth. I was born three years before its release, and it's one of the earliest movies I remember seeing. I watched it so much during my formative years, and still do, that it is an inextricable part of who I am. A quote from the movie that fits the situation I'm in perfectly often springs to my head, and I drive my family crazy reciting all the dialogue each time I watch it. So many things about this movie ring true - friendship, teen stress, the need to have a day off once in a while. I think most of John Hughes' other movies (with the possible exception of The Breakfast Club) are poor excuses for a window on teen life, but he must be applauded for this one, as must the actors, writers, and everyone else involved. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a truly great film.

reviews.review_title: The film that influenced a generation (well - me, anyway).
reviews.content: I make a point of watching this film at least once a month. There's something fundamentally timeless about this film (like Weird Science and The Breakfast Club) that captures the imagination. I grew up with this film, I can quote huge chunks verbatim and yet I still p**s myself with laughter every time Jeff Jones has the "Nine Times" discussion with Cindy Pickett.There are many things to love about this (not least the 250 GT California) and I'm eagerly awaiting the UK DVD release. The only problem with this film is that I find it difficult to watch any of the actors in anything else - I half expect Matt Broderick and Alan Ruck to turn into Ferris and Cameron in every other thing I see them in. As for Jeff Jones... words are not enough. This film is my love, it is my passion... and it is my fault I don't rewatch it as often as I should.

reviews.review_title: I have an intense crush on Ferris Bueller.
reviews.content: ... And this entire movie!  The cast is just hilarious and the dialogue is "so choice."  I admit, I am a fan of cheesy teen 80s movies in general, and an even bigger fan of John Hughes, but this... Ferris Bueller is a clean movie and yet he's become the sneaky slacker that practically a generation either wants to be or wants to know.  As a teenager, I give this my snarky adolescent seal of approval.

reviews.review_title: A teenage feel-good movie that could've held more
reviews.content: "Ferris Bueller's day off" is an overall feel-good feature film that easily relates and reaches the teenage audience. It's capable of brightening anyone's day, but struggles to keep the viewers attention throughout the entirety of the film.The overarching plot line is about a high school senior, played by Matthew Broderick, who decides to fake an illness and skip school when he hears about the very promising weather forecast. He then lures his reluctant best friends, Cameron (Alan Ruck), and his very willing girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara), into his fun-filled day off from school, all while he's trying to avoid being caught by, his parents, his sister, and the principal all at the same time.Matthew Broderick has to play Hughes' attempt at what an essential teen, might be, hoping to create the perfect teen movie, after not quite getting there from "The Breakfast Club" or "Sixteen Candles". Yet, Broderick does quite a good job depicting a feel good teen who isn't caring about the past or the future. This directly appeals to teens because most of them can relate to the theme of not knowing about the future, and essentially not caring.Where the film lacks is in the plot line, catching the audience's attention on this fun ride through Chicago narrowly avoiding trouble. After less than an hour though, not much really changes and it can get repetitive, failing to keep the viewers attention through the whole movie. It lacks movement as pretty much the same things are repeating without much intensity growing throughout. Just about the only thing attempting at keeping the intensity up is the music, which hosts some feel good, and upbeat songs.The most important theme in the movie is actually quite striking, that being Cameron's abusive relationship with his father. While his father is never seen in the movie, he is represented through his expensive car that he owns. It's a good theme a good amount of the audience can actually relate to. We can see this specific theme portrayed in one of the scenes where Cameron is fixated on an oil painting in a museum specifically looking at a kid in the painting. Cameron seemingly learns more from this experience than he ever did in school, and we can see him change in his thoughts and behavior after this scene. Another important key theme is the fear of what's next. It's shared between all three teen characters in the movie that they don't know what's next in their life, where Ferris fears what's going to happen when he's goes off to college, and Cameron claiming he's not interested in anything. This key theme is about the most relatable to teenage viewers and is what allows them to grip on to the movie."Ferris Bueller's day off" is a feel good movie depicting teens that just want to have fun without a care in the world, yet it struggles to grip the attention of most viewers, really only relating to teens with a few important key themes. Overall, it is a fun watch that won't necessarily strike as an important movie that must be seen.
Good for a passtime but it can be a bit predictable and sometimes silly.

This movie is a true classic. I believe it withstands the test of time. Remember when all you wanted was a day off from school? I sat down with my 15-year-old son and it was incredible watching his reactions to the movie. Except for the outdated technology in the film, it's all the same things kids are still trying to get away with today and still wish they could pull off. This movie takes you back to relive those days of carefree fun. Kids growing up in any time period can relate to this. I recommend any parent to be present the first time your kids watches this. Sit back and watch as they enjoy the same scenes you enjoyed at that age.

reviews.review_title: The greatest movie to ever be created by humankind.
reviews.content: This movie, in many ways, has shaped my life.I can't watch this movie enough times. Ever since I was a young boy I would watch it over and again. Even now I will watch it and laugh out loud. It never gets old. I could probably quote this movie verbatim.The main thing that I have gleaned from this amazing film is that no matter what is happening around you, you control the outcome of your actions. You determine whether or not life is wonderful. That is something Cameron had to learn the hard way.FBDO has also taught me that if you set your mind to something then you will live in your own mind set. Ferris was not only an optimist, but he also took steps to live out his dreams. It did not matter how impossible these steps seemed to be, he still executed every step until his dreams were in the now.Cameron, on the other hand, did the same thing but moving in the opposite direction. He also was living his mind set but was not happy with his life. Cameron had to be shown how to change his thinking in order to live without fear. Ferris in many ways represents a savior while Cameron represents the saved.

reviews.content: This is not a sophisticated movie, it's light at first glance but contains a few nuggets of wisdom. The characters are endearing: the bitter sister, the foolish school principal, the uptight teenager filled with angst, etc.I love Ferris, he's fun and wacky. He knows how to take risks to enjoy life, some would say too much risk, at the expense of his friend. But he knows how to a day off to appreciate life.I own very few movies. But I have this one on an old VHS tape. When I feel blue about life, I plug it in and remember to "stop and look around". That is what I take from this movie. A philosophy. "Ferris Bueller, you're my hero!"

reviews.review_title: A MUST SEE!!!! Classic 80's "feel good" movie!!!
reviews.content: If they could only make more movies like this.  The plot is simple as it is about what happens when the slick "know-it-all" high school senior takes a day off school to hang with his best friend and girlfriend.  My only criticism of the movie was the way the characters had to analyze themselves ( a John Hughes staple ala "Breakfast Club", "Sixteen Candles", "Weird Science") and look deep within themselves to come to some sort of realization about who they really are. The few moments this happens you stop laughing, though only for a minute.There is no doubt that the casting for this movie was outstanding.  The secretary and Ed Rooney are absolutely hilarious.  The mother, father, and sister "Jeannie/Shawna" were great selections.  Cameron plays the cynical/pessimistic best friend part beautifully, and what is not to like about Mia Sara.This is nothing but a good, funny movie that you don't need to think about, just sit back and enjoy.

reviews.content: While others did not really care for a similar movie, Eurotrip, it has become one of my favorite comedies that tied into my childhood. Many of my friends recommended Ferris Bueller's Day Off and I was skeptical at first since it was filmed before my time.I can now say that this is just as funny as current comedies if not even funnier. You get a connection between other movies such as Road Trip, Eurotrip, and American Pie, although I can say this is a distinct film all in its own. Cameron, who is played by Alan Ruck, in my opinion was the funniest of all the characters. Overall, I was not disappointed!

I would buy another copy of ferris buellers day off because it just that goodExcellent Job to all of the people that helped make ferris Bueller famous!

reviews.content: This film is sheer genius. It's one of those films like High Fedelity or the Breakfast Club; they seem to have a plot that can only go so far and then get boring. Somehow they all end up being the most amazing films i have ever, or will ever see.The plot of 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off' is simple, our young Ferris decides to take a day off school...From this simple start ferris shows his friends one of the most memorable days they will have for a long time. Whilst dodging detection from his parents and his jealous sister Jeanie, whom you may remember from 'Dirty Dancing' (he said with a pained smile on his face) Ferris tries to show his girlfriend Slone (huba huba) and best friend Cameron all that the city has to offer.Amidst all this confusion one man makes it his personal mission to catch Ferris and bring him to justice...Ed Runey, the dean. You may be familiar with this technique being used in the popular hit TV series 'Saved by the Bell' and if it worked for them i can tell you it worked for Ferris. Big time =]

I don't believe many perfect movies have ever been made but this is surely one. Bueller... has barely dated since it's release which, for a film about young people and city/suburban life, is an astonishing achievement. What it has in spades is sincerity and authenticity - qualities that set many of John Hughes' movies apart - combined with a ripping script. What I like most about this movie is that it is entirely devoid of sex and violence and can be enjoyed by "everyone in the family" (not that I don't enjoy sex and violence in movies but many of the best movies - Casino being a case in point - are not really suitable in the same way). I would honestly recommend this move to absolutely anyone.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off Movie Review"Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it." Though life may move pretty fast, Director John Hughes's Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one film you don't want to miss. Though this film is nearly 25 years old, it is considered to be a classic amongst teens and enthusiasts of 1980's culture everywhere. A well-developed story, believable acting, and the unique directing insight of John Hughes make this film worthy of a Golden Globe nomination, and a must see for anyone looking for an entertaining blast to the past. The premise of Ferris Bueller's Day Off is simple but something everyone can relate to. Ferris Bueller, played by Matthew Broderick, (War Games, The Producers) is an 18-year old High School Senior just weeks from graduating who fakes sick to enjoy one of his last days of spring with his best friend, Cameron (Alan Ruck, Spin City) and his girlfriend, Sloane (Mia Sara, Birds of Prey) to explore the metropolis of Chicago, IL. Ferris and his friends take a grand tour of Chicago in Cameron's father's extremely rare vintage Ferrari sports car, making appearances at Wrigley Field, The Art Institute of Chicago, and the Sears Tower. While "the sportos, the motorheads, geeks, sluts, bloods, wastoids, dweebies, and dickheads" (who all adore Bueller) rally support to fight Ferris' rumored life-threatening condition, Principal Rooney, (Jeffery Jones, Amadeus) and his sister, Jeanie, (Jennifer Grey, Red Dawn) do everything in their power to catch Ferris in the act of skipping school. Though Ferris uses his charm, wit, and improvised acting to slip through the grasp of pursuers, the care-free joyride the trio takes turns out to be more than they bargained for. The climax of the film kept me on the edge of my seat, constantly wondering if Ferris would make it through the day without being caught. By the end of the film viewers will feel satisfied with the conclusion, but hungry to hear more about the characters and their futures. Matthew Broderick's portrayal of Ferris Bueller is outstanding. Broderick spent many years sharpening his skills in formal acting training focusing mainly on theater, and his performance reflects that. Ferris is a smart-mouthed, cocky, and daring teenager willing to do anything to encourage others to laugh and have a good time. Like many teenagers, his hobbies include skipping school, killing time with his friends, and praying that one day he will have a car of his own. The iconic "Parade" and "French Restaurant" scenes show off Broderick's ability to be charismatic and commanding in a lead role, separating him from many of the cheesy, over-the-top actors of the 1980's. Though War Games is considered to be Broderick's breakout role, Ferris Bueller's Day Off will be easily remembered as his greatest work. Alan Ruck plays the role of Cameron Frye, Ferris's sickly best friend who worries that a reckless cruise in his father's Ferrari will end in complete disaster. Cameron is arguably the most complex character of the film, as he struggles with depression, conflict with his parents, and disillusionment with the world around him, like many teenagers in the 1980's. Though Ruck was nearly 30 years old when he joined the cast as Cameron, he convincingly plays a teen that is not in control of his own life. As the film progresses, the viewer sympathizes with Cameron, and secretly crosses their fingers that he will recover from the problems he faces. Ruck secured his place in this classic because of his goofy sidekick role, quality acting skills, and his ability to evoke emotion from the actors on screen as well as the viewers. Mia Sara plays the role of Sloane Peterson, Ferris's popular girlfriend. After the boys impersonate Sloane's father to have her released from school, she joins the pair in their adventure around Chicago. Unlike Broderick and Ruck, Sara had little experience in Hollywood, but it hardly shows in Ferris Bueller's Day Off. Like Ferris, Sloane loves fun and adventure, and wants to have one last good day with her boyfriend before he graduates. Sara's performance is emotionally genuine and authentic to the mentality of a 1980's teenager, as she was one at the time of the film's production. Though many actresses were auditioned to play the role of Sloane, I feel that Mia Sara was complementary to Broderick and Ruck, making her perfect for the part. Ferris Bueller's Day Off is known as one John Hughes's best films. Hughes wrote and directed this film, as well as the "Brat Pack" classics, Sixteen Candles, Pretty in Pink, and The Breakfast Club. Unlike many movies of that era, Hughes wrote characters that were complex, with desires and problems that many teens to this day can still relate with. The camera style as scene in the rest of his films returns; unique and visually appealing. The sound track features many classic songs of the 1980's, including Bueller's own rendition of The Beatles' "Twist and Shout". As long as there are high school students who are eager to get more out of life than learning from a monotonous economics teacher and gym class this film will remain relevant. Without the unique vision and clever writing skills of John Hughes however, this film may have flopped. Though the era of the 1980's is slowly fading from the conscious of our culture, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is likely to remain as popular as always. The stellar writing and directing of Hughes, a unique story, and a perfectly selected cast make this film a rare gem. I urge everyone who needs a good laugh to skip school and watch Ferris Bueller's Day Off, you won't be disappointed.

After seeing this film as many times as I have (too many to count), you may think that maybe i would get bored of it. Never going to happen. I believe that this film is not only the best teen movie that has ever been made, but also the defining movie of the 1980's. Although essentially a comedy, the film shows the essence of life as a teenager through brilliant performances by Matthew Broderick and Alan Ruck. Broderick's Ferris is a wonderful character neither stereotype nor overbearing persona, and John Hughes yet again creates genius through the character of Cameron, played by Alan Ruck - who was 30 at the time!Many may disagree, but for me the best lines in the whole film are Camerons - 'When Cameron walked in Egypt land...... Let my Cameron go' wonderfully delivered to convey the characters stifled existence in his home life and the pressures of being the best friend of such a man as Ferris. In all, teen comedies don't get better than this. 10/10

I loved this film in its entirety! I liked how fresh an outlook Ferris's character had, he really makes you feel excited about life. I like how the film was more about the people in Ferris's life growing and developing for themselves, in healthier if not better ways than they were already. Apart from the poor prick of a principle/headmaster, every character had a 'happy ending.' It isn't just a film, it's an encouragement for anyone who watches it. For me it says that people can be crazy happy and have their own spontaneous fun in life, not everything needs to be planned out and 'safe by the books'. I loved this film and I loved how it makes me, (and my friends), feel. A definite MUST watch. :)

reviews.review_title: Bueller! Next time you are sick, call me up.
reviews.content: This is a perfect movie to watch when you yourself are pulling a sicky. A popular High School boy decides to skip school and make the most of his day with his friend and girlfriend, while the principle as well as Ferris' sister try to blow his cover. It has enough believability for you to love the characters, and enough heart for you to sympathize with them. The comedy is sometimes subtle and crispy, sometimes so quirky and over the top that you just let it slide and enjoy it. I love the clueless parents and the whole late 80's vibe. Plus a cool soundtrack. Still not sure of Broderick, tho he is rather fabulous in this him, but good god do i not forgive you for Godzilla 1998!!! Looking for an enjoyable comedy, try this breaking-the-fourth-wall rebellious riot.

reviews.review_title: One of my top favourites of all time
reviews.content: I had the luck to be 17 when I watched this film at the cinema. I didn't know what it was all about before, the movie poster just looked inviting. But I didn't expect to see one of the few movies I'll watch over and over again my whole life!Many fellows have already told enough about the plot, so I can concentrate on my personal impressions. The film is simply about enjoying life and taking a day off sometimes to do just that, no matter what circumstances. Although the 1980s setting may seem a bit dated to some viewers today - as the very American setting is still a bit strange to viewers from other countries - the movie hasn't lost a bit of its actuality. It's pure fun, combined with unexpected twists and turns, a bit of wisdom and a genius cast. Matthew Broderick is in his best role ever, closely followed by his appearance in "War Games", and his teenage looks still make it nearly impossible for me to accept him in any of his later films ("Hey, what's Ferris doing in that movie?").To round it all up, the perfect choice of music makes this movie the outstanding work of director John Hughes, although all his other teenager films are real gems, too!To put it in a nutshell: If you are in your teens, don't ever miss that movie! But be careful, it may seriously affect your whole life!10/10 (and just a handful of movies get that from me!)

This is one of the best comedy movie i have ever seen.Right from the start movie engages the audience and builds the character of Ferris Bueller played by Matthew Broderick,who is a fun loving,full of life and very clever fella liked by everyone. The movie also makes you realize how important it is that you enjoy life as it comes and conquer your fears. However for me and many others that is exactly what makes the movie awesome. We suspend belief and just go with the story and enjoy the ride. In many ways I feel like I'm giving it too high of a score, but Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a movie that has a bunch of moving parts, all of which move pretty much flawlessly, and while none of the characters are the deepest in motion picture history, they all work well in their respective roles.  Mathew Broderick is legitimately excellent as the titular Ferris Bueller, a fun fourth-wall breaking character (almost like a semi-slacker predecessor to Wayne & Garth) who is just barely able to ride the line between being Endearing and being Smug.  A lot of this comes from the fact that, despite there is certainly a mild narcissistic element to Ferris' character, he is also almost obsessed with making those around him happy, and honestly, I think it's this facet to the main character that has given this film its longevity.  The rest of the Cast do well with their respective roles, albeit much of them are toned-down caricatures, however the infinitely-underappreciated Alan Ruck deserves some serious props as well, as his character largely lives in a self-induced misery (caused perhaps by some mild but genuine neuroses), however his story is actually one tinged with a soft, long-lasting sadness due to his parents' (unseen in the movie, a wise choice in my opinion) intense emotional distance from him, as well as from each other.  Alan Ruck's Cameron is, in a sense, the beating-heart of the film, bolstering Ferris' more empathetic side, and this allows the movie to feel a lot more endearing by the end than it otherwise would.  And for that, I do genuinely kinda love this movie -- It's breezy, it's fun, it's never mean-spirited (at least never intensely or for more than a few seconds), and it has a softer side that's genuinely welcome.

It's a funny gag, there's even an post-credits scene where he approaches the camera asking why the audience is /still/ there and tells them to go home. While I did watch this movie in my house, the line did get a couple chuckles out of me. The premise is incredibly simple: teen gets friends together, skips school, and causes shenanigans throughout the city while a skeptical principal (Jeffrey Jones) pursues him. Oh right! The dynamic between the principal as well as Bueller's sister (played by Dirty Dancing actress Jennifer Grey) and Ferris creates some of the funniest moments. It's a cat and mouse game, like Tom And Jerry, between them and is incredibly entertaining to watch.

Now I know this will sound iffy, but Ferris Bueller is and can be a positive role model, just depends on how you look at it. Yes he cuts school and makes risky decisions throughout, but it's all in good fun. And for those of us like Cameron Fry, sometimes we need to just let loose and have fun every now and again. It is not until the 3rd act that he becomes a 3 dimensional character, and we begin to understand him, and realize he is not the sociopath we might have assumed he is. While is seems he does all the things he does for his own pleasure, it becomes clear in the last 20 minutes he was really doing it for his friend. At the beginning of the movie, Cameron is timid, constantly worried, and unsure of himself.  We learn his parents argue, and his dad neglects him, and would rather work on his Ferrari instead of spend time with hi son. Throughout the movie, Ferris tries to boost his friends self-esteem, and by the end he has succeeded. His friend is a completely different person, and most of the major characters are, notably his sister. However, Ferris doesn't seem to change at all. He helps his friends become a better people, but in doing so, he isn't changing at all.

Watched 1 Of The Late Great John Hughes' Cinematic Classics Of The 1980s: The 1986 Comedy "Ferris Bueller's Day Off". Now 1st Off, I Admire John Hughes' Writing In "The Breakfast Club" (1985) & Such, & Even Though I'm Not A Matthew Broderick Fan, But In THIS Flick, He's Actually Likeable & Funny; He Has Some Charm & Cleverness, 2 Things You Wouldn't Expect Out Of An Actor Like Him. Now With Broderick Aside, The Writing By Hughes Is Funny, Clever, & Full Of Both "Holy Fuck!" Moments & Incoming Surprises.

Some Elements I Feel Must Have Inspired John Hughes To Write "Home Alone" (1990) A Few Years Later. Specifically In The Scenes Where We See The Traps Ferris Set Up At His House. The Film Uses 1 Breaking-The-4th-Wall Joke By Having Ferris Talking To The Audience & The Film Doesn't Let That Go Too Far To When It Becomes Annoying. Ferris' Sister, Jeanie Bueller, Played By The Gorgeous Jennifer Grey Of "Dirty Dancing" (1987), Kinda Reminds Me Of Candace From The Disney Show "Phineas & Ferb", Just By How She Tries To Deduce Her Brother's Lies Just As Much As His Principal, Edward Rooney, Played By Jeffery Jones, Is! And How Jeanie Learns Her Lesson To Not Care So Much About Ferris From The Ruffian At The Police Station, Quickly Becoming His Girlfriend, Haha, It's A Good Lesson For Siblings In Families To Not Worry About What Goes On In The Other's Life.

As A Whole, The Film Seems To Present Itself As The Jack-In-The-Box Of Teenage Road-Trip Comedies: There's Several Surprises Sprinkled In The Least-Expected Moments. Not As Deep As Something Like "The Breakfast Club", But "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" Has A Creative Story That Just Wants You To Come Along With Our Main Trio & Enjoy Their Day Off With Them. I'd Say This '80s Classic Is Definitely Worth 103 Minutes Of Your Time.

I've recently had the pleasure of re-watching the classic cinematic masterpiece that is Ferris Bueller's Day Off. This movie encapsulates the teenage dream, even 34 years after its release. Matthew Brodrick as Ferris Bueller, Mia Sara as his girlfriend Sloane Peterson, and Alan Ruck as his best friend Cameron Frye, are all talented and encapsulate their roles excellently, though they are over aged for these roles. Jeffrey Jones as Ed Rooney and Jennifer Grey as Jeanie Bueller both do fantastic jobs of epitomizing the insanity of stiff-necked individuals trying to catch a teenager in a lie that only hurts themselves. Ferris, Jeanie, and Rooney's plot lines are masterfully woven together in the end, leading to chapter development for Jeanie and Cameron, even over just a single day. Ferris asks big life questions, leading the audience down similar roads. Overall, this movie can be just about anything you want it to be? A comedy? Check! A fun movie leading to an existential crisis? Also check!

A film as beloved as this one has had so much said about it but I think what it comes down to is that this is an extremely entertaining diversion. It is hardly meaningful and it is not the meaningful paean about self discovery that some believe it to be but it features a great soundtrack, a genius central performance and some beautifully choreographed shots. Few films have made a city look as wonderful as this film makes Chicago appear and as they move through all of the famous tourist sites we realize that we are watching a very well packaged, glossy travelogue. All of this makes the film worth watching and when you want to relax and not put yourself through the emotional strain of Ship of Fools (1965) or Room at the Top (1959).

Smug high school student Ferris Bueller, Matthew Broderick, regularly fakes being sick so he can take a day off school and spend his time with his girlfriend Sloane Peterson, Mia Sara, and emotionally traumatized best friend Cameron Frye, Alan Ruck. This angers his sister Jeanie, Jennifer Grey, who does not break the rules like he does and she wants to see him punished for his actions. Bueller maneuvers to get his girlfriend out of school by pretending to be her father and incurs the wrath of school principal Mr. Rooney, Jeffrey Jones, who tries to track him down throughout the day. Bueller has more of a struggle getting Frye to come with him as he is afraid of even leaving his house and as Bueller wants to use his father's Ferrari which he worries his father will learn about it takes a lot of cajoling to get him to tag along with them. They travel through Chicago and enjoy themselves but at the end of the day they are all almost caught out.

The fun of the film comes in seeing a figure, a teenager, who is usually in a position where authority figures like his parents and schoolteachers control him is able to manipulate the system to gain freedom. He is smug and taunts those around him about the way that he has succeeded but at heart he does love his girlfriend and best friend and just wants to show them a good time. This is how most teenagers feel and the idea that you could actually control your own life and have fun doing it is appealing to hormonal, angst filled people. The villains in the film are also appropriately caricatured as his parents are politically conservative pushovers and the school principal is the sort of stickler for the rules that we all dislike. His girlfriend is a little too perfect as she is one of those 
‘cool' girls that male screenwriters love but this is a minor complaint as Hughes has written female characters with far less depth who face even more abusive treatment from the men around them.

The one part of the film that I did not like was the relationship that Frye has with his father and it is implied that he is overbearing and controlling but the film applies too much meaning to the idea of defiance. The climactic scene in which he pushes his father's Ferrari through the glass window and out into a ravine annoyed me as the film presents destroying an object valuable to your parents as the correct response to feelings of anger and resentment towards them. To have had Frye actually talk to his father or properly discuss his feelings about him to set up why he is so angry at him and would go to such lengths to attract his attention. I assume that there were a few extra scenes cut out of the film that would have done more to make this scene more poignant and understandable. I wanted to get into this part of the film as Frye is enigmatic at the beginning of the film and we are invested in his coming out of his shell but when the film tries to develop his backstory it fails to put us in his mindset.

You really will love the experience of watching this film even though it is flawed in developing some of the characters.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a 1986 coming of age comedy. The film was directed by John Hughes, and stars Matthew Broderick as Ferris Bueller and Alan Ruck as Cameron Frye.

The story follows Ferris Bueller a teenager who decides to skip a day off school. The story I found to be very strong and really enjoyable, especially once you hit the second act of the film.

In most films about teenagers the actors never feel like teenagers, but luckily for Ferris Bueller's Day Off the actors actually feel like the
characters their playing. The acting in my opinion was strong and very believable.

The characters are some of the most memorable that I've seen from a comedy in recent years, from how well they were portrayed to how much of a blast they were to watch on the big screen.

The cinematography was sound, with some very good shots of the characters and scenery, but nothing too spectacular.

The sets and costumes were also very strong, from Ferris Bueller's bedroom design to his and his friends iconic and stylish outfits.

The style of the film I personally really liked, from the coming of age feel to the fun and inventive fourth wall breaking. 

The film did also have some really quotable and memorable dialogue, from both the students and teachers.  

The comedy in my opinion is some of the greatest ever put to film, from the great fourth wall braking to the extremely funny Jeffrey Jones as Ed Rooney.

In my opinion Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of the most enjoyable films that I've ever seen, and I can't wait to watch it all over again.

Let's be honest . . . who here didn't try to play hooky at least once over the course of their academic career? Ferris Bueller happens to be king of the fake sick day and, using his ninth phony day off this semester, decides to show his hypochondriac friend Cameron and level-headed girlfriend Sloane the time of their lives. From admiring paintings in the Art Institute of Chicago to commandeering a parade float to perform in front of an almost magically absurd crowd - all while bending the laws of coincidence - this will be one day our three teenage heroes never forget.

John Hughes is the ultimate progenitor of exploring teen angst in cinema and "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is just one more in a string of classic comedies (including the oft-overlooked "Sixteen Candles" and the legendary malcontent manifesto "The Breakfast Club") that stood head-and-shoulders above their contemporaries. Hughes was note-perfect at writing incisive dialogue suited to the varied styles of his teenage protagonists while penetrating the very heart of human nature at the same time. It helps that Hughes always had stellar casts to work with.

The fourth-wall-breaking performance of Matthew Broderick is one of the best the Eighties ever saw and Broderick's on screen chemistry with Alan Ruck is convincing enough to make the viewer believe these two have been playing off of each other since kindergarten. Jeffrey Jones is a deliciously devilish amalgamation of high school principles while Jennifer Grey does her part as Bueller's sister who simply wants to escape the shadow of her spotlight-stealing brother and find a little recognition of her own. Even Charlie Sheen is on point doing his best Judd Nelson impersonation. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is a great example of the kind of heartwarming mischievousness from a more innocent age that we will probably never witness again on the silver screen.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986) is director John Hughes slacker anthem on the big screen. It's highly relatable to teenagers that just want out of school and to hang out with their friends. Every time I revisit this film, it always provides laughter and enjoyment. It's a blast of fourth wall breaks, Chicago sight seeing, and gallivanting with your pals.

John Hughes wrote and directed this pleasant trip with a nod to films like womanizing romance comedy films like Alfie (1966), which also broke the 4th wall to coming of age risque movies such as Risky Business (1983). It takes the romancing teenager with clever wit and poignant commentary on the social lives of suburban Americans. I found Cameron's monologue about his father's love to be even more biting than ever. Hughes had a knack for realistic dialogue from kids, while always trying to find the humor in odd situations. His direction goes from nice slow panning shots to blistering tracking shots and neat jump cuts between faces. This is Hughes on full steam ahead to nonsense and silly entertainment.

Matthew Broderick was the man after this film. His effortless charm and easy going attitude as Ferris Bueller taught us all to relax and appreciate the finer things in life a bit more. He is cool personified, even while being a truant miscreant of the highest caliber.

His friends Cameron and Sloane are really interesting unto themselves. Alan Ruck is hilarious as the dour and sickly Cameron. His nervous gasps and incessant hollering about his father's demands is so charming and relatable that Ruck may often steal the show from Broderick, especially towards the second half of Ferris Bueller's Day Off. His big monologue ranting about his father's expectations, wishes, and car is something to behold. He demonstrates not only a comedic talent, but convincing dramatic appeal as well.

On the other hand, Mia Sara is pretty generic and dull as Sloane. She is certainly pretty, but seems so lifeless compared to the two main boys. While her acting is flat, Jennifer Grey's is so dynamic! Grey is very funny and sympathetic as Ferris' sister Jean. She gives passionate speeches and underhanded comments throughout that always make me smile. Her indignant moaning about Ferris getting away with everything is so funny to me still.

Even Charlie Sheen makes a cameo in the police station putting on his best James Dean from Rebel Without a Cause to funny results. His snark and causal matter of fact delivery to Grey's character remains as funny and strange as ever.

Lastly, Jeffrey Jones is great as the stuffy principal, chasing down Ferris, with goofy results. While he is over the top, you could argue the whole movie takes on a life of its own with ridiculous bits that you will just have to go along with and believe. It's more about the adventure of spending time with your friends than just buying into the nihilism of caring that Ferris spews at you.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of John Hughes' finest achievements, regardless of how well its themes, cast, and situations have aged. I think this will always be a fun movie despite the campy tone and too silly slap stick bits. It is great for an afternoon watch, so long as you are not rooting for Ferris to fail. Just go along with the ride and you'll have a good time.

Ferris, one of the biggest procrastinators in film history, decides to take a day off from school and suggests/forces his closest friends do the same.  What follows is just about the most ridiculously funny high school films to date.  Pulling your parents leg about being sick is one thing, but convincing the entire city of Chicago that you're nearly on your death bed when you're actually singing Twist and Shout in the middle of a parade?  That's another thing entirely.

Yes, seeing a principle go to the lengths that Ed Rooney does to take Ferris down is a bit silly.  But when you have a talent like Jeffrey Jones to work with, you have to take advantage of all the physical comedy chances you have.  But speaking of talent, no one could have played Ferris better than Matthew Broderick.  If you don't buy into Ferris breaking the fourth wall within the first minute or so of the film, than the entire story won't work.  But with Broderick's charismatic charm, you buy into every second of it.  

It's like a great 90's action film, it doesn't take itself too seriously.  It knows that most parents wouldn't actually buy into Ferris' "sickness", or that he could impersonate a well-known Chicagoan to get into a restaurant, or even lead a parade, but the film exploits every one of these situations.  They take every chance they get in creating a ridiculously humorous moment.  

It's not going to blow your socks away with a realistically dramatic take on high school or real-life problems (though some are certainly touched upon), but it is a timeless tale of procrastination during youth, and the great lengths that one could go to make their day extraordinary.  The imagination is strong here.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off

High school senior Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) just wants a day off from school and will go to extremes to make that happen.  Ferris is the quintessential popular kid who seems to always get what he wants.  He is hedonistic, charming, smart, and consistently does two things to manipulate others:  first, he tells people what they want to hear, and second, he makes and carries out elaborate plans to trick them.  Ferris begins this day by making his parents believe that he is sick.  This is something to which everyone can relate.  Ferris, however, takes it to the next level by making a contraption that will snore when his bedroom door is opened. This way, if his mom checks on him, she will think he is sound asleep.  This is only one of several schemes that he puts in motion to make others believe he is home sick.  After his family leaves the house he invites some friends to join him.  He convinces his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck), who is a hypochondriac, to get out of bed and join him for the day.  Ferris then concocts a plan to get his girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) out of school.  This is accomplished with a phone call to the school's dean of students claiming there has been a death in her family.  Sloane is a pretty girl that would never miss an opportunity to spend a day away from school with Ferris.  He then convinces Cameron to take Cameron's dad's stunning red Ferrari so they can travel to downtown Chicago in style.

After the three friends arrive in downtown Chicago, they park the precious vehicle in a garage and begin their adventures.  They experience fine dining, professional baseball, and an art museum.  Ferris even sings in a parade.  While all of this is taking place, Ferris's jealous sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey), who knows that he is faking, is doing whatever it takes to make sure Ferris is caught and exposed as the lying faker that he is.  The dean of students at the school is also onto Ferris and will go to extremes to make sure Ferris gets to enjoy a fifth year of high school.  

This day off from school is not just fun and games.  The audience really gets to see the development of Cameron's character.  He is transformed by the end of the day.  Plus, the movie utilizes a style of acting in which the fourth wall is broken.  In other words, Ferris looks right at the camera and talks directly to the audience.  There is no separation, or wall, between the actor and audience.  This helps you feel like you are friends with Ferris Bueller and that you too are enjoying the day off with him, Cameron and Sloane.

Overall the movie is lighthearted and enjoyable to watch.  As stated by Ferris Bueller himself,  " Life moves pretty fast.  If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it."

Director and legendary writer John Hughes might not be recognized by mass audiences for the projects he's made, but movie buffs and critics alike most certainly remember him well. Films like: Planes, Trains & Automobiles, Pretty in Pink, Home Alone, almost all the National Lampoon films, and The Breakfast Club. That and so many are just some of the  films he's wrote/directed for that have not only have been home names today but also resonated with a lot of people growing up in the mid 70's and 80's. And while he sadly took a dark path of terrible films to follow afterwards, i thought it be best to look at his more famous film to date: " Ferris Bueller's Day Off." Yet another film along with countless other well know films that i haven't gotten to see till now. And, a bit to my surprise, i was luck enough to enjoy the film for what it was: Classic 80's being young and enjoying life. Basically John Hughes being John Hughes. And yes while i did kind of mind some of the uncanny coincidences that did occur here and there and the already overused story line that countless other films payed homage to, these are just VERY cynical nitpicks that overall don't break the film at all. Because like i said, i was able to enjoy the premise a lot to just sit back and just enjoy John Hughes doing his thing. Great things such as: A very well done and surprisingly charismatic performance by the young Matthew Broderick before doing Godzilla 98 (yeah him in that was....awful.), a very simple but yet entertaining premise, good performances overall from the whole cast, great jokes both from the slapstick and constant fourth wall breaking, and was overall just a fun film to enjoy. And yes it is great, but the film then gives me a sense of sadness as to how John Hughes goes from making cult-classics for over 20 years and before passing made....Flubber and Baby's Day Out. *Sigh* Who knows for sure. Still a great film though.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is simply a classic, and probably my favorite John Hughes film. It's actually amazing that I enjoy this film, because high school was not a happy-go-lucky time for me, but the brilliance of this movie is that the carefree Ferris really isn't the most important character in the film. It's the story of Cameron that really makes this movie shine, and made it an emotional touch-point for a generation. He is the change character, and the one that many people (like me) can connect with so closely. While I find Ferris' antics silly, and occasionally hilarious, the movie has heart because we see Cameron learning how to grow up. The other character who experiences growth in the film is Jeanie, and her story is also handled brilliantly. I like how Charlie Sheen actually teaches her the pointless nature of jealousy, and simultaneously teaches us as well. I could go on for hours just detailing all the things I love about this movie, because every single scene works for me. It has funny parts, it has dramatic parts, and it has emotional parts. The total package is a movie that I can watch any time and it actually makes me nostalgic for those days. I wonder if the movie would be as engaging for teens of this generation, or if so many of us connect with it merely because it was such a product of the 1980s. I'd recommend it to anyone because I love the movie, but I have a feeling only those of us who saw it when we were in high school will form that same emotional connection.

"Ferris Bueller" has its moments, and most of the best ones are of its own making. The much greater number of moments that don't work are a mix of atonal original content and otiose memes of better films.

Almost immediately, Ferris sets the movie outside the bounds of realism by talking to the camera. The technique suits Matthew Broderick's characteristic sense of detachment from the process of acting, his ability to exist on screen without seeming to even try to act but without seeming at all natural either. The cold eyes and feces-eating grin that accompany his verbal asides, though, give the impression that something more is going on in the film than whimsy. There is a darkness-not exactly a darkness, but a kind of menacing quality to the movie, as though it were a prank, and the audience is forever suspended in the instant of dawning horror and appreciation. It as as if John Hughes and a real-life Ferris Bueller are out joyriding in our cars while we are trying to figure out what we are watching, and realizing that it is both a joke for us and a joke on us.

The laugh-out-loud bits are played fairly straight. Ben Stein's steady drone in front of catatonic students. Charlie Sheen's cameo in which "drugs" is an inevitable but perfectly-timed punchline. The cheery profanity of a seemingly old-fashioned school secretary. A glorious song and dance number in the middle of the movie fills the streets of Chicago with color, and the spectacle seems as rich with directorial intent as it is with pure exuberance. John Hughes' placement of WASP city fathers on one side of the street, the ethnic European element of the city in the center, and the black community on the other side is undoubtedly conscious, and is appropriate for Chicago. There is probably no attempt at a social message here; it is part of the movie's non-judgmental celebration of the Windy City, and to portray the city as integrated would have been false.

A gawking fixation on Chicago adds to the sense that there is a movie going on beneath the movie, because there is no way that a kid like Ferris would choose this itinerary for his dream day. The Sears Tower? It's only for tourists. The Art Institute and its collection of 19th and 20th century masterpieces? Please. A black tie restaurant? I'd expect a real teenager to prefer deep-dish pizza and brats. Maybe the secret to understanding Ferris is that he's having the dream day that adults wish they had had, but only if they had known then what they know now.

But if Ferris is such a figure of fantasy, and so above the movie, why does Hughes burden him and his friends with the serious suburban anxieties that some people decades later derisively dub "affluenza"? Hughes had covered that ground very well in "The Breakfast Club," a film whose kids are much more real. In this movie, with its cultivated sense of superiority and apathy, the periodic downshift produces whiplash and slows the pace to an intolerable crawl. Alan Ruck is a good actor, but his best friend character is designed to be a drag and succeeds at it better than intended. Mia Sara's idealized, sexualized girlfriend character is a drag, too, because she has so much less mold-breaking individuality than Ally Sheedy and Molly Ringwold had brought to their earlier collaborations with John Hughes and Matthew Broderick.

Yet "Ferris Bueller" prefigures 21st-century entertainment in a way that the thoroughly dated brat pack films do not. Its use of antihumor, wherein a joke is held in abeyance for a long time while anticipation builds, and in which the big payoff is often understated, paved the way for postmodern high school comedies like "Napoleon Dynamite." This approach to humor is best exemplified by the additional content that plays during the movie's closing credits. Such stingers are rarely seen before "Ferris Bueller" but became a staple of the genre afterward. Instead of using 80s hits, the movie's musical cues are more timeless, like John Lennon and the theme from "Star Wars." Frequently, though, its pop culture references feel arbitrary and meaningless. Why bring "Alien" or Wayne Newton into this? They're drawn from a hat, like a "Family Guy" joke or an internet gif. Like them, the uneven "Ferris Bueller" is sometimes funny, sometimes obnoxious, and sometimes just puzzling.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a film to take a day off for.  Its a high school kid who is determined to get another day off of school at any cost while his principle tries to prevent that.  This film was written and directed by John Hughes who before this directed films such as Weird Science, The Breakfast Club and Sixteen Candles.

Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) loves to miss school and he doesn't just miss school he goes all out when he does it.  This time he has gotten it so that the entire community believes that he is on his death bed and needs help.  On this day off he forces his best friend Cameron Fry (Alan Ruck) to come along on his journey even though he is sick.  It takes Ferris some time to convince Cameron to join him but he finally does.  The two of them come up with an elaborate plan to get Ferris's girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) out of school and in on their day of fun.  They need principle Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) to believe that Sloane's dad is picking her up from school so they take Cameron's father's precious Ferrari for transportation.  After they pick up Sloane they start their crazy fun filled day all the while, the principal Ed Rooney is determined to prove Ferris is faking his illness and Ferris's agitated sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey) also has a goal to catch Ferris off guard.   The gang all enjoy their day off from school that is until they realize that there is a lot more mileage on the Ferrari than there should be and Cameron loses it.

"A high school wise guy is determined to have a day off from school, despite of what the principal thinks of that" (IMDb). Yes, I'm talking about Director John Hughes greatest creation, Ferris Beuller's Day off. Bringing in over six million dollars during opening weekend, Ferris Beuller's Day Off dominated theaters. Since June 11, 1986 we still can't get enough of this humorous, relatable, and alluding film. With an enjoyed audience percentage of ninety two on Rotten Tomatoes, Ferris Beuller was THE movie.
"Teenaged Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) is a legend in his own time thanks to his uncanny skill at cutting classes and getting away with it" (Rotten Tomatoes).  Ferris is not only the big man in school, a consistent ditcher, and sneaky. Ferris Beuller is hilarious. Between finessing his oblivious parents, annoying his sister, pressuring his pessimistic best friend, and getting under the principals skin. From the Economics teacher not recognizing his name, resulting in the famous line " Beuller? Beuller?" (IMDb). From stealing the Ferrari of his best friend's father, to getting it stolen by parking attendants. From his amazing lip- syncing rendition of "Twist and Shout" during a parade to running through backyards of the neighborhood to beat his parents home.  His humor, sarcasm, and witty comments made each scene ten times better. Ferris Beullers day off has you laughing from beginning to end. 
Ferris Beullers day off is relatable to every teenager. Nina Darnton states that, "Mr. Hughes is at his best in creating the nitty-gritty realism of the teen-age world, dealing with problems that really bother them: groups, parents, pressure, self-definition, much as Judy Blume does in her best-selling books" (Darnton, New York Times). This film portrays the oblivious, push-over, fun loving parents. Mr. & Mrs. Beuller easily fell for Ferris's "cough cough, I'm sick mommy" scheme. A scheme we've all pulled on our parents yet didn't go on such an adventure as Ferris did. Ferris Beuller didn't exactly give into peer pressure. Ferris was the peer pressure. It's not every day your friend pressures you into taking your dads three hundred thousand dollar car to go on an adventure in Chicago. Cameron, the best friend, was seen as giving into peer pressure throughout his day with Ferris. Some saw that his decisions were solely based around Ferris, as others saw Cameron as finding himself through these decisions.  Self- definition is also a big pressure portrayed in this film.  Throughout this film, Cameron and Ferris are finding themselves through this adventure. Hoping this would be his final game of hooky; Ferris just wants to be relieved of all the pressures of school and finding himself after he graduates.  Ferris Beullers day off is not only humorous, but relatable for teenagers. We all just need to escape every once in a while.
Ferris Beullers Day Off is alluding and a little inspiring to us onlookers. Haflidason states, "Matthew Broderick takes the type of day off that all of us aspire to but somehow never quite replicate in this famous 80s comedy" (Haflidason, BBC). It's a movie that makes you think about your life, wishes, and regrets. Like Haflidason said, Ferris had a day we all fantasize over. Setting everything aside, he just wanted to feel alive this one last time with his best friend and beautiful girlfriend. Many viewer reviews agreed that not only teenagers but also adults could learn something from Ferris. Most of us teenagers are too busy studying, reading chapters, freaking out over exams, and drowning in energy drinks. The film alludes that everyone needs to live every now and then. A day from school to explore your local cities may be the little adventure you need to stay sane. Like Ferris himself said in the film, "Life moves pretty fast. If you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it" (IMDb.)
	What is a great movie without Humor? Laughing from beginning to end, Ferris Beulllers Day Off was a crowd pleasing movie. Its humor may have played a big part in drawing the audience, but it's relatable scenarios won over the audience. Teenagers indulging worldwide will be able to relate to the pressures Ferris wanted to escape. Describing the day many wish they could live, Beuller alludes that we all stop, bask, and enjoy our lives. Given eight stars out of ten, Ferris Beullers Day Off was marvelous.

After watching Ferris Bueller's Day Off, my opinion of it is very similar to Groundhog Day. It's a good, well written fun comedy that doesn't need to be taken seriously. The story is straight forward and takes place within just 1 day, meaning that there is not much to take in. The film plays out with a good pace with it only slowing down slightly before it reaches the final lot of scenes. The film shouldn't be taken seriously with some over the top scenes, but that's the style John Hughes decides to showcase his story as the focused more on the teenagers rather than the parents. 
Other than the script, it is the selection of actors cast in the roles that keeps the film flowing. Matthew Broderick in one of his early roles creates one of his best roles and the lesser known Alan Ruck brings a fun character to his scenes. If i had to be disappointed in anyone's character then it would have to be Jennifer Grey. I'm not saying she was bad, but I just didn't really enjoy the character too much and felt some of her lines could have been toned down in performance. There is also a nice small appearance from Charlie Sheen that is quite ironic when knowing about his personal problems. However, I felt the highlight of the film belonged to Jeffrey Jones as the Principal. Some of the best scenes and lines were from his character and I would have loved more of him featured.
