I appreciate the irony in the fact that after this film, Matthew Broderick, as far as we knew, was the only one in this film who didn't get a day off, because everyone else in this film seemed to all but fall off the radar, which is surprising, considering the impact that this film had on a lot of young folks. Yeah, nothing says, "coming-of-age film" quite like skipping out on responsibilities, kids. Yeah, an education is pretty important in life, too, although I am all for youths embracing life in all of its glory, especially if their revelatory adventure makes Chicago look a little less scary. People, we all knew that John Hughes loved Chicago, but wow, this is about as much as love letter to Chicago as it is a love letter to youth spirit, which I suppose makes it the definitive John Hughes film. Not unlike youth, you've got to embrace this film while you can, because after this, Hughes took himself a break from coming-of-age films and started making movies about grown-ups and stuff. I can't believe Ferris Bueller went through all of the trouble rebelling against both the fourth wall and grown-ups, only for Hughes to end up rejecting youth films... although, in all fairness, he was 36 at the time of this film's release, and he was getting a little old to understand young people problems of the '80s. Well, at least he had enough of a grip to make a film that can be enjoyed by kids, grown-ups and Barbara Bush alike (Way to stay relevant for the Wellesley College kids, Barb), despite having problems beyond a questionable coming-of-age moral (Forget you, Pink Floyd, the kids do need an education).

Saying hardly anything off the bat, then proceeding to give only so much exposition as it progresses, the film probably doesn't need to say much as an almost inconsequential young adult character piece, but developmental shortcomings make it a little difficult to get invested in, or even buy into characters, only so many of which are morally relatable. Storytelling is sharp enough, and acting is charismatic enough, for the characters to endear pretty thoroughly, although there's something a little sleazy about the most major ones, and that's, maybe not distancing, but a little obnoxious at times, in a manner that would be easier to get past if the characters were more fleshed out or, for that matter, organically juggled. While the film is, on the whole, minimalist as a character-driven affair, it will often bring in some layers to its cast and focus, only to find trouble in keeping up with it all, resulting in a certain focal unevenness which makes it even harder to get invested in the characters. Perhaps the film would be a little more even if it was tighter in its storytelling, being not especially overlong with its 102-minute runtime, but still with certain touches of filler that outstay their welcome and thin already uneven focus, which would, of course, feel tighter if this narrative carried more intrigue to justify its execution's length. There's simply not a whole lot to say with a story like this, and that's fine, considering the entertainment value of the idea's interpretation, yet the inspiration that backs this flick most every step of the way can carry the final product only so far. The film is fun, make no mistake, but it's not much outside of that, and when inspiration fails to meet the ambition which begets too much bloating for consistency in focus and pacing, it's hard to not be reminded of the limited potential here. With all that said, the film entertains pretty thoroughly, so much so that it borders on rewarding, and stands as worthy of certain recognition, even for its story.

No matter how inconsequential, this film's story concept is relatively solid, as far as comedic narratives are concerned, being colorful and even unique as a portrait on youths' somewhat reasonable, if a little convoluted mission to embrace life while there's still plenty of it, even if it's for only one day. This story is both refreshing and relatable, and that's respectable, as John Hughes seems to understand, even as writer, offering snappy, often even, for a young adult film, gutsy dialogue and lively humor, all behind memorable set pieces - such as unique fourth-wall breaks that give you insight into the mind of the titular character - and, of course, memorable characterization that, while focally uneven and sometimes a bit obnoxious in its intentional drawing of flaws, presents generally charming and distinguished characters. If nothing else brings color to the characters, it's the characters' portrayers, with standouts including a Jeffrey Jones who convinces as a clumsily bitter antagonist, and an Alan Ruck who convinces as a self-conscious voice of reason with his own charming faith in fun, while Matthew Broderick, in a breakout performance, truly drives the film with his butter-smooth charisma and slick energy. While his charm doesn't find its share of challenges in this cast of limited star power, but abundant color, Broderick more-or-less carries the film, which also owes much of its liveliness to style, even musical. Flaunting a trio of composers which includes Ira Newborn, Arthur Baker and John Robie, the film's score is diverse, yet consistently stylish and lively, with moments of borderline killer flare that joins a couple fun tunes in the unoriginal soundtrack in drawing you in almost as much as dynamic locations that paint a handsome and immersive portrait on the distinct setting of Chicago. The film even offers a fine deal of style that, quite frankly, perhaps would be as effectively lively if it wasn't so well-orchestrated by Hughes, as director, whose plays on the aforementioned musical and visual style, and even on Paul Hirsch's snappy editing, keep pacing brisk, and whose occasional thoughtful moments ought to immerse you into the thematic depth of this portrait on coming of age and achieving independence. It's hard to fully agree with a lot of the characters' actions, but the overall theme in this coming-of-age flick is surprisingly subtle and worthy, thus giving the film a heart to go with all of the fun that may not exactly be substantial to the point of seeing the final product transcend its natural shortcomings, but certainly make quite the memorable comedy classic.

At the end of the day, the characters are a little underdeveloped, sometimes obnoxious, and occasionally unevenly handled, while storytelling proves to be repetitiously overdrawn enough for you to think about the inconsequentiality of the narrative concept that render the final product kind of underwhelming, but hardly so underwhelming that a unique and thematically worthy story, on the backs of clever scripting, charming performances, sharp style and colorful, when not thoughtful direction, fails to be enough to drive John Hughes' "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" as a classically fun, if near-inconsequential study on embracing life and youth.

John Hughes makes it look easy.  So this is about the classic ne'er-do-well Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick), who decides to play hooky from high school and spend a day in the city with his girlfriend and best friend.  This is another one of those spectacularly 80's movies that still holds up.  Throughout the entire film, the sense of fun is never lost at any point, and that has everything to do with the young Broderick.  Everything about his performance is smirking and self-aware; the sheer number of times he breaks the fourth wall to address the audience is only made possible because of his natural charisma (also, this movie has one of the best stingers of all time).  You also have the principal, Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), who plays one of the more underrated movie villains; just because your movie is a comedy doesn't mean you can't have a quality villain, and Ferris Bueller's Day Off never forgets that.  The focus on the movie is always on the best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck), who is an interesting character to watch, because it is never completely clear how much responsibility lies on his shoulders; sometimes, he plays the victim, and sometimes he is the cause of his own demise.  It's always funny to see how pointless high school can sometimes be, and Ferris Bueller serves as a reminder that it is good for your personal mental health to call out for no reason every now and again.

"Ferris Bueller's Day Off" features Matthew Broderick as the titular character Ferris. On a school day where Ferris is supposed to take a test on a subject that frankly he doesn't care at all about he decides to fake an illness and go out and have fun with his girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) and his best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck). The three decide to go out in style by "borrowing" Mr. Frye's prized 1961 Ferrari 250 FT California Spyder convertible an proceed to explore the city, spending their day sightseeing, visiting attractions, spinning circles around the adults that would send them back to school. Meanwhile the school's Dean Edward Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) tries to bust Forrest, as he is determined to expose him as a juvenile delinquent so he can hold him back a year.

There are two kinds of people that will leave the film, the first are the ones that will leave thinking that Ferris actually is just a juvenile delinquent and the second are the ones who will get swept up by the protagonist's charms. It's easy to see why you wouldn't enjoy the movie at first. Why does Ferris get to fool his parents and skip school while everyone else goes to class? Doesn't he know he's making his parents worry? What about the staff who are just trying to do their job? This kid's just trying to get his friends in trouble by stealing the car! someone catch up with this guy before he hurts someone for goodness sake! To those people, I say calm down for a second and really take a look at the movie. Ferris has a point early in the film when he comments on the test he is supposed to take that day. The test is about a subject that will have no bearings on his life whatsoever; it's useless information and even the teachers that are dispensing the lessons have no interest in it so why bother? Instead of staying at his desk all day and simply learning about life outside, Ferris actually goes outside and lives it. An example is at the Art Institute of Chicago where the trio go to admire some of the pieces on display. It's a beautiful sequence where the characters look at paintings and really analyze and appreciate them (it's done through a montage but you can clearly see Cameron inspecting "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte" by Geirges Seurat). Set to the music of The Smiths, it's moving to see because of the combination of subject matter, music and cinematography. Sure the group get into a couple of situations where they trick adults but for the most part they're not causing any trouble at all. The reason why you're put off by Ferris' behaviour at first is because none of us were that cool. No one dared to skip school so they could go on an adventure and see everything there was to see out there. None of us had the beautiful and dedicated boyfriend/girlfriend that was ready to drop everything and go off on a crazy notion that we had, none of us had the guts to laugh at the authorities and not get caught. You're jealous of the guy but once you learn to just accept that and go along for the ride as his friend Cameron does, it's a heck of a lot of fun.

The film is extremely well written, with many quotable lines and memorable moments. This movie is so iconic that you've seen it parodied at least a dozen times and probably never even knew. Ever seen a movie where there's a car flying over a jump in slow motion? Ever seen a character fail miserably at something and have a musical note laugh at them, "sad tuba" style? Or even more iconic, ever hear that porno-sounding track "Oh Yeah" by Yello, while something awesome is going on? Check this movie out. You'll notice the scene where the Frye's car is flying and the scene where Dean Rooney gets busted at the arcade just as the game of Pacman next to him ends (with the iconic death rattle playing as he realizes how badly he's screwed up). As for the song with Yello, well you'll just have to see for yourself. The characters are iconic and you'll relate to them very well, be it because you want to be like Ferris or because you're seeing a part of yourself in the other characters around him. As the movie progresses his friends and his sisters get a new take on life and while you're sitting there appreciating the movie, you will too. I'm making it sound like the movie is very deep and thought provoking but really that material is a subtext in a very funny and lighthearted film. It's filled with clever one-liners, close calls and smart commentary on the way life treats teenagers. It's a treat to listen to.

There are a few moments of bad over-acting and at least one scene where the movie goes a bit too much into fantasy land but you won't really mind. Even if at first you didn't care for the film, give it another shot and particularly, pay attention to the scene where Jennifer Grey (playing Jeanie, Ferris' sister) is stuck at the police station. There's a nice exchange of dialogue there that will really turn you around on the whole "juvenile delinquent" thing and it's such a crowd pleaser that the material is sure to grow on you. If you haven't seen it, you're missing out and if you have the opportunity to see it for the first time when you're still in school it will really resonate with you. I can't recommend it highly enough. (Theatrical version on the big screen, August 13, 2013)

Ferris Bueller is arguably the greatest creation of writer/director John Hughes, the man who ruled the roost of '80s teen movies. Personified by Matthew Broderick, Beuller was the "righteous dude" whom everybody in high school loves and it's easy to see why. The character is such a likeable slacker that even though we ought to tut disapprovingly at him for fooling his parents into thinking he's ill so he can bunk off school, he does this so he can help out his best friend Cameron who's having a rough time. We all want a friend like Ferris.
Out to catch Ferris is Mr Rooney, devious and slimy high school teacher. It's basically a rip off of Tom and Jerry with Ferris in the mouse role, continuously outsmarting Rooney. It doesn't descend to the cartoon violence levels of Hughes' Home Alone but the animation influence is felt.
Hughes has put together a flawless script for Ferris Bueller. It's full of proper characters, even those who only get a few lines you feel that you could paint a rich back history too. The dialogue is some of the best ever committed to celluloid and at times is extremely funny. The interplay between Ferris and Cameron, and the two with Ferris' girlfriend Sloane is pitch perfect.
To top it all off there's a street parade, dance sequence to The Beatles Twist and Shout, that is even better than it sounds.

John Hughes introduces us to another character stuck inside his head,the teenage dynamo Ferris Bueller.Bueller, played by Matthew Broderick, decides to create an elaborate hoax out of one of the oldest pastimes of the generation, skippingJohn Hughes introduces us to another character stuck inside his head,the teenage dynamo Ferris Bueller.Bueller, played by Matthew Broderick, decides to create an elaborate hoax out of one of the oldest pastimes of the generation, skipping school. But what sets this film part as another teen movie is not the premise of the film, but the actual character of Bueller and is influence on his little entourage of classmates and is entire school who hear about his 'illness'.Ferris orchestrates several ways so as his day off goes smoothly, dummy in the bed, recorded message for the doorbell etc, but a persistent school principal (Jeffrey Jones) may just wreck that.The day really consists of various places that Ferris has clearly wanted to visit, and a very memorable scene at a parade, which is just too enjoyable.Alan Ruck also stars as the worrying and depressive Cameron, Ferris' best friend but someone who has issues with his parents. Mia Sara plays Sloane, Ferris' girlfriend, who Ferris manages to get out of school.The movie has all the vintage touches of Hughes, the in-your-face cinematography and the exaggerated moments of simple scenarios with pounding music to signify the scene.Ferris continuously speaks directly to the camera, this is quite clever in that we see the influence and effect that he has on the other characters and the bigger, overall picture of what is being told, he is narrating the insecurities that teens face in their everyday lives, and what it means to be free, and also the simple case of not having everything doesn't necessarily make him unhappy.What I feel took the film down though was Hughes excessive use of his dramatised camera techniques, they just become annoying and didn't suit the style of the film at all, and the film could have benefited greatly without them.The message within the film does do the whole feature justice though, dealing with problems head on and looking out for your friends couldn't be more heartfelt in this film. Something as simple as freedom for the youth couldn't be more important, and Matthew Broderick has the perfect face and charm to put across that message. Certainly not an amazing film, but the agenda that the film has is one of the upmost importance and is a nice deterrent from the typical teen films that we are now accustomed to, if you don't stop for a while and admire it, you might just miss it.

I think all teens have felt this urge, and often have, or played sick for one more day toThis movie is a light and fun comedy that takes us back to school days. After all, who hasn't wanted to take a day off and simply enjoy their youth? I think all teens have felt this urge, and often have, or played sick for one more day to themselves. What, surely, will never have happened is something as complex and sophisticated as what Ferris Bueller decided to do.The film is fun and uses a tasteful comedy style, without good resources, able to delight the whole family. John Hughes assures a firm and intelligent direction, who guides the film with skill, combining a creative and intelligent story with a very well written and thought out sense of humor.The still young and inexperienced Matthew Broderick does a good job as the protagonist, and is already showing signs of the talent he will develop in mature works. He knew how to give his character a strong charisma, combined with a rebelliousness and stubbornness typical of a teenager who has been pampered too much. Mia Sara did an equally competent job, even though she's a more cliché character: she's the pretty, popular girlfriend, who's obviously also one of the school's cheerleaders. We find characters like her in virtually every teen comedy! Personally, I didn't like Alan Ruck very much. The actor is good and does what he can, but the character is irritating with all his spoiled rich boy whining. However, it's not just Broderick that makes the movie worthwhile: Jeffrey Jones' incredible work also deserves applause. He gave life to the school principal, who wants to prove that Ferris Bueller is deliberately skipping classes, and at the expense of that, he goes through a series of hilarious situations where, of course, he suffers hard. It's an impressive work by this actor, which makes us laugh until we cry.Technically, it's a film that doesn't have any major demerits, but it also has little that stands out: it has good cinematography, an excellent soundtrack and a series of witty and well-written dialogues, but everything else is within the standard you would expect from a 80s comedy.
